PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That human embryos deserve legal protection to enable the development of their full human potential.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Pass Senator Harradine's Bill to prohibit experiments involving the use of human embryos created by in virto fertilisation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 92 citizens), Button (from 904 citizens), Chipp (from 857 citizens), Coates (from 147 citizens), Cooney (from 956 citizens), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 956 citizens), Hamer (from 935 citizens), Lajovic (from 474 citizens), Mason (from 167 citizens), Missen (from 836 citizens), Primmer (from 995 citizens), Robert Ray (from 961 citizens), Scott (from 127 citizens), Townley (from 112 citizens) and Watson (from 187 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the Pharmaceutical Industry in Australia views with concern the failure in Government policy to recognise sufficiently the importance of brand-name products, developed by research-based companies;
Since the progress in development of new, safe and effective pharmaceuticals is vitally dependent on the economic viability of a research-based Pharmaceutical Industry.
Since the economic viability is a pre-condition for the continued employment of our well educated and skilled workforce in all aspects of the industry activity.

Since full information and reliable technical back-up can only be provided in easily accessible form from product information available from the research-based companies which are product originators.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should

initiate policies which ensure that continued access of Australians to safe and effective pharmaceuticals is secured through encouraging growth of a research-based Pharmaceutical Manufacturing Industry in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Costigan Royal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are greatly concerned with the extent to which serious crime including murder, major drug financing and massive tax frauds have penetrated into the highest levels of Australian society as shown by the investigations of various Royal Commissioners and in particular by Mr. Frank Costigan Q.C.

That we are concerned that the National Crime Authority has too many restrictions and possible lines of veto placed upon it for it to be an effective successor to the Costigan Enquiry and that this will allow major criminals to avoid prosecution.

And your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government negotiate urgently with the Victorian Government on the reactivation of the Costigan Commission and to extend its term to at least the 31st March 1985 and also to provide the Costigan Commission with whatever resources it may need to successfully conclude its investigations into organised crime in Australia. Further we believe that the issue of organised crime in Australia is so important that the Parliament should not be dissolved until at least the interim Costigan Report has been received and fully debated in both Houses of the Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Students: Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Parliament assembled. The humble petitioners of certain undersigned Australian and overseas students respectfully showeth that:
1. The overseas student program brings in a multitude of cultural, political and educational benefits as well as a net financial gain of A$5 million p.a., in foreign exchange. (Ref: Goldring Report)

2. Overseas students are under financial constraints. Most depend on their families for this financial support. The Goldring Report found 62% of overseas students come from families with annual combined parental income of less than A$15,000.

3. The imposition of high overseas student charges will deprive many overseas students from getting a tertiary education and qualification in Australia despite their academic abilities. High charges will determine education in Australia for overseas students on economic grounds.
4. The imposition of sudden and drastic increases in visa charges will also particularly disadvantage those current students, many of whom will be forced to discontinue their studies.
5. Overseas students do not displace local students. They represent a mere 3.4% of tertiary students. (Goldring Report)
6. The fluctuations and uncertainty in overseas students policy has led to uncertainty, stress and fear in overseas students.
Your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray that:

1. The Government re-affirm a commitment to its policy that supports the social and economic development of people and institutions in developing countries through access to Australia's education and training resources.
2. The Government formulate a consistent and considerate policy concerning overseas students.
3. The Government reconsider, as a matter of urgency, the legislation of such a high increase in visa charges.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we strongly oppose the 'A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill' introduced by Senator Jack Evans, because it will adversely affect sporting organisations and small businesses in the A.C.T., it reverses the onus of proof, and represents an unnecessary intrusion by Government into the private affairs of individuals and other groups.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject this Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Abortion Clinic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned who have great concern for the protection of the unborn child, call upon the Government to reject the Vinson Enquiry recommendation that an Abortion Clinic be established in Canberra.
And your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will reject this recommendation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Indirect Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and the members of the Senate assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that to pose a broadly-based consumption tax would mean a proportionately greater burden on low income groups and increase proverty stricken victims already existing within Australia. Petition against the proposed issue of indirect consumption taxation. So 'help' we pray!
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Indirect Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows that:
We, the undersigned electors, are deeply concerned at the possibility of an increase in indirect taxation currently being considered by the government.
To pose a broadly based consumption tax would mean a proportionately greater burden on low income groups and worsen their already precarious and impoverished position.

Women who are supporting mothers, together with their children, are acknowledged as the largest single group forced to exist below the poverty line. As beneficiaries of an already inadequate government pension, their futures would be even more jeopardised if there were to be a change towards increased broadly based consumption taxation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Federal government not adopt the proposed shift towards increased indirect taxation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the reason I opposed the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill being taken as a whole in Committee is that, quite clearly, this Bill has two clearly defined purposes. One is to amend the Nursing Homes Assistance Act, which now has been dealt with by the Committee, and the second is to amend the Social Security Act 1947 for the purpose of abolishing family allowance payments for certain student children over the age of 18 years.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Committee stage I am not able to rehearse everything that was said last night during the second reading debate and I do not intend to do that nor would I be permitted to do so by you, Mr Chairman. However, I do wish to have clarified for me, for the Senate and, indeed, for the people of Australia what the precise effect of this proposition will be. As I understand the situation, the effect will be to take away family allowance payments made to the mother of student children over the age of 18 years and to make adjustments in the same fashion as would be the case if those children became employed or were entitled to receive unemployment benefits. To take the example I gave last night, that would have the same effect on the payment of the family allowance for other children in the family as if the two oldest children became employed or were eligible for unemployment benefits. If that is the case I believe that this proposition is unjust.

Last night I made out a case which indicated that the measure was unjust and contrary to the principle of horizontal equity. I remind honourable senators of the example that was given last night of a person who is earning only about $1,700 or $1,800 above average earnings per year and who has five children, the two oldest daughters being at the Australian National University. That family could lose $84.55 a month. It could lose $55.35 because of the operation of this measure in respect of the two students at the ANU. However, because of the operation of the principal Act-that is, the Social Security Act 1947-the mother will lose an additional $29.20 per month because the three remaining children in the family will go on to lower scales of family allowance. One could understand that situation if the two oldest girls were employed but in this situation the two oldest girls are still dependent, notwithstanding the fact that the mother will not be eligible to receive the family allowance in respect of those oldest children.

I wonder whether I am reading the legislation correctly. If I am reading it correctly I think that some amendment ought to be considered by the Government in respect of this matter. I will put it another way. Were the two oldest children in this case the only children of the family, come November, the loss would be $55.35 per month. That is bad enough because those children would still be dependent, but why should the family concerned incur an additional penalty of $29.20 per month simply because it is a larger family? I feel that the Government should take that on board and if it is not prepared to recognise the principle of horizontal equity-and a lot of members of the Government are prepared to recognise it-at least it should consider the matter and come up with some adjustment to this scheme in August.

I point out that I do not quibble about the abolition of family allowances in respect of children who are employed or eligible for unemployment benefit. Obviously those children are no longer dependent and therefore the mother is not entitled to receive family allowances. In fact, in most cases those children are able to make some sort of contribution to the home finances. But in respect of the people we are discussing now-the two girls who are over the age of 18-they are unable to make a financial contribution to the family budget and, in addition, because they are students, the family must make direct and indirect adjustments. Not only must the family support those children in respect of the payments of fees, union dues, book costs, transport and so on, but it must also make adjustments in the home itself. In many cases quite substantial alterations must be made to the home, particularly if there are five children as there are in this case. This must be done in order to create an atmosphere that is conducive to the successful achievement of those children in the tertiary or secondary spheres of education.

If I am correct in my assessment, I believe that this measure is contrary to the principles of horizontal equity and common sense. It is also contrary to the stated policy of the Government to encourage families to keep their children at school so as to ensure their successful completion of the higher school certificate in the secondary sphere and their continuation to tertiary education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said last night, I appreciate Senator Harradine's position on this. In general, I support the payment of family allowances for the reasons that he has outlined-that they are the only demographic indicator we have. They provide horizontal equity and they are a tax measure. But we have to weigh up the situation. Not only is the maintenance of some sort of horizontal equity important, but also we must consider equity generally across the community of payments of this type. Governments have to make decisions on the basis of priorities, particularly in times like this, and the decision was made that the removal of family allowances for those aged 18 and above, who are adults in our community-with the exceptions that I have mentioned here-was an equitable thing to do in the light of the May statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me comment on the examples that were given by Senator Harradine. I always find that difficult in this place because we never know all the details. However, I will put some suggestions to him. First of all, if someone is on average weekly earnings with two children at the Australian National University and three other children at home, those children must be getting at least a part tertiary education assistance scheme allowance. If they are getting TEAS they are not getting family allowances now because the family allowance is absorbed into TEAS. There may be other circumstances. Maybe the income is not as high as Senator Harradine implied, but I think in Canberra it is likely to be. If the maximum adjusted family income is $400 a week-with five children, two at university and three at school-and the two at university are not getting either full TEAS or part TEAS, they have not applied for it; but they are certainly eligible for it. Therefore they would not be getting the family allowance now as the family allowance is absorbed into the TEAS payment. In the specific case that Senator Harradine mentioned I cannot see that that will make a difference. I think that every member of parliament has had complaints from families particularly very large families, in the situation of having a child reaching the age of 16 or a child over the age of 16 going into employment which results in the family allowances being removed under the existing legislation because the family allowance is calculated on the number of people in the rest of the family. It is the large amount, up to $7 or $9, which is removed. That is the way in which the system has operated since the introduction of the family allowance. I believe that is fair and equitable. If we are talking about horizontal equity we are talking about relating the same payment to each family, depending on the circumstances of the family. If a family has three dependent children, whether that family originally consisted of five or seven children and the kids have grown up or whether it consisted of three children all along, it should get the same family allowance as any family with that number of children.

As Senator Harradine has suggested, I will certainly take the matter up with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to see what inequities may arise. In theory-I stress 'in theory'-those who are eligible for TEAS are not affected because they are not getting the family allowance now; the family allowance payment is subsumed in the TEAS. I know that begs the question of whether the TEAS income test is reasonable or whether it is too harsh. I would be inclined to believe that it is too harsh, but to raise those income levels would cost a considerable amount. The people on the family income supplement whose children are not attracting TEAS-kids with double orphans' pensions, those on the handicapped children's allowance or the children of parents receiving an additional pension or benefit-will continue to get the family allowance under these circumstances as will Aboriginals and those under the isolated children's scheme. Sure, there are some people whose family income will be reduced. They will be primarily, as Senator Harradine pointed out in his speech, people with children at tertiary institutions. I remind honourable senators that university students-this all came out in the recent kerfuffle over university fees-are in a particularly advantageous situation in our society. They receive a considerable subsidy from the public purse for the costs of their training. In many cases they receive TEAS and after training, on the average, they receive a higher income than the rest of the community. So I believe we have to consider the arguments about that type of equity as well as the pure argument of horizontal equity that Senator Harradine is talking about.

As I said, the Government did not like making this decision and I, in particular, did not like making this decision. But I believe there is some argument that students from the age of 18, particularly those in tertiary institutions, are not treated as badly as they sometimes say they are. The Government made the decision it did with a heavy heart and with some difficulty. However, I will certainly refer the matters raised by Senator Harradine to the Minister for Social Security and the Treasurer (Mr Keating).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a question relating to another point. If, for example, the student concerned was eligible for part benefits under the tertiary education assistance scheme, as I read it, the mother of that student would be eligible to receive the family allowance.
—No, that is not the situation now.

—That is the point that I am coming to. There is therefore a cut-off point. In the case I mentioned the cut-off point is $22,280, which is $1,800 above average earnings, plus $450 for each child, which adds up to $24,080. The student child of a person with five children who is on a single income and receiving that amount is not eligible for TEAS, and although the child is still very substantially dependent on the mother and on the family the mother is not eligible for the family allowance. I acknowledge what the Minister has said and I understand the situation that he is placed in. I am grateful for the fact that the matter will be again considered by the Government.

DEBATE.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT (PERSONAL INCOME TAX SHARING) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is about to debate the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1985. Many of us on this side of the chamber feel very bitter about this piece of legislation. This legislation has been introduced by the Government as part of its mini-Budget package. The legislation destroys a major Fraser Government initiative which guaranteed a fixed share of Federal income tax for local government. In 1976 the first Fraser Government placed local government, municipal councils around Australia, on a very firm footing by guaranteeing it 1.52 per cent of revenue raised by the Federal Government from personal income tax for general revenue purposes. In other words, it was not directing local government where or how it should use the funds. Those arrangements were seen as a breakthrough in resources for local government and they were widely supported by all local governments around the nation. It was seen as tangible evidence that the Federal Liberal-National Party recognised the importance of local government in a wide range of public services. The flexibility of the scheme was welcomed as it allowed councils either to expand services or projects, especially those which may have been unacceptable if they had to be financed via increases to property rates, or to use the grants to supplement expenditure on existing functions, thereby alleviating increasing rate burdens.

SPEECH.PARA: Subsequently, the Fraser Government went to the extent of increasing the percentage share of the revenue to 2 per cent of personal income tax raised by the Federal Government. Again, this was greeted with widespread support by local government bodies. In effect then, since 1975 councils have been able to rely on a fairly steady proportion of the annual revenue being provided by the Federal Government by way of a share of personal income tax. These grants, of course, have now become a very important part of the fiscal processes of local government and councils have come to depend upon their continuation and their maintenance in real terms and in fact frequently have been seeking increases.

The fact that councils have been able to rely on this revenue has created a great deal of expectation in councils. Many councils and local government instrumentalities around Australia have been providing new services for people in need in their communities. These new services have arisen particularly in regard to trying to help the unemployed, trying to assist with child minding facilities and other general areas which local councillors can see would be of assistance to people living in their towns. It is clear that there needs to be a decision as to whether local government will continue to provide these services. In many cases, of course, councillors have sought kudos by providing services which perhaps State governments ought to have been providing but have not been providing. So councils have come to spend this revenue on services in respect of which, perhaps one may think in some ways they are exceeding their general responsibilities. Nevertheless, having once provided these services, members of the local community have become dependent upon them, and clearly a need has been seen for the services to such an extent that many councillors wish to expand these services.

The question which then arises is whether councils will continue to provide these services and whether they will expand them. I know that many councillors thought that under an Australian Labor Party government they would get more funds to enable them to expand into these services. The reason that they were thinking along those lines was the ALP policy. I quote the ALP policy from its 'Platform Constitution and Rules'. At paragraph 51 on page 227, it states:
Provide financial assistance for local governments, including-

an annual allocation of at least 2 per cent of Federal personal income tax receipts as a general revenue grant to local government; the allocation in any year to be not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation.

Many ALP candidates in the last election campaign went around espousing that policy to local government and assuring local government bodies that they would probably get more funds from an ALP Federal government to implement these new services which councils are now providing. Of course, what is happening through this legislation is a major breaking of that promise by the ALP Government. Local government has very little opportunity to increase revenue from its own sources. Rate increases in recent years, in most cases, have already exceeded the consumer price index, and other options which are available to local government are indeed very limited. There is no doubt that many complaints are being made by rate payers around the nation about the size of the rates and the expenditure by local government.

During the last election this Government certainly did not make it clear to ratepayers or councillors that it would be doing anything to increase the burden on property owners. It most certainly did not say that it would not follow its platform of continuing the payment of 2 per cent of personal income tax receipts to local government. In fact, what will happen now is that either local government will have to cut back on the services which it is currently providing or it will have to raise revenue from the rates source that is available to it. That would mean increased rates at a time when the community is already suffering the burden of rates imposed by local municipalities and land taxes imposed by State governments. Now, this Federal Government in this legislation is about to put further burdens on local government.

In May of 1984 this Government established the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance under Professor Self. Professor Self and his committee of inquiry are due to report in September. This Government is not even prepared to wait until it receives Professor Self's report. It seems that this Government has so mismanaged its budgeting and financial arrangements-I refer to its current mismanagement on the question of the returns which were estimated at $800m in excess of what it will actually receive-that it has told us in its mini-Budget that it needs $52m from local government. It is not prepared to wait until it receives the report of Professor Self before it deducts that $52m from local government.

The Government is quite prepared to disrupt the long term fiscal planning of local government, and by grabbing this amount of money hopes to spread the mess so that in some way or another people will not recognise its mismanagement but will complain about local government instead of complaining about the Federal Government. I point out that local government has expended enormous effort in co-operating with Professor Self's inquiry. It seems that that effort may have been totally wasted. At the appropriate time we shall move an in principle amendment condemning the Government for its broken promise to local municipalities around Australia.

Where to now? The Liberal-National Party Opposition is in a position where it would be damned if it does and damned if it does not. This legislation is presented as part of the mini-Budget package. As I have said, there are many people with bitter feelings about this Government taking away a Fraser Government initiative, but this proposal is presented, in effect, as a financial Bill and we recognise that at the last election the ALP was elected to govern, not the Liberal and National parties. If this Government says to the Parliament that it needs to save this $52m because of its mismanagement and if the Liberal and National parties are to remain a responsible Opposition, they are obligated to accept the Government's decision.

In saying that I draw the Senate's attention to the many occasions when the ALP in opposition refused to adopt that principle. On many occasions the Labor Opposition joined with the Democrats to prevent the coalition Government from raising revenue or cutting expenditure. I draw attention to that point because this is an occasion when we could join with the Democrats to prevent the Government from taking this step. The Democrats do not have to be responsible or to be seen to be responsible as economic managers. They will never be in government. The Democrats will continue their current policy of seeking votes from anywhere and everywhere by opposing all increases in revenue and all cuts in expenditure. Last night the Democrats were seeking votes of ex-servicemen around the country by opposing Government legislation in that area. Today, the Democrats will be seeking the votes of local municipalities by taking an irresponsible economic course. But we will not be joining them in that course. We recognise that the ALP was elected to govern and if the Labor Government has so mismanaged its affairs and needs to save $52m by cutting the grant to local government for this year as part of the mini-Budget package, the Opposition will be accepting that proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) does not hide the hurt and dejection suffered by the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) as a result of the breaking of yet another promise by this Government. Mr Uren has been a driving force in lifting local government from the Cinderella era. The Australian assistance plan arose from his work. Councils have been encouraged to believe that the Federal Government will keep its end of the bargain if councils provide the human services program that the community and the Federal Government ask of them. Now Mr Uren is being forced-under duress if yesterday's report in the Australian is correct-to preside over something that will make local government forever suspicious of future Federal Government undertakings. This is all in the name of doctrinaire, small 'c' conservatism which puts 'talking up the falling Australian dollar' before 'looking into the effects of arbitrary decisions on ordinary people in Australia.'

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister is entitled to feel that he has been betrayed by his more pragmatic colleagues. He is entitled to believe that the Labor Party platform has been sacrificed on the altar of economic slavery and, unfortunately, with little success so far. The Australian people have been sacrificed to the interests of foreign financial speculators and banks. In the Labor Party local government platform under the sub-heading 'Financial Relations', there appears the following undertaking:
A Federal Labor Government will in co-operation with State, Territory and local governments provide financial assistance for local governments, including-

(a) an annual allocation of at least 2 per cent of Federal personal income tax receipts as a general revenue grant to local government: the allocation in any year to be not less than real value of the previous year's allocation;
(b) specific purpose grants and loans to local governments; and
(c) support of local governments borrowing capacity.
These are undertakings made in the Labor platform on which this Government was elected. We have been elected and we have said that we will keep this Government honest. We are doing our best.

Last year there was an expansion in specific purpose grants. However, in the personal income tax area there was an increase in Federal Government collections of only 5.9 per cent. That compared with an inflation rate of 6.9 per cent for 1983-84. So the second part of that first plank was not complied with, just as local government's increase in the previous year had been less than the inflation rate for 1982-83. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table setting out these comparisons since the inception of direct grants to local government in the time of the Whitlam Government.
