TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I do not blame the Minister because one part of the platform was not sustained last year. By and large, local government had been expecting only the 2 per cent of personal income tax and it had planned on that basis. In the debate last May on an amendment to the Local Government (Personal Income Tax) Sharing Act the honourable member for Hughes, Mr Tickner, said at page 2083 of House of Representatives Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Parliament is to be complimented on what I hope is bipartisan support for the concept of a guaranteed level of untied grants to local government. I stress that the commitment to the continuing grant to local government of 2 per cent of personal income tax is a bipartisan commitment.

It appears now that its abolition is a bipartisan commitment. Only the Australian Democrats are standing up for local government. I am sure that the honourable member for Hughes has worked just as hard to try to have this commitment kept and that he is just as dejected as the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services because his colleagues have thrown principle out the window. Let me turn now to last year's general election. The Local Government and Shires Association of New South Wales wrote asking the various parties to put their policies and promises on paper. In a brochure published for the information of councils and the general public we find this contribution from the Minister:
The government is committed to allocating annually at least two per cent of personal income tax receipts to local government as a grant for general purposes.

Later on in the same contribution Mr Uren spoke of the Government being keen to examine both the report released last July by the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations on the responsibilities and resources of Australian local government and the report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, mentioned by Senator Lewis, which is due to be handed down by 30 September this year. The Minister assured us that the Government would be closely examining the findings of these reports. He went on to say:
However, I should stress that no decisions or changes to Commonwealth financial relations with local government will be made until full consultations have been held with all parties concerned.

The government is also responding to the initiatives of local councils to take up additional functions in response to community needs. For example under the Community Employment Program, the new Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the Children Services Program and the Home and Community Care Program.

That is from a written statement made by the Minister. Little wonder then that the Minister is so distressed by what his colleagues have now forced upon him. They have virtually dismembered his undertaking and have stomped on the parts that remained intact.

The Government is keen now to dress up this swindle by claiming that local government is still getting an increase in personal income tax money. When we look at the overall picture we find that, apart from the claimed $52m or $62m shortfall-depending on whether we believe the Minister's estimate or the estimate of the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-local government is also facing cutbacks in the moneys available for arterial roads in the States and the children's services program, and it will face extra costs due to the petrol products freight subsidy being reduced or eliminated. So the situation is somewhat less rosy than what we are being led to believe. Taken in conjunction with the puny increases in untied grants in the past few years-it is useful to bear in mind that a lot of the costs faced by local government rise much faster than does the consumer price index and that more and more functions and duties are being passed on to local government as can be seen in the table I have incorporated-there will be real pressures on many councils not just to forget about expanding employment opportunities in their areas but also to cut jobs.

In this regard I quote from the evidence given to the Self Inquiry into Local Government Finance by Mr Alan Morse, Chairman of the New South Wales Local Government Grants Commission. Mr Morse is a distinguished authority on local government matters. He does not mince words or exaggerate. He is well aware of the effects of the decisions by the New South Wales Government to introduce rate pegging, to shut down the local government assistance fund, to increase fire fighting levies and to make councils pick up half the tab for pensioner rebates on rates. Concerning rate pegging in combination with other policies, at page 813 of the transcript of the Self Inquiry, Mr Morse said:

Now, this is now starting to bite; and I would say that local government in New South Wales would be facing a financial crisis in the year ahead-in the years ahead-and unless something is done that will happen. It will be relieved to some extent in this coming year because, if the Commonwealth's forecasts are correct, and if PIT does return 19.98% . . . above last year, then councils are going to get some short-term relief inasmuch as a greater-sum-than-inflation rate, so that they will get some relief from that.

But had personal income tax collections for 1984-85 produced a figure comparable to the two preceding years, in my view, local government would have been right-in New South Wales-it would have been right on the brink of a financial crisis.

This is what the Commonwealth Government is now proposing. It is proposing to hit New South Wales Local Government with a cut in its percentage of personal income tax. One of the other things it fails to realise is that New South Wales local government uses the calendar year for budgeting purposes. In other words, councils would have already spent between one-third and one-half of their productive funds for the year. In the cases where they have taken the Government at its word, they will have to adjust. That will mean shedding jobs, tightening criteria for access to human care services and postponement of projects that are vitally needed in their communities. The option of increasing council rates to an extent which will ensure that vital community services will be provided is not an option available to councils in New South Wales, because of New South Wales rate pegging. That means hardship will be inflicted on a lot of communities, unemployed people, the aged, single parents and the homeless.

Let us look at some of the specific examples and bear in mind the general impact of the Government's mini-Budget announcements, which include winding down the community employment program, removal of petrol cartage subsidies, reduction of funding for roads and reneging on funds for operating pre-school centres and local aerodromes. We find that the personal income tax sharing money alone will be approximately $1.5m down in the electorate of Hunter and over $1m down in the marginal rural electorates of Calare and Eden-Monaro. Will honourable senators on the Government side be visiting those parts to explain to people whose community employment program jobs have vanished, or who have previously been able to arrange affordable child care while they worked, that they will have to wait until the Australian dollar stops falling and that, even then, the trilogy might not leave room for them to find work or assistance? Is the Government seriously putting forward that a drop in grants entitlements of over $0.5m in the municipalities of Blacktown, Wollongong and Lake Macquarie will not result in growth being stifled, especially where there is a crying need in those areas for community infrastructure expenditure?

The rural shire of Inverell looks like losing about $150,000 of what it quite reasonably expected to have this year. I have had several representations from that Shire Council. It fits into New South Wales Region 2 which covers about 93,000 square kilometres, has a population of 178,000 people and is divided into some 20 councils. Last year Region 2 received just over $12 1/2m in untied grants. It expected to get about $15m this year, if the Government had kept its word. It will be down by $1 1/2m unless we reject the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill. I quote from a letter I received from the Inverell Shire Council on 15 May this year:
Obviously this--
that is, the reneging on the 2 per cent of PIT commitments-

would require the Councils to totally review their current programmes. Such review would possibly result in reduction in employment. Some 104 jobs could be lost if these reviews were carried out on a basis of 65 per cent labour content in the programmes with average wage of $15,000 per annum. This effect would be even more far-reaching if the Councils decided, as a cost-cutting measure, to curtail their involvement in CEP and JOLOR programmes. When employment is already a great problem within our society, this would be a retrograde step.

I will deal specifically with the Shire of Inverell itself. Its share of the cutback will remove about 1 1/2 per cent of its general fund revenue. The Council has budgeted some $75,000 for the CEP and jobs on local roads program this year. Based on a 20 per cent contribution, that represents $375,000 worth of work, direct employment for 16 people, with its spillover effects on the rest of the community. I am sure that the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services was well aware of these problems when he fought so hard to keep the Cabinet and Caucus on the straight and narrow. I share his disappointment.

One of the things that have arisen spontaneously right around the country at the public hearings of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance has been concern about the chaos in the children's services area. Last year there was an injection of Federal funds to encourage local government to establish child care centres. The theory was that local government would find the cash for land and the bricks and mortar and the Commonwealth would take care of the recurring costs. The Government was going to create 20,000 new child care places over three years, a most praiseworthy goal. A very large proportion of the money was going to Victoria where local government bodies take responsibility for the provision of many children's services. An amount of $12.8m was available to Victorian councils in 1983-84 and $18.6m this financial year. Forty-two new child care centres were scheduled for opening this year because councils believed that the Commonwealth would not leave them in the lurch. Now we really do not know what will happen. If the Government persists in its overall approach to local government, I would not be surprised if in years to come the Government's word is not trusted at all. I would not be surprised if the councils showed great reluctance to get involved in the provision of new services that the Commonwealth Government undertakes to finance, especially if councils are left holding the baby, or the child minding centres, with no way in which to fund them.

Stop-go decisions of this nature are undermining councils' willingness to plan for progressive change. Victorian councils, as well as those in rural parts of Queensland, have approached me about the possible loss of jobs in the roadworks sector and about the job opportunities that just will not be there. Funds will not be available to put the local component into the CEP and other schemes. Earlier this month the Municipal Association of Victoria held an emergency meeting on tax sharing arrangements. My colleague Senator Chipp sent a strong message of support, the terms of which are set out in a Press release of 6 May. I seek leave to have this Press release incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DEMOCRAT SUPPORT FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT

Senator Don Chipp today sent a message of support to the Local Government Emergency Meeting on Tax Sharing Arrangements called by the Municipal Association of Victoria at the South Melbourne Town Hall.
Senator Chipp's statement expressed strong support for the retention of Local Government's 2% share of Personal Income Tax.

''There should be no changes to the current revenue sharing arrangements affecting Local Government before the Report of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance is available and Local Government has had an opportunity to analyse it and to respond to its recommendations.
''To enable this to be done, it is clear that the Local Government allocation for the financial year 1985/86 must remain at 2% of Personal Income Tax.

''Secondly, it is the position of the Australian Democrats that the current level of 2% of PIT should be treated as a basic minimum benchmark and that future allocations should take full account of the growing responsibilities of Local Government Authorities.

''The Australian Democrats believe that Local Government will face increasing responsibilities in the areas of economic and social development. In particular, we would expect Local Government to play a much greater role in generating increased local employment opportunities as more jobs disappear under the impact of advancing technology.

''Hence it is important that Local Government is enabled to develop the financial resources to cope with these responsibilities at local level where diverse needs of local communities can be met most efficiently.
''However, in the long term it may well be in Local Government's own best interests to vary the present formula to take account of the foreshadowed move away from PAYE collection.
''The Democrats are monitoring closely the proceedings of Professor Self's Inquiry to ensure that the capacity of Local Government to carry out its important role is not undermined in any way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Following further contact, the Metropolitan Municipal Association again wrote to Senator Chipp last Friday outlining the types of projects that are under threat as a result of the announced cutback in local government's share of personal income tax collections. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.
—Is that the breakaway municipal group?
—It is a group of metropolitan councils, yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
METROPOLITAN MUNICIPAL ASSOCIATION
Private Bag No. 3P.O. St Kilda 3182Tel: (03) 536 1333DX32057 Caulfield
Senator the Hon. Don Chipp,Parliament House,Canberra, 2600
Dear Don,
Federal Government Funding Cuts to Local Government

In response to your request for more concrete examples of services or projects most in jeopardy due to the recently announced reduction in Local Government P.I.T.S. grants, I have contacted a number of metropolitan Councils in an attempt to obtain specific details.

Most Councils are at this stage understandably reluctant to 'go public' on which specific services or projects are most likely to be cut. Almost all however, have said that the 'human services' area is the one most likely to suffer as expansion in this area in recent years has been directly enabled by the Federal Government P.I.T.S. grants.
Most Councils stated that it will be services introduced in recent years which will be the most in jeopardy. Examples would include such things as:

(i) Children's Services generally and in particular child care services. Many Councils have recently begun to expand these services but, in an atmosphere where continuity of Federal funds cannot be relied upon, these Councils will certainly be reassessing their plans.

(ii) Youth Services. This is another area in which Councils are recently beginning to take on an expanded role and, although State grants are available, they represent only a part-contribution towards Youth Worker salaries. The remainder of salary costs and all of the associated programme costs (which tend to escalate once a worker has been employed for a year or two) are all picked up by Local Government. Many Councils are directly dependent upon P.I.T.S. allocations to fund these programmes and will, therefore, be reassessing in the light of the present situation.

(iii) Employment. In a time of such severe unemployment rates, especially among young people, Local Government has accepted more than its share of its responsibility for job creation. Over one third of all C.E.P. funds have been utilised by Local Government, and a great many staff employed on a temporary basis via this scheme have been kept on and given permanent positions by Councils. In attempting to cut costs to keep running important community services, these positions are likely to be amongst the first to go.

(iv) Libraries. This is probably the best example of a service which is grossly under-funded by the State Government and in which Local Government is picking up an ever-increasing share of the costs. Several Councils commented that Library opening hours could be reassessed, given cutbacks to the Federal funds which are presently used to supplement costs.

(v) Other Community Services. Some Councils also indicated that small scale but important community services, such as the home handyman service and expanded community bus services, will also be amongst the first considered for cuts.

(vi) Increased Charges-General. Decreased Federal funds to Local Government will also certainly mean a review of charges for many Local Government services. This will apply in particular to child care and domiciliary services, but also to such things as use of sporting grounds which has in the past been free of charge generally but which Councils will have to consider revising in the light of increasing maintenance costs and decreasing income from the Federal Government. In essence, this just represents another form of tax which Local Government will have to introduce in order to ''subsidise'' the Federal Government's promised tax cuts.

In general, it is clear that the Commonwealth Government has led Local Government into providing a wide range of community services and is now rapidly abandoning any responsibility for ongoing support and assistance. As stated in our submission to Senator Walsh on this issue, Local Government has been expanding its income from rates in recent years far in excess of the rate of inflation. Ratepayers will certainly not tolerate further increases of recent levels, and Local Government has, therefore, been forced into an impossible situation.
In conclusion, may I express on behalf of the Metropolitan Municipal Association my sincere appreciation for your efforts for Local Government. I hope this information is of use.
Yours sincerely,
BRIAN JONES
Secretary Pro Tem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I wish to take just a few more examples to alert honourable senators to the impact of the Government's proposals. The Shire of Flinders writes:

SPEECH.PARA: The low growth in personal income tax collections over the last two years has meant the local government's share of Commonwealth revenue has been close to the rate of inflation-but below the rate of the increase in cost of providing the majority of local government's services. The proposed change comes at a time when local government will have the chance to make up for the last two years by gaining an increase in real terms.

A fixed percentage share of revenue has many advantages for local government in that it can plan ahead. In growth municipalities such as the Shire of Flinders, the Loan Borrowing Programme is based on future capacity to repay and the predicted revenue share from the Commonwealth has been taken into consideration in determining the appropriate level of loans raised annually.

Flinders Shire will have to put off 11 people who have funding under the employment relief pro- jects. It will also have to terminate contributions to aged persons housing and to terminate or reduce council contributions to aged persons welfare services. This will happen by increasing charges for Meals on Wheels, Home Help and so on. It is no wonder that the Shire of Flinders has taken the trouble to put its case to us most forcefully.

The City of Knox, with an annual population increase of 4,000 or 5,000 people, has increased its rate revenue over the past 10 years by an average of 14.1 per cent per annum. No one can deny that it is maintaining its rate effort properly. It says that a significant reduction in personal income tax funds would require an immediate rate increase of 12 to 13 per cent to maintain current standards. Alternatively, it would have to forgo money to the tune of $180,000-roughly the cost of a new oval, club rooms, a pre-school, an infant welfare centre or a senior citizens club. What is the sense of foisting more social problems on to such an expanding community?

The Shire of Ballan, which is one hour's drive out of Melbourne, has for many years grown at over twice the average annual State growth rate. Demands placed on it for additional welfare services and for improved road maintenance and street infrastructure are increasing all the time. This is what the Council says about the announced cutbacks:
Council has urgent needs in the expansion of the Meals On Wheels, Home Help and Day Care services. These will not be expanded now, but will be held at current levels.
Likewise, road maintenance and construction programmes will be curtailed and will suffer in real terms.
This will impact in the future upon road safety and the standard of the environment.
Later, in the same letter, it adds:

Council also objects most strongly to the ad hoc manner in which this reduction was made, coming at a time when the Federal Government Inquiry into Local Government Finance has not yet made any report.

These examples can be and have been multiplied many times from all States. I wish to consider briefly my home State of South Australia, where the Secretary of the Local Government Association, Mr Jim Hullick, warned last April that rates would have to go up astronomically if councils picked up the tab for the services for which Federal government money was expected. In this financial year, South Australia was entitled to nearly $42m. Therefore, the cutback will mean a loss of $5m in what councils were expecting. For instance, the Riverland region, which is having difficulties with the dairying, viticulture and dried fruit industries because of overseas dumping and increased salinity in the area, stands to have $200,000 knocked off its entitlements. The growth areas to the north and south of Adelaide look like being half a million dollars behind what they might reasonably have expected. The City of Henley and Grange has mentioned the awesome choices of retrenching staff, of contemplating massive rate increases or of abandoning-not pruning-community services.

The point will have got through to honourable senators by now that there will be very serious hurt and dislocation if the iniquitous proposals embodied in this Bill are hustled through. The question remains: What has local government done to deserve its punishment at a time when the Federal Government is happy to walk away with its own vastly increased share of taxation revenue? The total expenditure cuts announced on 14 May will prune only 2 per cent of the Federal Government's total outlays. They will take about 10 per cent of local government's untied grants and, all things considered, a substantial part of the tied grants. So the axe is falling disproportionately heavily on local government.

The examples that I have cited give the lie to assertions that local government rating effort has not kept pace with land values or with the capacity of the community to pay. During the adjournment debate on 27 March, Senator Peter Rae produced a table that showed that local government was maintaining its taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product. Senator Walsh undertook to have these figures examined and to make the analysis available to Senator Rae. A similar response was forthcoming the next day when I asked a question without notice dealing with a quite different local government financial issue. I am still waiting for a reply, despite a further letter and telephone messages which indicated how keen I was to get the information. I have also not had answers to my specific questions.

I can thus present no material that is gentle to the Government's case. When we look at public sector outlays, net of inter-government transfer, we find that the Commonwealth was responsible for 51 per cent of the growth between 1978-79 and 1982-83. The States were responsible for 44 per cent and local government for only 5 per cent. Of the $4.7 billion increase in public sector deficits over the same period, local government was responsible for 3 per cent, the States for 64 per cent and the Commonwealth for 33 per cent. So the major problems in the economy cannot be sheeted home to local government. It is recognised as the most efficient dispenser of services.

Lip-service is paid to the importance of encouraging local government to plan and to play a role as a partner in Australia's development. Yet we still find the rug being pulled out from under its feet without rational explanation by both major parties in this Parliament. Even with a $50m or $60m saving the deficit will not be markedly reduced. Job opportunities and taxation revenue will be foregone. The trust built up over the years since the early Whitlam initiatives to give local government proper funding will be shattered. Councils will be forced to borrow more heavily if they decide to maintain services. They will be competing with the private sector, which the Government claims is already crowded out of the money markets.

The irony is that the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance is in progress. That inquiry has probably consulted more people and groups than any other inquiry, except the Royal Commission on Human Relationships. It has travelled around the country, held many public hearings and conducted many informal meetings. The incisiveness of its members' questions makes its recommendations, due by the end of September, well worth waiting for. There should not be any rush to pre-empt its findings.

There is still time for the Government to recognise its blunder, to apologise to local government for undermining over 10 years of work and to withdraw this quite unacceptable legislation. There is not one shred of justification for imposing the hardship on the unemployed, on those without community services and on the communities in need of funds for upgrading facilities.

Equalisation, in fact, determines what most councils will receive, even though there is a notional per capita component in calculations. A reduction in untied funds will therefore hit hardest those sectors of the community in greatest need. The Labor Party, at various stages in its history, would not have contemplated the folly of dealing most harshly with its closest supporters. It is sad that it is prepared to do so now. I am also aware that the 2 per cent real increase on funds for last year, which the Government proposes, is easily confused with the 2 per cent of personal income tax that local government was promised and should be given. We are not fooled and nor is local government.

I call upon the Senate to stand up for this country and for honesty. As Democrats, we will be voting against this Bill. In the meantime, as we understand that the Opposition will be voting with the Government, we will support the words of censure which it is proposed to add at the end of the motion for the second reading. However, I invite all honourable senators to do the decent, Australian thing and reject the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At present we are debating the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1985. My colleague the shadow Minister, who is in charge of the Bill from the Opposition point of view, foreshadowed an amendment. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ', but the Senate is of the opinion that this legislation represents a further breach of the Government's election commitments.'.

I have just listened to a speech by Senator Vigor which is typical of the Australian Democrats. They parade themselves as being the protectors of any section of the community from which they are likely to get votes. The only problem with the Democrats is that although they denigrate the Opposition-on this occasion both the Government and the Opposition-they fail to recognise that the people of Australia unfortunately elected the Australian Labor Party to govern this country for the next three years. It is the responsibility of the Government to raise revenue as it sees fit. It is not the job of the Opposition or the Democrats to do that. They will never have the responsibility to govern this country. The Democrats parade themselves and suggest that we are not offended by this measure at all. We are. The coalition parties of this Federal Parliament have stuck up for local government over the years. We have a government which is committed to the Federal system whereby the government in Canberra keeps State and local governments in their proper places. We believe firmly in the Federal system.

We heard Senator Vigor extolling the virtues of Mr Uren. During the time of the Whitlam Government Mr Uren was Minister for Urban and Regional Development. He was dedicated to the destruction of local government by establishing some 40 regional councils throughout Australia with the ultimate objective of abolishing the State governments altogether. That was quite clear and ought to have been abundantly clear to Senator Vigor. However, the leopard has changed his spots and now purports to be the champion of local government. I support his feeble attempt to try to influence the Caucus of the Australian Labor Party. Unfortunately, he was unable to meet the strength of his Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who warned Mr Uren to toe the line, or else. A report in the Australian states:
Mr Hawke told Mr Uren a fortnight ago that he was 'finished' if he went to the Labor Caucus in a bid to over-turn a Cabinet decision on funding cuts for local government.
The threat from Hawke reveals a tougher attitude towards his ministers and his determination to ensure ministers do not use Caucus as 'a court of appeal' when they are defeated in Cabinet.

It looks as though the left wing was very weak in its defence of Mr Uren. If Mr Uren had his way, perhaps we all would have been happy about the measure we are dealing with today. I was interested to read the speech at the second reading stage made by the Opposition's spokesman on local government, Mr Everingham, in the House of Representatives on 21 May, in which he said:

There are disputes as to whether the Whitlam Government or the Fraser Government first introduced the original revenue funding scheme whereby 1.52 per cent of revenue from personal income tax would be distributed to local government.

I put on record that it was the Fraser Government which recognised the significance of local government. When my late colleague Sir Phillip Lynch introduced the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Bill 1976 in the House of Representatives on 16 October 1976 he made the following point:

. . . the tax sharing arrangements to apply between the Commonwealth, the States and local government were decided following extensive discussions between the Commonwealth and the States this year, and represent a central element in the Government's federalism policies . . . The inclusion of local government in the new tax sharing scheme accords it the status of a genuine partner in our federal system. This Bill recognises and foreshadows a new deal for local government.

As we all know, there was a progressive increase in the amount of money available to local government until it reached the extent of 2 per cent of personal income tax revenue. I was very pleased about that because, as a member of the local council in Port Augusta in about 1959-a year or two ago now-and as representative of the Eyre Peninsula Local Government Association I moved a motion that a royal commission ought to be carried out into the method of financing local government in South Australia with the object of getting a share of the personal income tax revenue. That motion was carried. It takes an inordinate amount of time for these things to grind through bureaucratic and party political processes. Eventually, in 1976, it was achieved by the Fraser Government.

I was appalled and wrote to the Minister concerned, Mr Uren, suggesting that it was premature to take any action with respect to local government financing until the report of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance was provided. That report is not due until September this year. This is another example of where the Labor Government has failed to honour its commitments. I quote from a paper I have dated 15 May:

A year ago the Prime Minister announced the establishment of a National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. Its terms of reference were to review the Local Government tax sharing arrangements and report on any changes required to improve the operation of the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976. The Inquiry's brief included consideration of the level and form of funding for Local Government from Commonwealth sources. The inquiry is due to report in September.

It is disgraceful and irresponsible for the Government to take any action such as we are dealing with now without the benefit of having that report. As far as I am concerned, the Labor Party's stand is a matter of regret and disgrace. We have to recognise that since the personal income tax sharing arrangement was made, local government has budgeted for a certain amount of money and been guaranteed that money-until now. Now the spirit of the legislation introduced by my late colleague in 1976 has been destroyed, so much so that it is contemplated that local government will be deprived of something of the order of $52m in the full year from 1 July. Recognising that local government had a bigger share of the cake, some State governments intruded and in some instances siphoned off road funds or introduced levies on local government to the detriment of that tier of government in our federal system.

The Labor Government has failed to recognise that fact, which makes it even more culpable in introducing this measure now, and not waiting until September, when it would have the benefit of a proper report with respect to local government financing and the recommendations that may flow from it. I would like to think that the present Government is conscious of the importance of local government, to the extent that it will take notice of the Self committee report and recommendations.

When we are dealing with public sector expenditure restraint, it is interesting to note that some people criticise local government. All I say is that if local government makes an equal contribution to the blowout in public sector expenditure it should simply share in the restraint. From a perusal of the financial estimates of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian Council of Local Government Associations understands that between 1978-79 and 1982-83 public sector outlays net of inter-government transfers increased by $30 billion. The Commonwealth was responsible for 51 per cent of that growth, the States 44 per cent and local government 5 per cent. In terms of the $4.7 billion increase in public sector deficits over the same period, local government was responsible for 3 per cent of that growth, the States 64 per cent and the Commonwealth 33 per cent.

From an historical point of view, the 19.9 per cent growth in local government tax sharing entitlement is seen as a catch-up on particularly the last two years. That is what it could have anticipated if the Government had recognised the value of local government and had recognised the problems it has to deal with. Senator Lewis said, and I think it was repeated by Senator Vigor, that local government will now be faced with the problem of either increasing its rates and becoming a de facto tax collector for the ALP-the ALP shedding that responsibility and placing it upon local government authorities throughout Australia-or being forced to withdraw or reduce services in the communities it serves, which of course could mean unemployment in the local government sector.

I recognise that some local government authorities may be less efficient than others. I recognise that over the years local government authorities have amalgamated in order to increase their efficiency and to increase their purchasing power, thereby increasing their service to the ratepayers they serve. However, the majority of local government authorities in Australia are efficient and I think act responsibly. We have given them added responsibilities for involvement in nursing homes and the like. For example, a complex was built at Port Augusta in co-operation with the South Australian Housing Trust, which built the residential section. The local government authority contributed to the administration block. Participation of local service organisations was also encouraged. I think that is a good thing, and it is the way we ought to go.

Local government happens to be the government closest to the people. It is not a remote government like the government in Canberra. I think it is a great pity that we, as champions of local government, are forced to accept the negligence of the Australian Labor Party. We have to accept the fact that the Labor Party does not value local government in a proper way. All I can say is that when a Liberal-National Party government is returned in two and a half years I will be one who will urge that government to reintroduce the 2 per cent personal income tax share as economic circumstances permit. When we take over in government we will be faced with massive problems. We will have to take some very unpleasant decisions early in the piece. As far as I am concerned, and I am sure this view would be held by a majority of my colleagues, when we are back in government we will see that local government returns to its rightful place in the federal system and is provided with the funds that, unhappily, have been taken away from it by the socialist ALP Government, which really has as its objective the ultimate destruction of local government, the destruction of the States, and the putting in place in Canberra of an all-powerful, dominant, dictatorial, centralistic type of government, which I would totally oppose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Amendment Bill 1985, which gives effect to the announcement earlier this month by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that local government will not receive 2 per cent of personal income tax collections for the coming financial year. The present tax sharing arrangements provide that in any given year local government will receive revenue amounting to 2 per cent of the previous year's personal income tax collections. Under the new arrangements the local government share of revenue in 1985-86, rather than being 2 per cent of the 1984-85 personal income tax collections, in fact will be 2 per cent of the 1983-84 personal income tax collections, plus an increase in real terms of 2 per cent. When the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Bill was introduced in 1976 with the purpose of providing for the sharing of personal income tax collections between the Commonwealth and local government, the benefits of the arrangements were clearly described by the late Sir Phillip Lynch, the then Treasurer, who said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The level of general purpose assistance provided to local government in any year will be known with certainty very early in that year. Very importantly, the amount of such assistance will grow as personal income tax collections grow.

And so they did grow. They grew from 1.5 per cent until ultimately under the Fraser Government they reached 2 per cent. The coalition Government thus clearly recognised the expanding role of local government and was prepared to provide a clear and constant means of support. The Labor Government also has made much of the importance of local government. In a speech to the Institute of Municipal Management in May last year Mr Hawke stated:

Local government is at once a significant employer, provider of facilities, services and infrastructure, and consumer of goods and services. Our local government network is a significant element of the social fabric of our nation, and serves as a major catalyst in developing community resources and capacity.
Mr Hawke went on to tell his audience:
The Federal Government will be working for a durable strengthening of local government capacity.

Now, only one year later, Labor is completely undermining one of local government's most important and reliable sources of income. As I have already pointed out, one of the benefits of the personal income tax sharing arrangements was that it gave local authorities plenty of advance notice of future levels of assistance and thereby facilitated forward budgeting. By the measure that is before us at present, local government authority budgets for 1985-86 will be thrown into complete chaos and even more so, because, far from being foreshadowed, the change in funding arrangements has arrived completely out of the blue, without notice, without signal and without any indication. It is completely contrary to the commitments that Labor has made with regard to local government.

Immediately prior the election the present Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Mr Uren, spoke about the many initiatives the Government had taken in recognition of the important role local government does, and can, play in the Australian economy, including significant increases in funding for local government. Even as recently as March this year the Minister was talking about continuing 'our work which hinges on the Government's commitment to strengthening the capacity and raising the status of local government'. It might also be expected that one could find some indication of Labor's intentions in the ALP platform. Luckily this is becoming less likely these days and it is certainly not the case in regard to this issue because, according to the ALP 1984 platform, a Federal Labor Government would:
Provide financial assistance for local government including . . . an annual allocation of at least 2 per cent of Federal personal income tax receipts as a general revenue grant to local government.

The precipitant for this legislation is the increase in revenue that would have accrued to local government through the increase in personal income tax receipts for 1984-85. Under the current arrangements the allocation to local government would represent an increase of around 15 per cent in real terms. The increase in personal income tax receipts for 1984-85 would have caused local government's share to have risen by around 15 per cent. That was just too much for this avaricious Labor Government. Suddenly the rules had to be changed. It could see revenue going to local government, which properly needed and deserved it. It has suddenly, in mid-stream, in mid-flight, changed the rules.

What really concerns me in this legislation is that the Government has shown itself willing to break the 2 per cent tax sharing agreement because it was a good year for local government. The precedent it sets removes all future certainty for local government funding while we have a Labor Government. Furthermore, it was clearly the purpose and the intention of the 1976 Act that assistance to local government in this form should increase in line with increases in personal income tax receipts. I am not suggesting for a moment that the 2 per cent formula is immutable, that it is set in concrete, that it cannot be subject to some sort of revision or review or that another formula cannot be provided. Whatever the formula, it ought to be one of growth and one of certainty.

I am reminded that on 25 March 1985, in reply to a question on this matter, the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, implied that local government authorities could raise any shortfall in revenue through rate increases; he was taking what was rightfully theirs and they ought to make it up through some form of rate increase. As my colleague Senator Jessop said earlier, this would make local government simply an agent for revenue collection for the Federal Government. Senator Walsh was presumptuous enough to say:
Local government authorities have not increased their revenue raising effort in the last decade or so in spite of rising property values.

I love theorists because it really gives one a fair understanding of how the socialists think and what their mentality is. Senator Walsh has said that because property values have gone up rates automatically ought to go up, implying that because property values have gone up, the capacity of the owners to pay has gone up. What absurd logic! I think this sort of statement gives a misleading picture of the situation and casts local governments in an improper and poor light. Certainly rates have kept pace with increases in the consumer price index and, as a proportion of household income-which is a fairer, better and more responsible measure-have remained constant in the last 10 years, from 1.33 per cent in 1973-74 to 1.38 per cent in 1981-82. I believe that that measure provides a truer indication of people's ability to pay higher rates rather than using nominal increases in property values suggested by Senator Walsh. Certainly as far as local governments go, I would argue that practical rating capacity is not increasing; it is declining. The vast majority of major ratepayers, particularly in rural areas, are farmers. Many have been in precarious financial positions which have been inflicted on them after years of increasing costs and declining returns and they would be simply unable to sustain any further increases in rates.

One has to look only at the rural sector, which the Labor Party if it is not ignoring it seems to be tearing away further revenue from it, and the parlous state of that economy to understand the rural sector's lack of capacity to pay increased rates. As a result of this legislation, in 1985-86 local government will receive an estimated $52m less than it would had the current arrangements remained. Thus, it will be much less able to meet community requirements. When I say that local government will receive an estimated $52m less, it depends on whether one listens to the Minister, the Government or the Commonwealth Statistician. The figures vary between $52m, $56m and $62m. Whatever the figure, it is a very significant reduction in revenue to local government.

Because of the untied nature of revenue grants, different local authorities use the money in different ways-for example, to top up short falls in revenue for road building, for developmental projects or, perhaps, for community services. Each State has a responsibility to allocate a minimum of 30 per cent of the personal income tax sharing grant among its local authorities on a population basis. The remaining assistance is allocated according to the financial position of the respective authorities. Obviously, it is those local authorities which are least able to rely on alternative sources of revenue which are most dependent on the personal income tax grant and which, of course, will suffer most from any cut.

Local government authorities must now be left wondering about the purpose of the much vaunted inquiry into local government finance and, in particular, Mr Tom Uren's promise that the recommendations of the inquiry 'will be fully discussed with the States and local government before any amendments to the Act are considered'. Just recently the Minister made that promise. What do we find? The legislation has been changed; the formula has been changed; an ad hoc basis has been introduced; and local government finds itself $56m short, without any notice being given, without consultation, without discussion and without the recommendations of the inquiry being brought down. The inquiry was specifically established to review local government tax sharing arrangements and report on whether changes to the present system were necessary. The Government has now completely pre-empted the outcome of this inquiry and by its actions shaken the faith of local government and shown it what its real intentions are.

It comes as no surprise to us on this side of the chamber to see what is being done to local government. I would be surprised if local government is in a state of shock. One only has to recall the Whitlam days, as my colleague Senator Jessop said. It was the intention of Whitlam, and now is the intention of Hawke and the ALP, to abolish States. For practical purposes under the present construction local governments would be abolished and local regional governments set up, thus bypassing both local government and State government. Of course the funds that were to be provided to those regional governments were to be by way of tied grants so that there would be a centralised system in Canberra with no authority, no power and no distribution of decision making outside Canberra. Therefore, it should come as no shock to local government to find now that the formula, the base of revenue, the understanding and the legislation on which it had come to rely in the past has, at the stroke of a pen, been taken away from it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not repeat the arguments that a number of my colleagues have already put forward in relation to this shocking example of the Government's blatant dishonesty. It has gone to an election with a policy promise that was made clearly and unequivocally and now it has blandly breached that without even a beg pardon. I remind honourable senators that this is the highest taxing, biggest spending government in the history of Australia, yet it is quite prepared to plunder the public purse by taking large amounts of personal income tax without giving any sort of cut, deferring the day from which it intends to make the cuts until after it has had a tax summit and after it has had some other sort of inquiry, nevertheless pocketing the proceeds in the meantime. Talk about plundering the public purse! The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, talks about plundering the public purse, but could there be a worse example of doing just that than this situation before us now?

SPEECH.PARA: We recognise the need to curtail public expenditure. We recognise that the public debt is rising rapidly in this country, that the first $35 a week paid in tax by the average taxpayer in this country goes simply towards servicing the public debt, which is rapidly rising. Of course it is necessary to have a curtailment of Government expenditure. As I asked in a recent debate in this chamber, what is this Government doing by way of giving a lead? It is doing nothing at all. It is increasing its own administrative expenses by anything between 15 per cent and 30 per cent on average across the board, through the departments. It is not cutting back in the area in which it could give a lead; it is imposing the cuts on war widows and local government. It is saying: 'It is necessary to curtail expenditure and you and you and you out there will be the ones whose expenditure will be curtailed; not the Government's'.

There was the clearest possible policy commitment on the part of this Government to maintain the allocation of 2 per cent of personal income tax. It was an election promise that the Government would maintain that, but without a beg pardon it has simply reneged on the promise. There has been no cut in the personal income tax rate, which is accepted as being unduly high in this country. Without waiting for its tax summit, without waiting for any change in the personal income tax rate and without waiting for the report, due in September, of the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, the Government is destroying the budgetary processes of local government. I believe that local government in Australia had every reason to budget upon the basis of anticipating that any changes to the policy of the Government that had been elected would be negotiated and discussed and that changes would not be imposed without fair warning or prior notice. Yet that is what has happened. The changes have been imposed without prior notice part of the way through the financial year. Local government had every right to budget on the basis of the expectation of the receipt of that share which the Government had promised it.

What is clear from the hundreds of letters which I have from municipalities all over Australia, from local government associations as well as individual councils-I do not pause to read them but simply to indicate that I have a bundle which takes a very thick file to hold it-is the outrage, the shock and the horror that was felt by them when they found out what this Government intends to do to them. We believe they were entitled to budget on the basis on which they did. We believe they will probably now be forced to increase rates or, alternatively, to curtail expenditure. They will be forced to cut programs which they would otherwise have undertaken. In some cases, they will be forced to increase rates. If they increase rates, that will impose an inflationary pressure which will add to the cost of production of all the businesses which pay rates. It will impose an inflationary pressure in the community. If they curtail expenditure that will almost certainly increase the likelihood of unemployment growing at an even higher rate than it is at the moment.

This legislation has destroyed the confidence which people may have had in this Government as a government of any form of probity or honesty, a government which was likely to keep its promises. I again emphasise that, whilst it is the highest taxing, biggest spending government in history, we believe it is necessary for there to be a major program of curtailment of expenditure. But it ought to be negotiated, it ought to be discussed, it ought to be across the board and it ought to include the Government's own expenditure, particularly in relation to its own administration. The Government has failed to await the outcome of the National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, it has failed to expedite that inquiry-if it is urgent that something be done-it has failed to honour the agreement which it made prior to the last election, it has failed to honour its policy promises and it has failed to negotiate to the benefit of taxpayers any arrangement whereby tax savings could be passed on by way of some form of rate remission, which would have been another alternative for the Government if it felt it was necessary for all of us to tighten our belts a little at this time to reduce the rapidly increasing rate of public debt and to get the Budget a little closer to balance. That could have been passed on as a form of encouragement to taxpayers. The Government has said that the amount of personal income tax collected is so high that it would increase by nearly 20 per cent the amount going to local government, and that that is an unreasonable increase. It has then said: 'But we will not pay it back. We will pocket that unreasonable percentage'. That is the part that gets me. That is the part that is most unreasonable in what this Government is doing.

I would sum the legislation up in this way: Firstly, I believe it is a measure of the Government's preparedness to plunder the public purse; secondly, it is an indication of the Government's preparedness to pocket the plunder when it has plundered the public purse; thirdly, it is an indication of this Government's selfishness and complete lack of fairness towards local government; fourthly, it is an indication of this Government's indifference to the plight of property owners who already pay hefty rates and taxes; fifthly, it is a measure of this Government's lack of interest in those who have to rent property and to whom any increase in rates will be passed on. This legislation is a measure of this Government's dishonesty and disinterest. It is a measure of the extent to which this Government has, I believe, disqualified itself from being entitled to remain in government. It is just one more broken promise and one more example of what can be done by a government which has neither the capacity to govern nor the decency to honour the promises it has made.

I wish that we were in the position which the Australian Democrats invite us to be in of being ambivalent and able to switch back and forth on what we have undertaken to do. We are not prepared to do that. The Democrats may be prepared to say on the one hand that they will not support the rejection of a Budget or Supply Bill, and all sign commitments saying they will not do it, and then when it suits them turn around and do it and invite us to do it. We are not like that. We are going to honour the promise we made, that whilst the Government is the Government it is entitled to have its Budget Bills passed, even though we are entitled to criticise them and point out the dishonesty with which the Government is approaching its job of governing the country.

It is with great regret that I can do no more than say that I shall warmly support the amendment. We condemn this Government's breach of policy promises and its attitude of indifference to local government. We look forward to the day when we are back in government and able to negotiate some reasonable basis upon which local government can operate in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised by honourable senators in this debate. In response on behalf of the Government I shall make a few points to put the whole matter back into some sort of perspective. The decision to change the arrangements for tax sharing with local government was necessary for the Government to make, given the need for restraint. It is worth pointing out that under the present arrangements for tax sharing with local government, grants to local government in 1985-86 would have increased by nearly 20 per cent or some $97m. The Government considered that, in the current circumstances, this increase was excessive.
—So you pocketed it for yourself.

—The Government has decided that local government authorities should share in the expenditure restraint. Senator Rae is interjecting but it seems to me to be an entirely fair principle that at a time of restraint all agencies should share in that restraint. The Government decided that local government authorities should share in the expenditure restraint in order to lay the foundation for continuing economic growth. Of course, local government, like any other authority in this country, will benefit from the continuation of the economic growth that has been achieved by the Hawke Government over the last two years. At present it is estimated that local government will receive an increase of $45m as compared with what they received in 1984-85. This increase, although it is below that which would have occurred had the Act not been amended, is still very substantial. In fact, it is the largest increase since 1982-83. I think that point needs to be emphasised, given some of the exaggerated claims that have been made by Opposition senators during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable senators have expressed concern about the current National Inquiry into Local Government Finance. It is important to point out that the amending Bill changes the grant arrangements for 1985-86 only. The arrangements to apply in subsequent years will be decided after the Government considers the report of the inquiry. This report is expected by the end of September this year. Before the Government finalises its decision on that report it will be fully consulting State and local government authorities. Contrary to some of the suggestions made during the debate, the inquiry's report will be fully considered. It will certainly not be wasted.

In conclusion, I emphasise that the Government's commitment to local government remains firm. The changes made by this legislation reflect the priority the Government attaches to restraining economic growth. The changes do not indicate a weakening of our Government's intention to assist local government to raise its status and strengthen its capacity. The Government has already made considerable progress in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish! Absolute rubbish. You are ignoring the facts.

—If honourable senators choose to ignore the facts, I suppose they can continue with this ignorant chain of interjections. But the fact of the matter is that we have increased by 50 per cent the total of tied and untied assistance to local government since 1982-83. That extent of increase means that there is now a contribution of about $1 billion to local government this year. Clearly, the commitment by the Commonwealth is still a very large one. The increases are still very large and local government still will be able to sustain an increased level of activity as a result, as well as benefiting from the general growth in the economy, which is the Government's main priority in terms of economic management. As well as these specific increases in revenue for local government, the Government will be continuing with other programs and policies designed to achieve the objectives of increased status and strengthened capacity for local government. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence (Re-establishment) Amendment Bill is a rather petty piece of legislation. It is part of the Government's mini-Budget and for that reason the Opposition will not oppose it, although we have circulated an amendment. I therefore move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ', but the Senate condemns the further erosion in terms of service for servicemen and women that the Bill represents, and calls on the Government to act urgently to restore equity in those conditions of service and adequately reward servicemen and women for the service they render to Australia.'.

The position is that for some time now there has been in existence a scheme, which will be removed by this legislation, under which some assistance is given to service men and women on their resignation or retirement. The scheme is known as the defence re-establishment loans scheme and was introduced in 1965 to provide loans for business purposes at a low rate of interest, repayable over a period of some years. The present amounts of the loans are $5,000 for ordinary business purposes, and $10,000 for assistance to those ex-service personnel who wish to go into some agricultural business. Last year 200 applications were made under the legislation. Although the sums of money are small and have not been increased for a number of years, nevertheless they are seen to be of value to the service community. The numbers of servicemen who have benefited from the scheme are considerable, even though the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has played down the figures.

This legislation represents a further erosion of the terms of service of men and women in the Services. This has become a distinct pattern of legislation and decisions by the Hawke Labor Government which, by a series of measures, has eroded the terms and conditions of service men and women resulting in a clear lowering of morale among service personnel. Not only is this a serious matter for those who are serving but, because of the discouragement it has given to those who are serving and those who might serve in our forces, clearly it is a matter of major concern to Australia, and it should be to this Government, although it shows no indication of understanding the problem.

The Senate will recall the iniquitous legislation in 1983 to impose taxation on lump sum superannuation payments and its considerable impact on service personnel. They rely on taking their Defence Force retirement and death benefits in a lump sum for the purpose of getting into a business. Such personnel retire at a comparatively early age and seek to make another career for themselves. That was a very severe blow to their conditions of service. Despite some minor amendments that were made by the Government to meet the concerns of ex-servicemen it is quite clear that they did not ameliorate that iniquitous tax. The service community is suffering very much as a result of that move by this Government.

On top of that, of course, we recall that the Government removed the income tax exemption on Reserve pay that had been enjoyed. That has had a devastating effect on the numbers of reservists and people prepared to volunteer for the reserves. The state that has been reached was highlighted at an Estimates committee meeting a few weeks ago in this Senate where it was indicated that the number of Army Reserve personnel has dramatically fallen-I think by some 10,000. A very serious situation has now arisen which at last this Government has been prepared to admit and to recognise. It now proposes to embark upon a major recruiting campaign for the reserves, but it will not succeed with that campaign while it continues to maintain policies which clearly indicate a lack of understanding of the needs of service men and women and which also indicate that the Government is simply not sympathetic in any way to them.

We have in this piece of legislation a further indication of the Government's thinking about the service men and women of this country, its very negative approach to them and its lack of understanding of and sympathy for them. Even though this is a small and, one might say, only a pin-pricking matter, it is eloquent of the Government's attitude about which I have been speaking and, as our amendment suggests, it is a further erosion of the terms of service of service men and women.

As I have said, the Opposition will not oppose this measure because we believe that the mini-Budget which was introduced by the Government a couple of weeks ago should come into force. We do not believe that it is appropriate for the Opposition to remake the Government's Budgets for it, whether it be the main Budget or the mini-Budget, or however one likes to describe them. The Government has to take the responsibility for its economic policy and it has to make its own priorities. In this mini-Budget it has chosen to make a number of cuts that it believes should be made. Those are the Government's priorities and we agree with the thrust of that cost-cutting exercise although, of course, we do not think that it is anything very unusual; it is the sort of thing that happens every year.

We believe that the Government is acting responsibly in taking that step and we have supported it. That does not mean to say that the Government's choices necessarily would be our choices. Nevertheless, the Government should be taking the responsibility for each of its decisions and we in the Opposition will not tinker around with this measure and make any changes of our own. We will not oppose this measure but, as I have said, we think the Government's choice is a petty thing and is an indication of the Government's lack of understanding of and adequate support for the service men and women of this country. It is for that reason that the Opposition has moved an amendment to the second reading motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are debating the Defence (Re-Establishment) Amendment Bill which, as the second reading speech of the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) makes clear, is to abolish the entire defence re-establishment loans system. It is to apply from the date of the mini-Budget statement and means that those people who had intended to make application for these loans will be unable now to do so. The amounts of money, as the Government and Opposition have made clear, are small in today's terms; $5,000 for a business or $10,000 for an agricultural based business. They are indeed small amounts when one looks at the cost of business establishment today. I read a section from the Minister's second reading speech. It is here that one finds the non sequitur in this particular argument. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Re-establishment loan, at $10,000 for agricultural ventures and $5,000 for business ventures, is simply a cheap alternative source of a small part of the finance required to re-establish a serviceman or woman in civilian life.

That is true. It is a cheap alternative source of a small part of the finance required, but it is still part of the finance which is required. To that extent, there have been, as is evidenced in the Minister's second reading speech, 200 such loans made each year. So there are 200 veterans each year who have sought this particular loan support in order to go into business and re-establish themselves in civilian life. I believe it cannot then follow that, simply because it is only a small support, it ought to be abolished. If that particular reasoning were followed, we would have the abolition of payments for children in families and the abolition of a whole range of support schemes that are provided by government to assist, at least in some small way, what are considered to be worthwhile causes. I do not think it follows that because such a loan is small and it is only part of what a person must put together to re-establish himself or herself in civilian life, it is of no use. Fairly obviously, it is of some use, otherwise there would not have been, as the Minister said in his second reading speech, 'about 200 loans approved each year'.

The loan actually provides, for some reason that I have been unable to discover, that the first $100 is interest free, which seems to me to be a rather odd provision. The interest charged on the rest of the loan is 4 1/2 per cent reducible. That 4 1/2 per cent, as against the available interest rates at the moment, represents a considerable saving. Certainly, if a person got $10,000 for an agricultural venture, that would be of assistance in making repayments in the initial stages. I would have thought that is what one would be seeking to do.

I do not dissent from the view that there could be better ways to spend this money for veterans, if that were the intent of the Government. However, it is not the intent of the Government to redirect this money to veterans in other ways. Therefore, I believe, one has to see it in the light of what the Government has proposed in the Minister's second reading speech; that it is a removal of entitlements from veterans so that their total entitlements are thereby reduced. It is, looked at in that way, a mean spirited piece of legislation. It is nowhere near as draconian as the exercise that the Senate went through last night, but it is a piece of legislation that is part of that general package of cutbacks in veterans' entitlements in a whole range of areas that were so evidently a part of the cuts which were made in the mini-Budget.

The Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion, that 'the Senate condemns the further erosion in terms of service for servicemen and women that the Bill represents, and calls on the Government to act urgently to restore equity in those conditions of service and adequately reward servicemen and women for the service they render to Australia', I believe, represents a view that ought to be supported by the majority in this place. However, I do not think that it goes far enough. I think that in each of these areas we ought to have had a more adequate explanation as to what the Government was about in terms of these various pieces of legislation. As was made clear in the debate that we had yesterday, we also ought to have had consultation with the various ex-service bodies. That consultation had been promised by the Government. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) promised that those discussions would take place where there was any contemplation of changing the entitlements of veterans. The Minister has made a very clear and unequivocal statement that he would discuss those changes prior to their tabling in this place.

It is a pity that that promise of the Government has not been kept in this instance. It seems to me that it was a reasonable promise. It was a promise which would have enabled reasonable discussions to take place. I think that if the Minister were here he would be able to say that the ex-service organisations have acted in a reasonable way in their discussions with the Government over the past couple of years, as they have with previous governments. As a group they have particular interests. I see nothing wrong, in a democracy, in certain groups banding together to promote the interests of their fellows who have particular concerns. That seems to me to be, in fact, essential to the operation of this democracy since it is the very basis upon which political parties are formed to represent certain groups and certain propositions. When those various groups are consulted by government it is often discovered that the proposals they bring forward are extremely sensible ones, ones that can assist in the operation of government. They are not always ones, as is sometimes represented in debates in this place, which are self-serving.

With regard to the cost of the loans, I think this is one area where considerable support could have been given to the Government as to how it could reorganise the defence re-establishment loan area to lower the administrative costs. I ask the Minister-I presume the information must be available because it is in the second reading speech-about the cost of administering loans, particularly in the financial year ending 30 June 1984. In the second reading speech the Minister alluded to the fact that it actually approached 20 per cent of the value of the loans issued during that year. I would be interested in the money figure in that regard and the amounts which were paid out during the financial year running up to 30 June 1984. I think that what we are seeing here is not so much a problem with the defence re-establishment loans scheme but possibly a problem with the way in which that loans scheme has been administered.

I find it odd that one of the reasons given for terminating the scheme is the inefficiency of the bureaucracy to deal with it and to expedite it so that costs were not as high as is stated-that is, 20 per cent of the value of the loans unless the loans during that year were very small. I suggest to the Senate that there are institutions in our society which make profits out of lending money-it does not have to be an exercise in losing money-so, some simple mechanisms may very well have been found had the Government had the time and the inclination to discuss these with the ex-service community. Time could have been made available to look at ways of restructuring this process so that those sorts of costs were not involved.

For example, one way could have been to use the method the Government is suggesting for the defence service homes, whereby it proposes to sell the operation to private enterprise. A way may have been found to remove from the Department the administrative cost burden. With some lateral thinking, an alternative may have been found other than the alternative which the Government has chosen, which is simply to abolish the scheme.

The Government also suggests that the scheme is now out of date, although there is no elaboration of this in the Minister's second reading speech. I will certainly be interested in the Minister's reply as to why precisely it is out of date. For example, the only thing we find in his second reading speech is the statement:
. . . because its objective as a re-establishment measure is not being met and it is inefficient to administer.

I have already dealt with that matter. I will be interested in the comments of the Minister as to why its objective is not being met and whether the Government is contemplating any other method of meeting what I presume the Government also supports as a worthwhile objective, that is, helping veterans to re-establish themselves in that transition to civilian life which, after all, was the objective of the original legislation in 1965. If that is not able to be achieved, as the Government maintains, through this particular mechanism, does the Government have some mechanisms through which to seek that type of re-establishment or something by way of an alternative scheme that will assist to achieve the objective that the Government maintains this piece of legislation has been unable to achieve?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has submitted a humbug amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Defence (Re-establishment) Amendment Bill. I am surprised that Senator Durack has the gall to do so, even given that oppositions frequently have a lot of gall, because the figures of $5,000 and $10,000 for the business and agricultural loans respectively were increased by the last Labor Government from the $3,000 and $6,000 which previously applied. In the seven years and a few months that the Government of which Senator Durack was a member was in office, and during which the consumer price index more than doubled, that Government made no attempt to adjust upwards the amounts of those loans. Thus, I think it is fair enough to describe that as a humbug amendment. Senator Durack's amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate condemns the further erosion in terms of service for servicemen and women . . .

Senator Durack may not have noticed that in fact in the critical area of ex-service entitlements-that is, of housing loans-the Government has announced a decision not only to preserve the existing rights of serving members of the forces but also to offer to the great majority of the serving members of the forces an option which will be more attractive. That option is to take an up-front lump sum payment of comparable value with the existing loan interest subsidy or, alternatively, a smaller amount of subsidy on a much larger loan. For example, the present housing loan is $25,000 which, as anybody would know, falls well short of the amount required to buy a house almost anywhere.

However, there is the ultimate sanction on the official Opposition that one day it will be in government. Those opposite know that one day they will have to deal with the problems of government. Of course, no such sanction applies to the Australian Democrats who are indulging again in the populist posturing which is typical of a group of opportunists and dilettantes trying to cobble together a coalition of vested interests large enough to get 10 per cent of the vote at election time, thereby ensuring their worthless political survival, knowing full well that they will never have to accept responsibility for anything they advocate or argue. The Democrats are for all tax cuts, for lower deficits, for all expenditure proposals and for reduced outlays.
