Regarding the one point of substance raised by Senator Macklin, the approximate total value of loans which were made last year and which would have been expected to be made next year, had the scheme continued, is in the order of $1.25m. The cost of administering that proposal is about $250,000, or 20 per cent. A scheme of this nature is innately managerially inefficient because all the requirements of legislation and public accountability must be met. It is innately inefficient for that reason, particularly when dealing with relatively small sums, as it always did, and better provisions can be provided much more quickly and delivered efficiently by the private sector.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) a question with regard to the figures that he included in his personal abuse, which went by the notion of a winding up of the debate. Can he actually tell me where the expense of $250,000 is incurred? In other words, is that an expense which is incurred by the Department or is it an expense which is charged to the Department by any other administrative body, such as a State or a bank which is carrying out the activities under the provisions of this Bill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are administrative expenses incurred within the Department. Loan applications take between three and six months to process. The viability of the proposal has to be investigated. The applicant's suitability and security have to be checked. The mortgage has to be drawn up and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Walsh) read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 12.41 to 2 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the Treasurer's statement yesterday attempting to explain away the Government's billion dollar Budget mistake on returns from provisional taxation. The Treasurer said that about half the revenue shortfall comes from primary producers, and I note his later comment:

QUESTION.PARA: There is a possibility that the prospects of higher taxation due to the recovery of incomes in 1983-84 may have led to more widespread resort to tax avoidance and evasion.

Is the Government suggesting that primary producers have engaged in large scale tax evasion? Is not the most likely explanation that increased outlays on deductible items led to a much smaller than anticipated net return from the farm sector? Does the Treasurer not realise that because of the Labor Government's disastrous policies affecting primary producers, an increase in gross income does not necessarily mean an increase in profitability?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the Treasurer's statement and therefore I am not in a position to say whether the quotations, or claimed quotations, which Senator Collard gave are in context or are a fair and reasonable interpretation. However, I do know that the Australian Taxation Office had estimated that there would be an increase of 8 per cent, presumably in real terms, in deductible expenditure items from primary producers' income but that the current estimate in fact is that that 8 per cent has increased to 30 per cent or 40 per cent. I do not know on what particular items that 30 per cent to 40 per cent was spent.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the latter part of Senator Collard's question, it remains an indisputable fact that agriculture, along with the Australian economy in general, was in the depths of the deepest recession since the 1930s, and in the agricultural sector the deepest recession since 1970, once again under a Liberal and National Party coalition Government. There has been a very large increase in agricultural profitability since then.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not suggesting that that has anything at all to do with you?

—Yes, of course it has. It has a great deal to do with us because, when we came into government, inflation was 11 1/2 per cent and rising. Senator Lewis can ask any farmer what his greatest threat is and he will say that it is inflation. Inflation was 11 1/2 per cent and rising when we came into government. Within 18 months to two years it was reduced to, I think, 5 per cent. So we halved the rate of inflation in two years. Any farmer will say that there is no greater threat to the long term survival of agriculture than a high rate of inflation. Therefore, to a very significant extent it is due to this Government and the policies it has successfully pursued.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst this is not particularly relevant to the farm sector per se, although there are many part time farmers who supplement their incomes with off farm work, I might add that when we came into government the Fraser Government had achieved the unique record of having both inflation and unemployment in double figures, and both were rising.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Finance and I refer to a full-page advertisement in today's Daily Sun in which the minority Premier of Queensland claims that Queensland is being discriminated against by the Federal Government. The advertisement lists alleged discrimination under seven headings. Are the claims by the Queensland Government correct and, if they are, how can it afford to place blatant propaganda such as this in the Queensland media?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen facsimiles of advertisements which the Queensland Government, I presume, has had inserted in a number of Queensland papers. The paper which I have here is, I think, the Townsville Daily Bulletin, but I am not sure of that. Evidently identical advertisements have been inserted in a number of papers. Unfortunately, I am not able to tell Senator Colston what the cost of those advertisements is. Some of the items in the advertisements are technically correct but the general picture is grossly distorting, misleading and dishonest. For example, a figure is quoted regarding the Australian bicentennial road development program. The fact is that Queensland has received slightly more from the bicentennial road development program this year than Victoria, and Queensland has about half the population of Victoria. So in regard to that item Queensland is in fact getting twice as much per capita as Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to tertiary education funding, Queensland started from an extremely low base in 1974. The reason it started from an extremely low base in 1974 is that until that time tertiary education had been funded jointly by Commonwealth and State governments and the Commonwealth governments of that time, and for a long time before that, required a matching contribution from State governments. Of course, in the case of Queensland the Bjelke-Petersen Government had refused to make the matching grants which both the Whitlam Government and the previous Liberal-Country Party coalition governments had required in order for the States to qualify for Commonwealth funds. Therefore, Queensland started from that very low base. The funding for tertiary education in Queensland has grown at a much faster rate in more recent years than in Australia generally. To take the 1985-87 triennium for example, the real growth rate in tertiary education funding to Queensland is 9 per cent compared with 6 per cent in Australia as a whole. Therefore, that area is another of the items dishonestly presented in that advertisement by the Queensland Government.

In regard to the bottom line on payments to Queensland compared with payments to other States, the most recent Budget Papers show the simple fact that total Commonwealth payments to the six States averaged $1,277 per capita. Commonwealth payments to Queensland averaged $1,324 per capita. Therefore, Queensland's per capita total payments from the Commonwealth Government are some $47 per capita higher than in any other State. In absolute terms that would be of the order of $100m above the per capita average paid to Queensland from that source. It is well known of course that a Commonwealth Grants Commission report has been received recently and that the recommendation, amongst other things, will be considered at the Premiers Conference this week. The Grants Commission is an independent and objective agency. I think it is very important to note that. Perhaps it has passed judgment on the validity of the extravagant misrepresentations appearing in various Queensland newspapers today under the name of the Queensland Government and at the cost, in the first instance, of the Queensland taxpayers and ultimately, I suppose, of the taxpayers of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance whether the Government's trilogy commitment to cut the money level of the 1984-85 Budget deficit next financial year will be based on the now discredited $6.7 billion deficit or yesterday's newly recalculated deficit of the order of $7.1 billion? Would the recently discredited Minister for Finance prefer not to make a commitment at this stage because of the possibility that further costly mistakes may yet be discovered and the final deficit figure may ultimately go much higher still?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Rae for that question because it gives me an opportunity to set a few facts straight and to correct some misreporting in the Australian newspaper-which is not at all surprising-and, what is more surprising, misreporting in the Age. What was stated quite clearly yesterday is that it is now expected that in one particular revenue item there will be a revenue shortfall of the order of $1 billion. The latest estimate is that Budget estimates of revenue will be exceeded and also that outlays in total are likely to fall short of the Budget estimates. The net reduction in revenue on present estimates is of the order of $400m.
—That is the figure I used in my question.

—I did not say the honourable senator was misrepresenting or misreporting. I thanked him for the opportunity to correct a couple of newspapers which have misreported. Because of that reduction in revenue the increase in the deficit will be considerably less than $400m, probably of the order of $200m which is, in an outlays figure of almost $64 billion, an extremely small percentage. The Australian reported:

ANSWER.PARA: Although the Government moved quickly to put an end to reports that the deficit could be $1 billion more than expected, renewed estimates put it at least $400 million higher.
The Australian was maintaining its well-earned reputation for writing fiction as news. Somewhat more surprisingly, as I said earlier, the Melbourne Age also had the story wrong and said:
. . . the gap could be about $400 million, taking the deficit this financial year to more than $7,000 million.

No such thing was said and that report is also inaccurate. To return to Senator Rae's question directly, the undertaking which was given before the election is that the money deficit in the next financial year will be lower than the estimated deficit in the 1984-85 Budget. That of course means there will be a very significant reduction in the deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product. This year's estimated deficit in round figures of $6.74 billion on present estimates could rise as high as $6.9 billion, but the $6.74 billion was the relevant figure for consideration of the trilogy.

Just to give some indication of the difference between a lower money deficit and a lower deficit as a proportion of GDP, a deficit of the same proportion of GDP as the $6.74 billion in 1984-85, translated in 1985-86 figures, would be approaching $8 billion. So there will be a very substantial reduction in the deficit as a proportion of GDP, and some reduction in the nominal deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he is aware of a report in today's Age which suggests a resumption in Indonesia of the policy of executing political dissidents. Did the report also allege that a trade union official and member of the Indonesia Communist Party, the PKI, Mohammad Munir, had been executed and that the execution by firing squad of three other PKI leaders was being planned? Can the Minister say whether this report is accurate and whether the Australian Government will respond to it? Further, did the same newspaper report carry a statement from Indonesian officials stating that they expected the Australian Government to prevent continuation of radio contact between East Timor and Australia? Can the Minister give an assurance that the Australian Government will not interfere with the transmitter which is located on Australian soil?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with very deep regret that the Government recently learned of the execution on 14 May of Mohammad Munir, a trade union official and member of the banned Indonesian Communist Party. Munir was imprisoned in 1968 and sentenced to death in 1973. He made a series of appeals against his sentence, the last in 1984, to the President, which was turned down. The Australian Government is concerned that although the execution appears to have followed the formal observance of the Indonesian legal process, Munir was executed after having already served a very long prison sentence. Whatever one thinks of the death penalty itself, or the right of countries to impose it, it is very difficult to believe that the carrying out of such a penalty could ever be justified for someone who has been imprisoned for 17 years and under sentence of death for 12 years. The Government would hope that reason and compassion will prevail with respect to other former PKI members under sentence of death and awaiting execution.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second part of the question, I am of course aware of media reports that a radio transmission from a Fretilin leader in East Timor was received over the weekend near Darwin. The alleged transmission is said to have cited examples of abuses of human rights by Indonesian forces in East Timor. The Government has noted that illegal transmission may have taken place from Australian territory and this aspect of the matter will receive attention from the responsible Minister, the Minister for Communications.

The Government is aware of reports from time to time concerning accusations of human rights violations in East Timor. We view these reports with concern but have no recent information to suggest increased levels of activity by either Indonesian or Fretlin forces which might have led to killings by either side. We follow the situation in East Timor with very close attention. The Government has raised its concern about East Timor, including, of course, human rights issues, with the Indonesian authorities on many occasions, most recently at the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in March 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance will have noted with concern that the dollar nose-dived again yesterday, closing at just above 66c against the United States dollar. Does the Minister agree that the revelation of a deficit increase, poor production statistics and continuing concern that the Government has lost control of the money supply were the main factors in the slide? Does this latest dip in the dollar indicate that the mini-Budget has failed to convince the financial markets of the Government's ability to manage the economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is possible that the exchange rate was influenced by the news yesterday; it is possible that it was influenced by the misreporting of the news by the Murdoch Press to which I have already referred. Even taking the misreporting of the Murdoch Press as being news instead of the fiction that it was, a change in the deficit of that order of magnitude is an extremely small proportion of total outlays. Indeed, I think it requires a certain amount of luck to be able to budget accurately enough to produce a deficit close to the estimated deficit. For the first Budget this Government produced in 1983-84, if I remember correctly, the difference between the Budget estimate of the deficit and the actual outcome was of the order of $600m; it was $600m lower than had been anticipated when the Budget was put together. This is in marked contrast to the deficit outcome of the last Budget produced by the discredited former Treasurer. At Budget time 1982 he predicted a deficit of $1,700m and finished up with a deficit of $4,500m. That is a discrepancy of almost $3 billion. He finished up with a deficit almost three times as big as the one he had budgeted for. This Government has, in the one year which it has now completed in office and in this year which it is about to complete, come much closer to the mark than that. If the exchange rate was significantly affected by a minimal change in the estimated deficit, a change of the order of less than 0.3 per cent of total outlays, the money market is not behaving very rationally. I guess a number of things that have happened in the money market recently suggest that it has more to do with hocus-pocus and cargo cultism than it does with rational analysis.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it is possible that the disclosure of a substantial shortfall in collections of particular types of revenue and the possibility that that shortfall was due to tax avoidance and tax evasion may be seen as a more significant matter. I suggest to Senator Parer that if he wants to restore the confidence of people in the money market and elsewhere in the ability of this Government to recover the revenue which ought to be recovered, he should persuade his colleagues to behave differently in the Senate from the way in which they have behaved in the past when voting on legislation. It is a matter of record that half, or these days two-thirds, of the Australian Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Liberal and National parties have consistently frustrated the attempts by this Government to make people pay the taxes which they ought to have paid.

The attitude of the Opposition parties to tax evasion can be summed up by this analogy: If one has had one's fist in the till all the week and one is caught on Friday, one has to pay back the money that one pinched on Friday but one does not have to pay back the money that one pinched on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday. That is the attitude of all the Opposition parties. The attitude of this Government is that if one gets caught with one's fist in the till on Friday one must pay back what one pinched on Friday and on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I wish to direct Senator Walsh's attention to the other points that I raised in the question. I did not refer entirely to the deficit increase. I also referred to the poor production statistics and the continuing concern that the Government has lost control of the money supply. I said that these were other factors which had brought about the further devaluation of our dollar.

—There used to be a simplistic theory that was popularised by Milton Friedman which I thought no one took seriously any more. There was a monetary equation that the money supply multiplied by the velocity of circulation equals the price of goods and the quantities of goods, and from this Friedman developed the simplistic and logically unsound theory that increases or decreases in the money supply were directly proportionate to changes in prices. That ignored the fact that there were two other variables, one on each side of the equation. I thought that no one took that equation seriously any more. Even beyond that, as a result of the changes in the financial system over the past 18 months, whatever value M3 may have had as an indicator of the true level of the money supply-something that is impossible to measure with precision anyway-it now has much less value because it is no longer as relevant to the financial system as it was before deregulation.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment been drawn to a page one report in today's Age newspaper headed 'Australia not only broke China's sword but misled her about paying for it'? The article refers to last year's Chinese Entombed Warriors Exhibition. Can the Minister say whether this report is accurate?

—The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided me with the following information: Suggestions that Australian officials have been deceptive in dealing with the Chinese Government are unfounded. The level of compensation was agreed between Australian and Chinese representatives within the terms of the original agreement. The total value of the visiting exhibition which was brought to Australia by the International Cultural Corporation of Australia Ltd was $382m. The total indemnity paid to date-that is, for the cost of damage-is $299,521, a very small proportion by comparison with the total value of the exhibition. Damage also occurred to a painting during the Picasso exhibition at the National Gallery in Victoria and compensation is being negotiated in accordance with the agreement at present.
—Will the Minister please table the paper from which she has quoted?
—Will the Minister table the paper?
—Yes.
—The Minister tables the document.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of the findings of the Federal Government-funded study 'Young Australians Today' which says that 80 per cent of Australia's 2.6 million young people fear unemployment? Does the Minister realise that many young people saw the community employment program as one of the safety nets which might rescue them if they became part of the chronically unemployed category? How can the Government retain the confidence of young people in themselves and in their government when it signals in its May economic statement that the community employment program is to be chopped?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get one fact straight. The estimates in the May statement provide for the same level of new approvals in 1985-86 as there were in 1984-85. So the number of people coming into the CEP in the next financial year will be the same as it is likely to be this financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose Senator Jack Evans could argue that the CEP should be funded at a higher level. One could argue that everything should be funded at a higher level. Indeed Senator Evans's Party tends to argue just that. Unfortunately, when it comes to raising revenue, Senator Evans's Party tends to do the opposite and to vote against measures which will raise revenue.

Apart from the record of two-thirds of the Australian Democrats on tax evasion and avoidance, which I have already mentioned, I refer Senator Evans to his own record on the legislation to introduce cash bidding. The Government had estimated that significant revenue could be obtained through throwing open for cash bids petroleum licence areas. It believed that significant revenue could be raised from that source. Thanks to the ideological prejudice of the Liberal Party of Australia, and whatever it was that motivated the Democrats, that idea was rejected on the completely specious argument, if I may say so, that the Australian off-shore areas were not sufficiently prospective to carry a system of cash bidding. If the industry had come to that judgment it would have bid precisely nothing.

Due to that actions of Senator Evans and his ilk the opportunity to make that assessment was denied to the industry and money was denied to revenue as well, money which may have been used to maintain a higher level of funding for the CEP or some other worthy purpose. Oppositions can have that luxury of saying that every area of expenditure should receive more funds but that nobody should have to pay any more taxes. Governments have to accept responsibility for the things they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Further to the earlier question regarding the misleading advertising campaign of the minority Queensland Government, I ask the Leader of the Government whether he is concerned about the ongoing hostility of the Queensland Premier in continually blaming the Federal Government for Queensland's own mismanagement of its economy. Is the Minister aware that the Premier repeatedly threatens to secede and to sue the Federal Government if he cannot dictate his own terms at the Premier's Conference this week? What steps can the Federal Government take to reassure Queenslanders that they cannot rely on the extremist claims of a minority Premier but they can depend on the Prime Minister to fund Queensland fairly?
—Can you remember all of that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure. I am aware of what Senator Reynolds calls the ongoing hostility of the Queensland Premier towards the Commonwealth Government. It appears to be no secret as even I am aware of that. He certainly blames the Commonwealth Government for a lot of matters which are peculiarly within the province of the Queensland Government in respect of Queensland's economic development. I suppose that is one of the things we have to live with in politics. All I am saying is that the Queensland Premier seems to have a somewhat exaggerated approach to his brief. I am also aware of the Queensland Government's threat to secede from the Commonwealth and I have on previous occasions answered questions about that. I think it would not be in the interests of the Queensland people for that to happen, but he may get a majority for such a move in some other States.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the extremist claims about Federal government funding of Queensland are concerned, they have to be dealt with in the context of a forthcoming Premiers Conference. In the leadup to a Premiers Conference all Premiers tend to make claims which are somewhat exaggerated, but that does not ignore the fact that the Commonwealth Government has to deal with those matters when the Premiers actually meet.

In an earlier answer in relation to Queensland Senator Walsh indicated that some of the suggestions made by the Queensland Government and the Premier in their advertising campaign were misconceived. I think it is not unfair to describe them as 'disingenuous'. I repeat that in 1984-85 the per capita payment to Queensland was $1,324, which was 4 per cent higher than the six-State average. Of course, there are particular payments which vary between States for many reasons, including State expenditure priorities and questions such as distance which determine payments in respect of roads. But even in relation to roads, which is a classic example much cited in Queensland, Queensland receives more funds under this program than the State of Victoria, for example, and more on a per capita basis again than the six-State average, which includes the other big States. One can go through a variety of programs and see the same pattern emerging.

When the Queensland Premier comes to Canberra at the end of the week for the Premiers Conference he will no doubt seek to justify some of the outrageous claims that have been made. He will have to be better than he has been in his Press advertisements this week. While he may think he can pull the people of Queensland by the nose in respect of these issues, he will have a different task when he comes to Canberra to negotiate at the Premiers Conference. His views, of course, will be taken into account having regard not only to the requirements and interests of other States and the Commonwealth, but also to the facts, and that is an important matter which he will have to get over.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Finance. Is it a fact that the Forward Estimates were prepared on the assumption that there would be no 2 per cent Commonwealth Public Service pay rise? What effect will the 2 per cent pay rise granted by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, with the full support of the Government, have on Government outlays?

—The Forward Estimates were prepared on the assumption that there would not be a pay rise, because it had not happened at that stage. This figure is subject to check because I am only going from memory, but I think the effect of the pay rise on full year outlays is of the order of $100m. I will have that checked.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Press report that the State Government of Queensland could lose most or all of the deposit paid on a contract to purchase a new Lear Fan turbo-jet? Has the Minister also noted that the Premier, as Treasurer, paid a $250,000 deposit on a $2.1m contract to purchase this plane? Is it true, as reported, that the construction company, Lear Fan Aircraft Co., collapsed yesterday? Does the Minister believe that the Treasurer, Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, should be accountable for the loss of outgoing funds which could be allocated to support job creation, welfare or education in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen Press reports along the lines that Senator Jones indicates. Indeed, there is such a report in the Courier-Mail, I believe, of today's date. It appears that soon after the Queensland Premier had had delivered his jet aircraft, which cost the Queensland taxpayers about $8m in 1982, he ordered a Lear Fan turbo-prop aircraft which was to cost another $2.1m and paid a $250,000 deposit on that purchase. It now appears that the Lear Fan Aircraft Co. either has collapsed or is about to collapse in spite of very substantial assistance from the British Government, of the order of $100m. I suppose this action does help to give us a fix on the Queensland Premier's priorities in that, although an advocate of frugality for other governments and other people, he has never been backward in indulging himself, or indeed members of his family, with funds from the Queensland Treasury, which he now controls directly.

ANSWER.PARA: I fear, though, that there is little that the Commonwealth Government can do about this sort of thing, other than endeavouring to ensure that the people of Queensland know about it, as they are entitled to know. One could only agree with Senator Jones that it would have been better to apply that amount of money to some worthy purpose than the purpose to which it was applied, even if the original intention of the policy had been fulfilled-that is, if the aircraft had actually been purchased.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the belated changes to the pension assets test announced last Sunday. What steps is the Government taking to compensate those pensioners who have already disposed of their assets or are in the course of doing so under the rules existing before Sunday's changes? Further, will the Government pay backdated adjustments to pensioners who have had their pensions reduced or taken away since the introduction of the test on 21 March but who are now treated differently under these new rules?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is none. People who were dealt with under the assets test-
—'Dealt with' is a good expression, too.

—The honourable senator can suit himself. I thought that he would wait until the debate this afternoon, when we could deal with him. People who, under the assets test, had assessments made knew all along what the rules were at the time, and they also knew that the conditions under which the administration of the assets test was occurring in rural areas were under constant review. They were reviewed with care. Senator Messner may believe that the changes have been belated. We do not believe that they are belated at all. They are just administrative changes to cope with some of the difficulties that have been brought to our attention-not so much by the Opposition but by people who are more concerned about seeing a fair system than about making political points.

ANSWER.PARA: People in rural areas, as I pointed out to Senator Walters last night, are treated under the hardship provisions of the assets test far easier than are people who are applying for special benefit, and far easier than those who were applying for special benefits when Senator Chaney and I were Ministers for Social Security. So the people knew. Nothing has received more publicity in recent months than the assets test. The few people who will be assisted by the changes will know about them and will get the benefit of them. There will be very few people whose position will be changed by the review who have not already appealed, because the changes affect primarily the hardship provisions, valuations, and a few people who have given donations to nursing homes.

Of pensioners, 97.4 per cent will remain unaffected, as they did before. The 31,000 pensioners who crossed themselves off immediately the assets test was introduced, and did not even bother to fill in a form because they knew that they should not have been getting the pension, will not be affected; nor will those who, with the assistance of their accountants, have had their assets in artificial schemes contrived to get the full pension and full fringe benefits be affected, because they were already picked up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer, but I want to know specifically whether the assessments for those who have lodged appeals will be backdated to 21 March, and from which date the new rules will apply to those who have not appealed.
—I think the new administrative procedures applied from Friday, when Mr Howe made his announcement.
—Was it Friday or Sunday?
—It might have been Sunday. I am sorry, I might be two days out.
—What about getting it straight? No wonder there is confusion.

—At least I can lie straight in bed, unlike some of the honourable senators opposite. With regard to the second part of Senator Messner's question relating to people who have already appealed, those who appealed some time ago about the revaluation of their properties will be paid back to the time they applied.
—Will they be assessed under the new rules?
—There are no new rules on the valuation of properties. The properties that were wrongly valued will be valued correctly this time.
—Oh, come on.
—Order! Senator Messner, you have already asked your supplementary question.
—The difficulty, Mr President, is that this afternoon Senator Messner is having his fifth matter of public importance on the assets test.
—Seventh.

—The seventh, I am sorry. The questions he asks are always about a minute number of people; they are not about the 97.4 per cent of pensioners who will not be affected. They are never about the vast majority of pensioners in this country who have no assets, who have no money in the bank, who have no income, and who have been ripped off by the sorts of people who have been picked up by the assets test in this case. Senator Messner spent the time before he came into this Parliament manipulating people's affairs so that they could avoid tax and receive the pension, and he continues to do so in this place. We will treat him with the disrespect he deserves.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to a newspaper report published today which predicts job losses of 4,300 in Tasmania should the Commonwealth Government implement recommendations made in the Commonwealth Grants Commission report. Were any of the Grants Commission members appointed by the current Labor Government? Does today's estimate accord with other estimates made about alleged employment losses in Tasmania?
—You just want to see the cuts made.
—Why don't you stand up for your State?
—That is the same as kicking the dairy farmers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that that question has aroused so much parochial ire in the chamber.
—It is a parochial question.

—It is more than a parochial question because the question of unemployment concerns the Commonwealth Government very much. That is why we have given so much attention to addressing the problem and that is why we have been so relatively successful compared with the previous Government. Let me say that the figure of 2,700, which some report in the Launceston Examiner identifies as being the number of potential disemployed persons as a result of the implementation of the Grants Commission program, was presented in that newspaper on Friday or Saturday of last week. That figure has grown to 4,300 today, according to the front page of that same newspaper.
—It is a different report.
—It is an independent report.

—It may be a different report. I have seen the newspaper, and it may well be, as Senator Walters and Senator Watson interject, a different report. In terms of the political purpose of the articles and the concern which articles such as this engender, I draw attention to the two headlines in the newspaper on the respective days.

ANSWER.PARA: The Grants Commission report and the allocation to be made to each State as a result of revenue-sharing arrangements is a matter for the Premiers Conference, and I can say nothing by way of prejudging the issues and the discussion at that Conference. It is a pity that the Launceston Examiner does not take the same care in dealing with this issue. I was also asked by Senator Aulich whether the members of the Grants Commission were Labor Government employees-

TALK.START.PARA: —Appointees.
—Yes, appointees.
—They are your employees, but not your appointees.

—I stand corrected on all these technical issues, but the point of Senator Aulich's question was, I suppose, arising from irresponsible allegations that have been made that the members of the Commonwealth Grants Commission are Labor Government appointees and therefore would bring down reports prejudicial to the State of Tasmania.
—The report doesn't say anything about that.

—I did not refer to that newspaper report; I said allegations which may have been made. The fact is that all members of the Grants Commission were appointed by the Fraser Government. They reported to this Government, and the question of what is in their report requires objective analysis, and it should not be influenced by the sort of scuttle-butt that goes on of the kind suggested.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the parliamentary Labor Party's division into at least three factions and to the Cabinet's division into at least four factions, and to the statement which the Minister made this morning about this factionalism in the Australian Labor Party when he said that he found this situation 'boring', despite the considerable concern about this factionalism expressed by others, such as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the National Secretary of the Party. Accordingly, I ask: While the Minister also said this morning that he is not wishing to provoke any retaliation from powerful faction leaders like Senator Richardson, and noting the Minister's admission of some degree of fear about the power they wield, does the Minister believe that the effectiveness of the Government and public confidence in the Government are being impaired by the existence of such formalised factions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to answer this question very truthfully and directly. I was lying in bed at about 7 o'clock this morning contemplating my day, and I thought: 'One thing that is likely to happen to me today, because it has not happened for a week or two, is that I will get an awfully boring question from Senator Teague'. Sure enough that turned out to be right. I tried to head him off on the AM program this morning by saying that a lot of the discussion about factionalism within the Australian Labor Party was pretty boring, and it is.
—We love it.
—I know the Opposition loves it.
—Tell that to Senator Cook.

—I am telling it to Senator Cook now through this microphone, and anybody else who is concerned. Senator Teague's question has a freshness about it in one respect. He now identifies four factions in the Cabinet, which is upmarket on any previous estimates. There are three factions in the Liberal Party of Australia and five, if not six, in the Australian Democrats; there are no factions at all in the National Party of Australia; which says something about the intellectual capacities of members of that Party and nothing else, and, of course, there are factions in the Australian Labor Party. If the Press had its way by its kind suggestions to all political parties about the degrees of factionalism that exist in those parties, we would all be reduced to the intellectual stature of the National Party because there would be no factions at all. We would all have exactly the same views about every conceivable topic.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I have made on numerous occasions is that any government, and any political party, will have a diversity of views in the councils of the Party about particular matters. I am saying that it is sometimes boring to hear those views expressed widely in the media about every conceivable topic. I am asked whether this limits the effectiveness of the Government. Those who write that sort of thing are in exactly the same category as the Liberal Party representatives in this Senate who, day after day, ask questions with mock horror about what might happen in 1986 in regard to a particular matter or what might happen to discounting of wages in 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are interested in 1985.

—Or in 1985; it does not matter. All sorts of questions are asked in this chamber that commence with the words: 'What might happen if . . . '. As far as I am concerned, I do not propose to oblige the Opposition about what might happen if a certain set of hypothetical circumstances come to fruition. Ultimately, what a government and a political party are judged on is what they do, not what individuals in that government or party happen to say at any time. I think that is the important point which I was seeking to make this morning. I hope that Senator Teague understands it even if nobody else on the other side of the House does.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. At 7 o'clock this morning and now the Minister answered only part of the question. The other part of the question was that matter about which the National Secretary of the Party was concerned-that is, the enormous undermining of public confidence in the Government. Does not factionalism answer for the appalling state in which the Government is now in the public opinion polls?

—No, I think it plays a very limited role in the undermining of confidence in the Government. Basically, I think it is Senator Messner, single-handedly, who has undermined the confidence in the Government because of his persistent references to wine tax and the assets test.

—My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the new repatriation determining system been fully implemented? Is there any sign that delays in the processing of claims and applications are being reduced?

—It is hoped that, once the system has settled down, it will be possible to achieve an average time taken of 90 days from lodgment of a claim to receipt of a decision by a determining officer. I have indicated to my Department that every effort should be made to achieve this average time by June 1986.
—The Department of Senator Gietzelt.

—I was referring to Senator Gietzelt, Senator Grimes. I indicate this on behalf of Senator Gietzelt. However, given that outstanding claims at the first level of decision totalled over 25,000 when the new system came into effect, it may be some time before this target is achieved. It is hoped that the average time will be reduced at the initial stage of decisions to approximately 150 days by December 1985. For reasons it is not easy to understand there is a substantial increase in claims lodged at the first level of the determining system which is currently running at 38,000 a year.

—My question, which is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows the answer that he gave to Senator Aulich in which he said that there may have been allegations that Commonwealth Grants Commission members were Labor appointees. Did the Minister simply drag that possibility out of the air or does he have some evidence to suggest that such allegations have been made? Is he suggesting in his answer that there has been political bias on the part of the Grants Commission in the reports that it brought down either recently or earlier?

—I dragged that possibility out of the air because I was asked whether they were Labor Government appointees or Liberal Government appointees. I dragged it out of the air in my response because I wanted to make it quite clear that I did not understand the point of the question, unless that allegation was floating around somewhere. I did not state that I had heard the allegation myself or anything like that.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I take it that the Minister is not suggesting political bias?
—No, I am not suggesting political bias on behalf of the Grants Commissioners.

—Can the Minister for Education comment on the progress of the participation and equity program and the possible effects of the recent decision to extend funding over four years instead of three years as originally intended? Is it fair to describe that program as a phantom education program as suggested by a correspondent in last week's National Times?

—I do not think that a program which to date has been funded by amounts of $77m in 1984 and $82m in 1985 can be described as a phantom program. I have had my attention drawn to the correspondent who wrote about the program in the National Times last weekend. I was gratified to read of the extent of support that there was for this initiative. That correspondent, at least, has seen a great deal of practical effect from the program. The program has been progressing at a very high level of allocation-as I said, $77m in 1984 and over $82m this year. The Government has decided to spread out the remaining funds, which initially were going to be spent in 1986 but which will be spent also in 1987; that is, $41m will be spent in each of the years 1986 and 1987. By any reckoning, these are substantial sums of money which will enable substantial progress to continue to be made towards the objectives of increased participation and increased equity in education.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. Is it a fact that the Macquarie University in Sydney will no longer receive an earmarked grant from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the triennium 1985-87 for its School of Slavonic Studies, despite the fact that the student numbers are well above the target figures set in 1982, at the time when the School was established? Can the Minister inform the Senate why such an important and, as far as I know, unique development in the study of cultures and languages of a considerable part of the Australian population will not be supported by the Labor Government?

—I will have to seek detailed information to respond to Senator Lajovic's question. I am not aware that a decision has been taken to discontinue that program. I point out to Senator Lajovic that decisions about particular courses within universities are usually taken by the councils of those universities. When decisions are taken about overall levels of expenditure to universities within a State, the decision makers take into account advice from the higher education co-ordinating body of that State. Final decisions about allocations of tertiary grants are taken by the Tertiary Education Commission. That series of decision making processes, none of which I have direct involvement in, can result in programs being set up or discontinued. I simply point that out to explain why at this point I cannot answer in detail Senator Lajovic's questions. Certainly, I have taken no such decision. I do not know whether such a decision has been taken, but I will seek the information for Senator Lajovic from the Tertiary Education Commission.
—Is the Minister for Community Services in a position to give details to child care centres and centre users as to how the current changes in child care subsidies will affect their budgets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I cannot give exact details to each child care centre.
—Not even to a dorothy dixer.

—I can say that it will affect them very little. I hear Senator Messner's interjection; but I can assure centres that there will not be a year of consolidation and review like we had under Senator Chaney, in which no one was funded, no one received any more funding and no new child care services were delivered. We will maintain the high standard of Commonwealth funded child care which we have in this country, maintain the system whereby people have access to children's services across a whole range and maintain our determination to increase the number of child care places. Since we came to government we have increased the number of places by 60 per cent. We will continue to increase the number of places by at least 20,000 in the next three years. In the funding of children's services we have a very generous fee relief system, but there are some inequities in it. For instance, families earning $50,000 or more a year pay the same subsidised fee in child care centres as families earning $28,000 a year. I do not believe that is an equitable system. All people receive up to $30 or $35 by way of an operational subsidy, regardless of income. What we intend to do by these small savings off the Forward Estimates is to rejig the fee relief system and the operational subsidy system, so those who are on high incomes will have to pay a bit more of their share. But we continue with our determination to build 20,000 new places in the next few years.

ANSWER.PARA: The changes that we are to make will not be introduced until 1 January. This will give us an opportunity to be sure that we do not make such changes, as has happened in the past, where the very wealthy are charged such high fees that they move right out of the system and the system is left as a second grade system just for the low income people. We want to maintain a balance of people across all groups, with our preference that particular disadvantaged groups will get priority of access. On looking at children's services in this country I have found that there has been some anxiety in that people who are extremely well off have been paying too little. There has been a general appreciation that the number of services has increased and the fee relief system has been very generous. I know that if a government suggests cutting $1m or $2m off any program there will be people who protest and organise themselves immediately because they fear that there will be a general slashing of funds across the board. I dare say those are the sorts of people who protested against the Prime Minister last night. Despite his and this Government's record in the last two years, they were willing to stand outside the function he was at last night and describe him as Judas and all sorts of things.

The answer is that the children's services program will continue. It will expand. The changes to individuals in child care centres will not be great. Certainly, some people on higher incomes will have to pay a little bit more. By the time we have finished this term of government we will have more than doubled the number of Commonwealth funded child care places in this country in less than two full terms of government. That is a record of which I think we can be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —By leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented by a Press report today. Today the Australian Associated Press put up a story which said that the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 was passed without opposition. I have received irate phone calls about that. I would like to make it clear to all concerned that anybody who had heard the debate last night at the second reading stage and had read the transcript would have seen that the measure was strongly opposed by me and, I believe, by others as well. This morning we considered the Bill in Committee. At the Committee stage one adopts a slightly different approach. As you would appreciate, Mr President, in Committee one cannot deal with the matters in the way that one can in a second reading debate. There was a quieter consideration of the matter this morning. Nevertheless, I do not know what one needs to do in this place to show that one opposes legislation-whether one stands on one's head on the table-
—Have your vote recorded.

—It was pointless to call for a division this morning as the Opposition had made it clear that it was a Budget Bill and that it would not oppose the Bill. I therefore take up the suggestion made by Senator Baume and seek leave to have my vote recorded in opposition to clauses 5 and 6 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Messner proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to make other than cosmetic changes to its harsh and inequitable pensions assets test.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This very important matter of public importance apparently has the interest of everybody in Australia, including the Opposition, but certainly not of the Government. During Question Time today the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) said: 'Look, this boring subject has been brought up seven times in the Senate by the Opposition'. That is only a little more than once for each time that the Government has changed its mind over the assets test since it was first introduced in August 1983. There is only one reason why this absolutely, may I say, obstinate but certainly stupid Government has maintained the so-called assets test. The Hawke Government appears to be determined to hold on to a fragment of the original test to maintain the myth that it is a government which can take hard decisions. That is the only explanation that one can put upon the mess that it has developed, the muddle that it has perpetrated on the Australian people since August 1983, the confusion in the minds of Ministers as evidenced even here today by the Minister for Community Services, who in Question Time could not even tell us the date from which the new provisions announced last Sunday would apply. Those are the latest conditions and he, the Minister representing the Minister for social insecurity, could not tell us when those provisions would begin to apply. How can the Government expect the people of Australia to understand the assets test when the Minister cannot even tell them, when questioned, when the provisions will begin to apply?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us just consider what has occurred since August 1983. First of all, it was claimed that the original assets test would bring in some $320m. In fact, the evidence now is that some $80m will be brought in by the assets test. That is the measurement of the changes that have occurred over those 18 or 20 months. But against that the Government has spent $65m to set up the scheme and has employed an extra 1,500 public servants to do the work. The cost of running the assets test is of the order of $30m a year. Is it any wonder that the people of Australia are pressing the Opposition to discuss this matter even more and more urgently as time goes by? Whether the Government has in mind any further changes to the assets test, God only knows. At this time all we can suggest is that the Government must have some hidden agenda for the assets test to which we, and certainly the Australian people, have not been party. As we said during the election campaign, we see the assets test on pensions as only part of, or the first foot in the door towards, the introduction of death duties, a capital gains tax or both.

Let us consider very quickly the history of the assets test. Firstly, there was the Hawke assets test mark 1, announced on 23 August 1983. Its features were: A deemed income rate of 10 per cent, and exemptions for pensioners' homes, two motor cars, personal effects such as jewellery, furniture, antiques and paintings on the wall, caravans, boats and so on. Then, in November of that year, we saw the Hawke assets test mark 2, and the introduction of a lifestyle package that included a $30,000 exemption for things such as holiday homes, bush blocks, boats and so on.

Hawke assets test mark 3 followed in January 1984 when we saw the introduction of certain provisions to alleviate hardship for the self-employed and for farmers. Of course, that was most inadequate as was demonstrated later as the result of persistent pushing and questioning on the part of the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia. During this time a growing tide of public opinion was rising against the assets test and it was only in a flash of inspiration that the silver-haired messiah, on his way back from Japan by air in February 1984, suddenly decided that the assets test was not good for people in Australia and that he would do something about it. He even admitted the error of all his ways by saying:

It has become clear that there is continuing and justifiable uncertainty about whether the Government has yet found the best way to implement legislation on an assets test in a fair and equitable way.

I can tell honourable senators that the people of Australia still have that opinion. It is 15 months on from that flash of brilliance of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I would like to bring home to those opposite who are complaining about the assets test within Caucus or within their own factions, or wherever they meet in their mouseholes, that, had the Opposition not opposed this legislation in September 1983, the original assets test would have been law by now. The irony of that, of course, is that, had the original legislation been passed, the Labor Government would probably have been swept from office in the election last December. Because of persistent pressure from the Opposition there has been a great deal of modification of the assets test, to the point that it has reached today. Back in May 1984 the Government decided to appoint Professor Fred Gruen to investigate what kind of assets test should be introduced for Australians. He reported at the end of May 1984 and his main recommendation was that the family home should be included in the assets test. Of course, the Government did not accept that, so we had the Hawke assets test mark 4.

Senator Grimes and the Prime Minister, in joint statements, introduced then what was called the modified tall poppies test. This has now been in existence for about a year with growing concern being expressed in the community about the unfair and discriminatory impact, especially on small businessmen and farmers, and those in rural situations. The community has been bringing forward cases of discrimination. There have been protest meetings all over the country attended by hundreds, in some cases thousands, of people, all protesting about the hardship caused by this law. The media is constantly bringing to our attention cases of individuals who have been unjustly treated, which have been most pertinent, poignant and in every way absolutely descriptive of the hardship that this Hawke Labor Government has wrought on the community.

The Opposition's position has been clear from day one. We oppose the assets test. We stand for the repeal of the legislation upon being elected to government. Even within the Government's back bench, 22 rural Labor back benchers are concerned; and concerned they might be because surely they will lose their seats at the next election as a result of the assets test and other lack of rural concern by this Government. Let me put to honourable senators the words of Mr Barry Cunningham, the chairman of the Caucus committee that investigated the assets test. He holds the seat of McMillan in Victoria. He was quoted in the Border Watch, that famous journal in the south-east of South Australia, saying that--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren's bible.

—Yes, former Senator McLaren knew that paper very well. Mr Cunningham claimed that the farmers had been diddling the tax system for years. This kind of theme has been picked up in the last day or so by no less a person than Mr Keating, the Treasurer. In seeking to explain away his own mistakes in estimating the Budget revenue for the current financial year, he blames it all on the farmers. He claims that they are tax evaders and tax avoiders; that they are trying to manipulate their incomes to avoid taxation. Of course, this is typical of the attitude of this Government to the situation of rural people.

SPEECH.PARA: On a television program on Sunday we heard the National Secretary of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Bob McMullan, saying that the Labor Party is perceived as being anti the aged in the community and that the Party will have to overcome that image in order to survive electorally. We come to the decision of last Sunday, which was, of course, the Hawke assets test mark 5. In the latest changes we get a revision of the pension pay as you die scheme. We will have a minimum of $100,000. That is a good step forward. I believe that in that area the Government has done something which is of great value to people. The second point is the doubling of the amounts with regard to the hardship provision. That decision is certainly not adequate. It is a puny attempt to redress the problems in that area.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few thousand dollars.

—As my colleague Senator Teague says, it is a very small amount which will be of very little value. The next point is that people who have lived on a property for 20 years will not be expected to sell that property. I will return to that point because I believe that to be a fundamental mistake in the Government's thinking. There is to be a recognition of the payment of forgone wages in determining the value of a property. Again, that is a good point, but no guidelines have been provided. Nobody knows how that will affect pensioners. Consequently, we cannot form a valued opinion about that. I will come back to that point in a moment. There will be certain other cosmetic changes such as the change to the deemed rate of income derived from property. There is to be a process of speeding up the valuations, reviews and appeals under the present assets test provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider some of the difficulties that come immediately to mind as a result of the Government's decision. Consider the 20-year rule. The Government says that if a person has been on a property for 20 years he will not have to sell the property; the Government will pay him the pension anyway. I hope that is the correct interpretation of what Mr Howe, the Minister for Social Security, was saying on Sunday. We are certainly left in the dark about some aspects of that. Let me put to honourable senators what I have found to be the cause of the greatest hardship in the rural community. People who have inherited a property face very substantial death duties under the provisions of the laws that have applied in this country since before 1978. In many cases, those duties could amount to hundreds of thousands of dollars. Those people may be forced to sell the property in order to pay the duties and then move on to another property. Many of them will not be helped by the Government's 20-year rule. Yet that is the very group of people who will suffer most. Those who will be affected are those who have been hit most seriously by death duties in the past and who have reduced rural holdings in the way people have been complaining about for years. So the Government has not helped them in any way. In fact, that is the kind of situation in which the Government's needs based principle, or whatever it is the Government professes, just falls apart at the seams.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not read the Press release.

—I remind Senator Coates that there are many other examples. One might consider compulsory acquisition as being a problem for people with regard to the Government's 20-year rule. Let us look at the matter of the forgone wages. Certainly, this is a most valuable point. Where a son has inherited a property and has worked on that property for many years with little or no wages, those wages are to be calculated and taken into account in assessing the value of the property. The Government does not tell us whether that is to be done in 1985 money values or the money values that applied in the past. We do not know what effect it will have in real terms. However, the most important question is whether, that money having been declared to the Department of Social Security as wages forgone, those people can expect a bill from the Australian Taxation Office for the tax that has not been paid in respect of those wages.
—What a wondrous imagination.

—The trouble with the Minister is that he never bothers to think through these questions and find out the answers before he blunders into this place. That is why he is left with egg on his face in regard to the assets test and has been for the last two years. He fails to appreciate the problems involved with the assets test. We need an assurance from the Government that the tax that might be charged by the Taxation Office will not so reduce the amount of the valuation as to put people back into the same position they were in before the announcement the other day. We need to know how many extra staff are to be employed by the Department to speed up the review process for valuations and appeals and how quickly people can have their cases heard. Again, we had confusion about this matter from the Minister at Question Time this afternoon. There was no clear indication as to where people stand in relation to appeals.

SPEECH.PARA: All of this adds up to the fact that the assets test as it is now, irrespective of the various changes made to it over the last two years, is virtually the same as it was. It is different only in that it is creating new problems, new anomalies and new difficulties for people. The basic question still remains as far as rural people are concerned, and I do not know how many more times we have to repeat this to the Government to get it to see the point. A person who lives in the city and who may have a house worth $200,000 and $50,000 in other assets can get the pension, but a farmer who has a house worth $50,000 and a farm worth $200,000-in other words, in both cases there is exactly the same total value of assets-cannot get the pension. Why is that?

TALK.START.PARA: —You would agree with including the family home?

—No. Senator Coates misses the point entirely, as he always does. The point is, as we said right from the outset, that the assets test is unworkable, illogical, and does not work in favour of people. I do not know why Senator Coates cannot see this. He is obviously tied into some great, obstinate point of view. The Government says that it has a great deal of money coming from the assets test with which it can help the needy. Let us see how the Government is to help the needy. It cannot raise the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings without it costing more than $1 billion. It will get a puny $80m out of the assets test. On a television program this morning the Minister for Social Security said: 'We have the beautiful home and community care program. That will be a revolution. It will change everything'. What has the Government done? One of the greatest election tricks of all time took place during the election campaign last year. The Government said that it was going to spend $300m on the home and community care program, but we find, under questioning, that only an extra $10m is going into that program. That is the sort of trick this Government has been perpetrating upon the people. The Government is now trying to switch the argument to what we are doing about things such as the home and community care program. That has caused only disillusionment in the public mind already. Obviously, this Government has no idea of what it intends to do.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me turn briefly to the role of the Australian Democrats in this situation. Many times the Liberals and the National Party have brought forward Bills in both the House of Representatives and the Senate to get rid of the assets test. We looked to the Democrats to support us. They have let us down on every occasion. Consistently, all the way they have opposed our trying to get rid of the assets test. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know that in your State of Queensland Senator Macklin is going around claiming that the Democrats have been trying to get rid of the assets test time and time again. Before the assets test was voted upon in the Senate, Senator Macklin said to the pensioner groups of Queensland: 'I am not going to support an assets test'. What happened when the vote was taken in here? He would not even come into the chamber and vote. He stayed out. He would not vote against the legislation and he would not vote for it. That is what sort of courage he has. You consider the case of Senator Jack Evans in Western Australia, who-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Messner, will you address your remarks through the Chair.

—I thought I was, very directly, Mr Acting Deputy President. I make the point that in a similar situation in Western Australia Senator Evans made the point that he believed that the Liberals had let him down in seeking changes. As we all know, of course, the Democrats never put forward any amendments in public to change the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has failed again with the assets test. It will continue to fail until it realises that it is wrong. It is wrong in principle because the assets test can never be established in such a way that it is not discriminatory and does not affect people unfairly and inequitably. The Labor Government's assets test does discriminate against people and for that reason it should be abolished. The sooner the Government realises that, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing yet again with another matter of public importance put forward by Senator Messner on the assets test. Today's wording is:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to make other than cosmetic changes to its harsh and inequitable pensions assets test.

It seems to me that in times which everyone admits are economically difficult and in times when great changes are being made to the economy, it is very surprising that once a week there seems to be an urgent desire by the Opposition to raise these alleged matters of public importance and perhaps an even more urgent desire by Senator Messner to get up here and have his 20 minutes worth on the assets test and to throw in a few other things to pad out the time, as he did today, like giving the home and community care service a forehander and giving Senator Haines, Senator Macklin and Senator Jack Evans a backhander. He gradually filled out his time with his usual emotive and nit-picking speech which I am afraid we are all getting very used to and which, to use the expression of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, we are all getting very bored with.

To take up Senator Messner's final point, that Senator Macklin said one thing and did another and that Senator Evans is alleged to have done something which he said he did not do, I remind Senator Messner of his good friend and supporter, Mr Alex Downer. What seat is he in? He was one of the most vocal supporters of the assets test ever seen on television or heard on radio anywhere in this country, but he was suddenly transformed in order to get pre-selection for the Liberal Party of Australia. There are others, like Mr Julian Beale in Victoria, who make no bones about the fact that they support an assets test. We wonder why Mr Howard is so silent, why we never hear anything from him. We know that Mr Howard supports an assets test. We know that in the past Senator Chaney and Mr Peacock and a whole swag of people on the other side have supported the needs based principle. In a very articulate speech in this place which I have quoted several times, Senator Chaney demonstrated his belief in the need for an assets test at that time. Why do these people on the other side of politics take this view?

TALK.START.PARA: —Never me.

—Never Senator Teague! Never would Senator Teague believe such a thing! The reason they take this view is that they believe it is quite simply unfair and inequitable that someone who retires from the New South Wales Government railways and gets a small weekly superannuation payment, someone who gets a small income from investment, someone who gets a small benefit from someone who has left it to him or someone who earns a small amount of income in his spare time, should be income tested, whereas someone who has the capacity to put his worldly wealth into what is termed assets or capital in this country and gets a gain from it and is able to live on it, should be able to get the full pension and the full fringe benefits. That is why they believe in an assets test. That is why they believe it is quite unfair to penalise people because they receive a small income and let people go scot-free if they have large assets from which they could acquire income and, indeed, from which they sometimes do. That is why the assets test was introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Messner's first complaint about the assets test, which I note he did not bring up today for a change, was that it is an invasion of people's privacy; that in fact it is absolutely outrageous to ask people what their assets are but perfectly legal, respectable and all right to demand to know from people, as governments of all persuasions in this country have done since before the Second World War, what their income is. He says it is okay to ask people what their income is but that it is wrong to ask people what their assets are.

The simple fact of the matter is that it is now known very clearly that a considerable number of people, although a very small proportion of pensioners, were in fact so manipulating their affairs as to defeat the letter and the spirit of the law in this country in order to get a full pension and full fringe benefits despite the fact they were very much better off than most other people in our community. They were saying to people on low incomes, perhaps with children: 'You should contribute extra income for me through your taxation despite the fact that I am very much better off than you. They are saying to the vast majority of pensioners in this community who have no assets apart from their own home, if they are lucky, and who have no income apart from the pension: 'Your pension should be held down so that I can get the same pension as you. I am the same age as you and I deserve a pension because I have lived in this country all my life'. This is the usual sort of argument we hear.

Both sides of politics in this community believe in a needs based social security system. If we have a needs based social security system we inevitably must have means tests or incomes tests. If we have incomes tests without assets tests and means tests they are inevitably unfair, as the system was. Of course, we knew that if we changed the system and introduced an assets test there would be great political furore. We knew it would be easily misrepresented. We knew that the sort of scare tactics we have heard from Senator Messner day after day and week after week in this place would be used. We accepted the fact that in order to do something in this area we had to do the right thing; we had to make decisions because they were right for the country and right for the people of this country and we had to cop the political flack for it. That is what we have done. That is the distinction between this Government and the Government which preceded us.

I repeat that 97.4 per cent of pensioners in this country are not concerned about the assets test at all because the assets test does not concern them. In the short time the assets test has been operating there has come to light-I am not going to list them again-a large number of cases of people who have assets, in some cases amounting to hundreds of thousands of dollars, which had not been used to produce a reasonable income but in many cases deliberately manipulated in order for them to get pensions and fringe benefits. I remember the highest level of assets which I saw involved a person who had $580,000-odd in a cheque account. That was done through ignorance and through stupidity. We had many examples-some of them drawn to our attention by members of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia-of accountants who had deliberately manipulated people's affairs so they could get into the taxation system and the social security system. Even worse, in some cases accountants themselves were the recipients of interest free loans from such pensioners so that they could then have the advantage of manipulating people's assets, and salving their consciences for doing that in some way because they knew that the people would get the pension and fringe benefits and everything would be all right.

Last time I spoke on this matter in this chamber I pointed out that at that time 12 millionaires were receiving a full pension and full fringe benefits in this country. I am told that the figure is now 34. A total of 160 people out of 31,000 had their pensions cancelled because their assets were too high and most of them cancelled themselves out. They said 'Look, we know our assets are too high. We know we should not have a pension', and they cancelled themselves out. Another 23,562 had their pensions reduced and 13,498 lost their fringe benefits. Only 2.7 per cent of pensioners were affected. It is not an issue to the vast majority. This is because of the extremely generous limits which are indexed annually. These are-I repeat again-$70,000 plus a home for a single person or $120,000 if no home is owned. For a married couple the corresponding figures are $100,000 and $150,000. To have no entitlement to a pension a person must have assets, apart from his home, of $117,250, or $179,000 if married.
