Where a home is not owned, the figures are $167,000 and $229,000 respectively. Those figures may not mean much to Senator Messner or Senator Teague, who are representatives of wealth in this country, but they are beyond the dreams of the vast majority of pensioners in this country who do not get a very large income.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are paper assets.

—Senator Messner says that they are paper assets. If they are worth that much they can be sold and produce that amount. The honourable senator knows that. We are not only talking about farmers; we are talking about wealth beyond the dreams of the average pensioner in this community. Senator Messner does not say 'We will abolish the assets test for farmers'; he says: 'We will abolish the assets test for everybody. We will let the 12 or 34 millionaires get the full pension and fringe benefit'. Senator Teague nods, indicating that that is fine.
—Because there are only 34. Just for the sake of 34 you have all that apparatus.
—It is not only for the sake of 34; it is for the sake of $150m of revenue each year.
—You are talking about millionaires.

—I am talking about $150m of revenue each year. If Senator Teague does not think that is much money, all I can say is that he has not been in a Budget Cabinet of any political party in Australia trying to make the books of this country balance. We have always said, and I have said in this place repeatedly, that the biggest and most difficult area in applying an assets test in this country is the rural area. It is not only because, in Senator Messner's words, these people own properties worth large sums of money which are only of paper value. If they are only of paper value there would not be the concern there is now, because they are of much more than paper value to the people to whom they are going to be left. They are of great sentimental and personal value to the people who are living on them and, in many cases, who have worked on them all their lives. They are of much more value to those who are waiting at the other end of the line for those farms to be passed on to them, to inherit them and get the benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about an assets test which affects only 2.7 per cent of pensioners, and which gains for the revenue of this country $150m a year-a significant amount of money. Of that 2.7 per cent, a small number of people are very difficult to fit into the assets test. That is why we said we would monitor and change it. Yet those people are allegedly the source of the debates of Senator Teague, Senator Messner and others who we hear in this place and who cause so much excitement. Why is that so? It is so, first of all, in Senator Messner's case, because he cannot help himself. As I said in Question Time, before he became a member of this place he spent his time fixing up people's books and accounts so that they could avoid tax and get pensions and things like that, and he cannot stop going on the way he is now. Secondly, those people are a politically attractive group to people such as Senator Messner and Senator Teague because those senators can get up here and tug at the heart strings in a way they cannot do about some of the other people they are trying to protect, such as those they tried to protect when they voted against the legislation which would have got into the tax evaders in this country. In that case honourable senators opposite threw away $700m of income.

It always fascinates me that honourable senators on the other side of the chamber say: 'You've got to cut the Budget; you've got to cut government expenditure; you've got to cut waste in this community'. Yet they are perfectly happy to come here and advocate wiping out $150m worth of revenue by wiping out the assets test. They vote to exclude $700m from the revenue through bottom of the harbour legislation. They do this because, in the second case, that is where the support comes from and, in the first case, one can get plenty of heart strings and plenty of bleating from the pseudo-Christian moralists who sit on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both of them are very unfair.

—What is more unfair than someone with assets worth $500,000-I pluck a figure out of the air-getting a full pension and full fringe benefits when someone with a weekly income of $100-odd, or less, loses his fringe benefits and most of his pension? Where is the justice in that situation? Where is the fairness in that situation? There is no justice or equity in that sort of situation. However, Senator Teague will always take the attitude: These things happen, but to be really fair we have to look after those people because they have acquired all of those assets, they are worth looking after, we do not want to be unjust to them, and the person with $500,000 worth of assets may wonder where his next meal is coming from. It is a strange sort of morality, I suggest--
—Do you want them to squander the assets? Do you want them to give them away?

—I do not want those people to squander their assets. I want someone who has $500,000 worth of assets to provide himself with an income from those assets which is higher than the pension. Why not ask him to do that? If he will not do that why should the ordinary taxpayer in the community-not Senator Teague and I-be propping up such a person? This is the situation which we have been trying to get over, and we have got over it. I am not going to go through the details of the changes that the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, announced on Sunday.
—They are too many.

—They are not too many; there are only six of them. I will comment about two of the things Senator Messner said here today. The hardship provisions have been increased so that people can come under consideration if they have more than $6,000 if they are single or $10,000 if they are married. Senator Messner told us that that was outrageous and unfair. We provide in this country a special benefit-it is at the same level as the pension-for people who are in great need who do not get into the system, who fall out of it as it exists now. We have provided it for years. It has been administered by Labor governments and Liberal governments. If one has more than $300 in the bank one cannot get a special benefit. I have never heard Senator Messner bleat about that-either in government or in opposition.
—Wrong end of the spectrum for him.

—Yes, it is the wrong end of the spectrum to complain about. In Queensland, that great and glorious State of Queensland, where the National Party complains about the vicious assets test, State community care services are provided. The Queensland Government provides aids for the disabled and other community care services. My colleague Senator Colston wrote to Mr Austin, the Minister for Health in Queensland, and asked what the income test was on these benefits. Mr Austin wrote back and said: 'No, we cannot tell you. We keep it a secret. If we told you people would start to manipulate their affairs so they could get the community care services'. So we found out what the test was. If one has more than $5,000 worth of assets in Queensland one does not get any services from the Queensland Government. The gist of all that is this: Everyone knows why the assets test was introduced; everyone knows that it will not affect most people; everyone knows that it will gain us $150m plus in revenue as the years go by; everyone knows that we had a system which was basically unfair and inequitable and everyone knows that what the Opposition is about is desperately casting around for something to give it some headlines. Of all the issues in this country, this seems to be the only one that Opposition members can repeatedly talk about on matters of public importance in the Senate. It may provide an interesting afternoon for some; it certainly provides an easy afternoon for some of us, but it is a pity that we are not doing something more substantial for the good of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anybody listening to Senator Messner earlier today would be forgiven for thinking that no one other than he had ever complained in the years since the Labor Government first took office about the various assets test plans that it has thrown up before us. In fact, I recall-and I am sure the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, recalls-that I confronted him in the corridor of this place the day after the original announcement was made in 1983. In fact, I followed him into his office and, with my voice raised slightly, I complained about the list of anomalies that we had come up with in a couple of hours thinking about that first announcement. These anomalies included holiday houses, lifestyle packages and all sorts of other things that would make the original test highly inequitable. It was not just the official Opposition's complaints about that 1983 package that caused the about-face by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in February of the following year; it was the combined outcry from all of us who felt that that package would significantly and inequitably affect a large section of the population.

SPEECH.PARA: Nor has it only been Senator Messner in the last few months who has raised the problems of anomalies in this assets test legislation. Again it was I and not Senator Messner who raised the problem facing some people who were living in aged persons cottages. That anomaly was raised by me in this place in the first week the Parliament sat following the election. Senator Messner does not have a monopoly of concern about people in the community who are affected by this legislation. He attempts valiantly to give that impression and in doing so he flies in the face of the fact that a large number of people in his own political party support, and have said they support, assets test legislation.

In this matter of public importance before us today Senator Messner claims that the test is harsh and inequitable. I presume that that means that he thinks that any system which applies a means test should be equitable. The previous test, of course, was not equitable; it affected only those people who were income earners. It did not affect another large section of the population. In fact, some people who are complaining about the effect of the current legislation on farmers are not being particularly equitable in their complaints either. I have a transcript of an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program which interviewed a number of farmers. One farmer complained that he and his wife had retired to the coast on the proceeds of a cashed in insurance policy but they have now lost their only source of income, namely, the pension, because they still own several hundred acres of land on which their son and daughter-in-law live. I remind honourable senators that this applies equally to people who retire to the coast but who have a family home in the city, even if that home is lived in by members of the family. It also applies in reverse if they live in a home in the city and have a holiday home on the coast that they let some member of their family live in. So if we are talking about equity we ought to talk about equity right across the range and not limit it just to people in rural areas.

Senator Grimes pointed out in his speech that there is a strange form of schizophrenia operating in Senator Messner's mind with regard to who should and should not have access to certain information about people in this country. As he pointed out, it is apparently all right, as far as members of the Liberal Party of Australia are concerned, that people should have to declare their income, but it becomes strangely wrong when they have to declare details of their assets. I have memories, as I am sure many people in the community do, of the way in which officers of the Department of Social Security behaved under the previous Liberal Government over the cohabitation rule that then applied. It was fondly known around the traps as the size 10 thong and bed sniffing brigade, which may not have been a very delicate way of putting it but which was accurate enough. It describes exactly what the purpose of visits to people on pensions and benefits was all about.

Following Senator Walters's comments last night, Senator Messner took an opportunity to have a swipe at Senator Macklin, who deliberately and quite clearly abstained from voting when the first assets test legislation was brought before us. He did so in honouring a pledge to the pensioners of Queensland that he would not support the legislation. Indeed, in abstaining he did not support the legislation. Any other criticism is pure sophistry but it pales into insignificance when we consider the number of occasions on which Liberal members and senators have cried buckets of blood over the damage a piece of legislation is likely to do to the community and then voted for it.

I remind the Senate that on 10 separate occasions this year the Liberal Opposition cuddled up with the Australian Labor Party Government in support of legislation which was demonstrably damaging to people that it classifies as its constituents. A number of primary industry levy Bills last year, the wine sales tax legislation, superannuation legislation and tax changes were all cried out against by Liberal members and senators but voted for when the Australian Democrats called for divisions. What happened? We were then accused of grandstanding. It seems to me that grandstanding is defined according to the number of people who do it. If only six, seven or eight do it, it is grandstanding, but if 30 do it, it is a matter of deep principle.

The Liberals may believe that but I can tell them, from the telegrams that we have received today over their appalling behaviour last night in relation to the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, that their little bit of grandstanding has gone down very badly indeed with the veterans in this community, many of whom, I remind honourable senators, live in rural areas. They are soldier settlers. They have been disowned by the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia, which colluded quite clearly with the Labor Government yesterday, after trying to do it last Thursday night, and sold those veterans down the drain by voting to bring into operation the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, which will have a dramatic and possibly tragic effect on many veterans in this country, some of whom, I repeat, are soldier settlers, the very farmers that Senator Messner is allegedly concerned for in the matter before us today. Of course, these soldier settlers again may be on the wrong end of the economic spectrum. Perhaps it is only the farmers who own very large tracts of land and who have been caught by this assets test, who complain that they were not allowed to rearrange their assets in order to get out of the effects of this legislation, that Senator Messner is concerned about.

The Government, under pressure from senators and members not only from the Australian Democrats and the Liberal and National parties but also from within its own ranks, has been forced to alter the manner in which it administers the assets test. It has altered only the manner in which it administers the test. There is no legislative requirement here; it is purely a matter, as we have said all along, of administrative determination. In doing so the Government has made some quite significant changes which will correct or mitigate most of the problems facing people on farms. According to the Australian, the seven-point plan has made administrative changes in five main areas-the pensions loans scheme, the transfer of assets, the hardship provisions, the appeals review process and accommodation for the aged, the last of which does not seem to have made it into Senator Messner's motion.

Among the changes, interest under the pension loans scheme, which allows people to receive pensions which are later repaid, has been reduced from 13 per cent to 10 per cent. The loans scheme will also be available for income support during periods of financial readjustment due to the assets test. The new arrangements include doubling the amount of available funds a pensioner might have and still be considered to be in hardship. Furthermore, the Department of Social Security will accept that a pensioner will not have to sell a farm or large building block if he or she has lived on the property or has been a farmer for 20 years. If a close relative has been working the property for 10 years and relies on it for a living the Department will accept that the pensioner could not sell the property. Farm transfer provisions have been changed so that where a pensioner farmer has legally transferred a property to a close relative the value of the relative's contribution, such as forgone wages, will be deducted from the property value. Finally, the income that could be expected from leasing a property is expected to be halved to 2 1/2 per cent of the property value, without taking into account the house and home paddock.

The Liberals have come in here today showing unmitigated gall in carping even further about this matter. Clearly, they do not care that their demented attempts to return to the old income-only system would cost Consolidated Revenue at least $100m a year and at the same time return us to a highly selective, inequitable and anomalous income-only test. I am tired of the double standards applied by members of the Opposition, on the one hand refusing to join us in voting against things such as the wine sales tax legislation, Bills to increase primary industry levies and the repatriation legislation because, they say, they are money or Budget Bills and therefore somehow sacrosanct, while on the other hand being prepared to make political capital when the Government tries to save $100m by introducing equity into pension eligibility. Their behaviour is pathetic and does no credit to the Parliament. Indeed, I suggest that behaviour such as we have seen from the Opposition in the past few months brings the tone of this place to an all time low. Anybody who wants to check the statistics on when the Liberals have voted with the Government in the last year or so should do so, because it is an extremely interesting exercise. It is almost as interesting as the spectacle that we were treated to on AM this morning and again on the 11 AM program with Senator Grimes and Senator Chaney doing a tweedledum and tweedledee act about the repatriation legislation, jointly holding the knife that has stabbed hundreds of veterans in the back. It was a nauseating display and I hope that we do not have to see too much more of it.

The Opposition talks about cosmetic changes to the assets test. I wonder, then, what Opposition senators call what they did yesterday in colluding with the Government over the repatriation legislation. There is nothing more cosmetic than the attempt they made yesterday to postpone until the Budget session further discussion on that legislation. I ask them now: What will they do when the repatriation legislation is finalised, when the sunset provision runs out? Will they introduce another of their useless repeal Bills in this place and then try to convince the veterans, as they have tried to convince farmers, that somehow repealing the legislation in the Senate would make the Act inoperative? I am not quite sure that they have even thought that far ahead, or whether they have thought of it at all.

For a group of people who constantly complain about Australian Democrats grandstanding, they have not done too badly in the last little while in doing a bit of that themselves. I think it is about time they realised that all elected members of parliament have a responsibility to the people who elect them. Either we sit back in this place and allow the Government to do as it chooses, treating money Bills differently from anything else, or we treat all legislation the same-look at it and the way it impacts on various sections of the community and act accordingly.

It seems to me that at the moment we have an official Clayton's Opposition. It picks and chooses the areas in which it will oppose. It suffers from terminal double standards, and it has failed to confront in this particular issue the question whether we have a pensions eligibility means test or whether we do not. Personally, like a lot of people, including some members of the Liberal Party, I presume, I would prefer that we did not have any sort of means test. If we are not prepared to confront the fact that means tests ought not to operate, and if we are not prepared to come to terms with the need for a national portable, contributory superannuation scheme, we must also accept that, in having a means test at all, it must be as equitable and as anomaly-free as possible and not simply affect one group in the community-namely, income earners-while letting massive asset holders off scot-free.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Messner's matter of public importance. I believe that the changes to the assets test that have been effected by the Government are no more than cosmetic changes. The mark 4 version of the assets test was supposed to have saved about $96.8m in its first full year of running. The present mark 5 assets test is expected to save $80m per year. It seems to me quite incredible that the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, talked about having to penalise the rich for a miserable 75c a week per pensioner, which is what is represented in the cosmetic changes that have taken place as a result of pressure that has been exerted relentlessly by Senator Messner and the Opposition since this iniquitous matter was embarked upon by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite amusing for me to listen to Senator Haines, who voted for the assets test. Listening to her, one would almost think that she is trying to model herself on Senator Ryan. I recall that not long ago Senator Walters drew attention to a reply from Senator Haines to a pensioner, in which she said:
Those anomalies which exist in this assets test are limited to people in aged cottages and people on unproductive land.

The Australian Democrats constantly display irresponsibility with respect to the monetary measures we discuss in the Senate. They came into this Parliament with the proud boast that they would never reject Supply. Yet repeatedly the Democrats vote against parts of the Government's Budget and claim that they are not voting against Supply. When one adds up the niggling little measures that the Democrats have supported here and there in a desperate attempt to please sectional interests in the public, to curry favour, while desperately thrashing around trying to get the votes that that Party needs in order to survive, it makes one wonder just what credibility it has.

There was another party in the Parliament called the Democratic Labour Party. It had some good policies. They were attractive and that Party made them attractive, well knowing that it would never govern. The same will happen to the Australian Democrats, but they do not have any good policies. Half the time they cannot decide among themselves what course of action to take. They come into the Senate and berate Senator Messner, who, together with other members of the Liberal-National Party Opposition, has been trying desperately to persuade the Government of its errors. There is some evidence of success in the Government's latest, although miserable, attempt to change the assets test. Headlines of an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 27 May suggest that the National Farmers Federation believes that the assets test switch is not enough. The article states:
The National Farmers Federation yesterday criticised the latest changes to the controversial assets test for failing to remove the discrimination against pensioner farmers.

When we look at the rural situation at the moment-the average income is about $9,000 a year-by no stretch of the imagination can we regard the farming community as being wealthy, although, over the years, the Australian Labor Party has traditionally regarded the landed gentry, as it habitually calls the farming community, as being wealthy people. They certainly contribute a lot to our export income, but by no means can it be suggested that the average farmer in Australia is a wealthy person. A pensioner, living in the Adelaide hills, made representations to me not long ago. He was invalided out of work and is on a pension. He lives in a comfortable but humble home on a two-acre block of land. His block was valued at something like $65,000. That is unproductive land. There is no way that he can get any assets from it because the local government authority's developmental by-laws state that he is not able to cut that land up and sell it off. So he was penalised for living on that block.
The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), in a Press statement in support of Senator Messner, drew attention to anomalies which still remain. He cited the following examples and said:
. . . the changes do not:

Remove the anomaly between the pensioner who lives in the country and the city. Both may own property and have assets of equal value, but the country-dweller loses the pension and the city-dweller keeps it.
The second point he made was that the changes do not:
Resolve the problem of those who lose their spouse and then get re-classified under the Assets Test, forcing them to perhaps sell some of their property.
He also pointed out that the changes do not:
Resolve the problems of those who have bought land, which is now highly valued, often on city fringes, but which is not income-earning.
Address itself to those people who have been deprived of part of their pensions because they pursue hobbies which are imputed to be 'valuable' under the Test.
Resolve the discrimination against pensioners who rent their homes.
Or resolve the discrimination against those who because of illness are forced to sell their homes, but choose to live in 'granny flats' with their families, rather than entering nursing homes.

Those are a few of the examples caused by the erratic and arbitrary nature of the assets test introduced by this Government. The test, said Mr Peacock in a Press release on 27 May, is 'full of illogicalities'. He said that these included treating 20 years as a magical figure for the period a person has to live in a farm residence, making the process of valuation implementation and administration of the hardship provisions even more difficult. He continued:

This approach will put more power into the hands of administrators, while creating a tangle of conflicting judgments as to how to assess individual cases. At the same time, after no less than five changes to the assets test, pensioners are going to find it harder than ever to understand where they stand under the assets test guidelines. This can only create more confusion and anxiety.

Senator Messner has already stated that the Government will have to come up with $1 billion to fulfil its election promise to raise the pension to a quarter average weekly wage. The Government will have to turn elsewhere to make up this difference.

I return to the rather ludicrous argument used by Senator Grimes earlier in the debate when he referred to the poor pensioners and how they are being robbed by the rich pensioners. Yet they stand to gain less than 75c a week-the price of a can of beer or a small bottle of coke. That is all that the so-called poor pensioners, with whom we all sympathise, will receive as a result of the Government changes in the assets test. Another Press comment made on 27 May suggested that the new package does not go far enough. This seems to me to be very significant. Under the headline 'Changes a small step, say the farmers', the article states:
The asset test changes were only a small step in the right direction, according to the Victorian Farmers and Graziers Association.
The Association's senior vice-president, Mr Frank Drum, said:
. . . rural pensioners affected by the test would still get only half the income that city pensioners received.
The article continues:
Mr Drum said many farmer-pensioners were in a 'dreadful position' because they could not make money with their assets.
'The fact is that $250,000 in assets in agriculture won't make you a living', Mr Drum said.
He said many of the rural pensioners affected by the assets test had farms valued at around $90,000 that were in poor, hilly or uncommercial areas.
I am not sure, but I think I remember Senator Haines talking about living on unproductive land.

TALK.START.PARA: —She said that was the only problem.
—That the only problem was people living on unproductive land; I think that is an incredible attitude for a Democrat to take. Mr Peacock in his Press release went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: One group particularly affected will be those who have already been forced to sell their property or who are half-way through the legal process of doing so because of the changes that have been made.

One asks: What happens to those people? The birth of the assets test, mark 5, which is what we are now criticising, is destined to be as painful, as unfair and as confusing as the previous four miserable attempts at the test by the Labor Government. Mr Peacock went on to point out that it is outrageous now that a few Labor back benchers, who failed to vote against the original test and who again failed to vote for the Opposition's Bill to abolish it, should declare themselves content with this latest fiasco that we are criticising today. Mr Peacock went on to say:
Assets Test, Mark V, which gives even more power to the administrators, is bound to be even more intrusive and more costly to implement than any of the other previous attempts.
The changes will further reduce Mr Howe's so-called savings from the Test and boost his army of interfering anomaly jugglers . . .

I gather that initially the Department of Social Security had to employ something like 1,500 people to supervise this assets test and I believe that the Department of Veterans' Affairs had to employ between 300 and 500 additional public servants to police the assets test. Of course, this is typical of a Labor Party government. This Government does not believe in reducing public expenditure by keeping the Public Service under some sort of control. The Liberal-National Party Government tried to do that. We kept a ceiling on Public Service staff levels, but not this Government. This Government has had to employ an additional 2,000 public servants, on very high incomes, to deal with the assets test for a miserable contribution of 75c a week to the pensioners of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which they haven't given yet either.

—Which this Government has not given the pensioners yet. I would be very surprised if this Government does anything more for the pensioners. Its promise to raise pensions to 25 per cent of the average weekly wage is a pipe-dream when we have regard to the economic chaos that is taking place in Australia today due to this Government's mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that not only honourable senators in this chamber but also most people are heartily sick and tired of the debate about the assets test. But members of the Opposition keep stirring about it with matter of public importance debate after matter of public importance debate, somehow thinking that it assists them politically to advertise their policy of wanting to perpetuate the inequity that existed between 1976 and 1984-those seven or eight years when there was not an assets test, not a full means test but only an incomes test. I think it is generally acknowledged that the inclusion of assets in determining and assessing people's means is entirely justified because of the way in which the income test was being manipulated by people.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter of public importance debate, brought on by Senator Messner, is the Opposition's reaction to the announcement of the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, on Sunday modifying some aspects of the administration of the assets test. First, let me remind the Opposition that the Government has said all along that the reintroduction of the assets test would be monitored, that there would be a constant review of its administration, the way in which it was affecting people and the way it was working. That review has produced these modifications and that review will continue.

Members of the Opposition have tried to claim that somehow this is some completely new creation that they are calling the assets test mark 5. Of course, they have said that they would prefer that no changes were made, but the proposed changes are not as major as they have suggested. I acknowledge that these changes are not major but they could by no means be described as cosmetic as the Opposition described them in the wording of its matter of public importance. If these changes were cosmetic no one would benefit. In fact, a substantial number of people will benefit. They will keep their pension or they will not lose as much of their pension as they would otherwise have done. Primarily, it is just those people who are affected by the scheme because of the assets that they have who are in the categories identified as needing particular attention-for example, the people in rural areas. The changes that are being made will make the test even more reasonable than it was. The Government is bending over backwards to be fair about this matter. It is ludicrous for Senator Messner and Senator Jessop to suggest that the assets test is either harsh or equitable. The Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, covered that aspect well and I will not go over the points he made. There is clear justification for the need for an assets test. Even the Hobart Mercury-not a wild Labor sympathiser-made the following comment in a recent editorial, which is worth quoting:

There is widespread acknowledgement among all political parties that measures must be taken to bring greater equity to the welfare system and to contain its growth. There has been a sense of urgency about restructuring the system of old-age pensions as government is confronted with the difficult situation of an increasingly ageing population and the necessity to lift pension payments. In this context, the principle of an assets test, to enable the government to concentrate its resources on those most in need, should not be objected to. An incomes test alone is insufficient measure of need as it offers the temptation to convert income into assets and thereby claim benefits.

I point out that the Hobart Mercury seems to be under the impression that it is only age pensioners who will be affected. That is not so, and that is only fair. Senator Messner talked about the mess and confusion that had been created over this whole issue. The Opposition has helped to create the confusion in this whole matter by misrepresenting the provisions of the test. Senator Messner referred to the 1983 proposal and how 'their pressure' had altered. I was happy with the proposal at that time. I was pleased to go out and defend it; it was quite a reasonable proposal. But the test as implemented earlier this year is in fact very generous; even more generous than the reasonable test which was proposed originally. The recent modifications announced by Brian Howe make it even more so.

The point has been made by the Opposition and by others that there is an unfairness to people in rural areas who have large holdings, compared with people in the city with expensive family homes. I can see that point, but if the Government had implemented an assets test without exempting the family home, I can just imagine the outcry there would have been from the Opposition, affected pensioners and the Melbourne Herald in particular, which has been carrying on a campaign about the sanctity of the family home being affected. The family home is not counted in the assets test, so there has been much objection from people in rural areas about the claimed relative unfairness to them, compared with city people who have expensive houses; hence some of the changes that have been made in the administration.

I make the point that no one is forced to sell his or her assets. The hardship provision and the loans scheme mean that no one is forced to sell his or her assets. This is the sort of phrase the Opposition has been using all the time-that these people are forced to sell assets. That is not so. They have the option of coming under the pension loans scheme, if that is their wish, or the hardship provisions which will ensure that no one is badly done by.

The various changes that have been made to the administration are as follows: Firstly, the interest rate for the pension loans scheme has been altered. The interest rate was 13 1/2 per cent compound interest, the going rate in the market place, which meant that people could make a neutral decision about whether they entered into that scheme, or disposed of assets. That rate has been changed to 10 per cent simple interest-that is, the interest does not accumulate-so now there is actually an incentive for people to use the loans scheme. The provision will remain that at least $100,000 will be left after recovery. So it is not as if every last cent of a person's estate will be lost if the pensioner opts for the loans scheme. I think that it is very reasonable for people to opt for this scheme. This proposal encourages them to do so. It does not just leave it as a neutral economic decision for them to make. It will make it quite attractive to those with even sizable non-liquid assets who need income support and will reduce the repayments of pensioner loans for surviving relatives.

Secondly, the hardship provisions are to be relaxed. The limit of available funds a pensioner may have and be counted, taking into account severe hardship, has been doubled to $6,000 for a single pensioner and $10,000 for a married couple. I emphasise that these are liquid assets, not total assets. They are the assets which pensioners are able to put their hands on. A major criticism of the test has come from people with liquid funds of a little over the $3,000 and $5,000 that did apply. Hence the Government has seen fit to liberalise these provisions, not by a major amount; it is not by an amount of tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars because to do that would be to alter the whole principle of the assets test. But it will make a decisive difference to those who are on the edge of entitlement; that is, the most deserving ones.

The next aspect of the changes involves those who have lived on a property and farmed that property for at least 20 years or-for Senator Messner's information as he claimed that there was not such a statement-a person who has been a farmer for more than 20 years, even if not on that property. At the same time the deeming provision will be cut in half to 2 1/2 per cent of the value of the property. The term 'living on a property' means that if a close relative has been working the property for 10 years or more and relies on it for a living the Department of Social Security will again accept that the pensioner cannot be expected to sell. It was always the Government's intention that there be a concession along these lines. This has not been given a great deal of prominence nor put into practice until now. On the basis of the experience of the last few months this is being made a clear criterion for the test. This change will be of special benefit to farmers. It is not a cosmetic change, but rather a compassionate response to people's attachment to their properties and to the needs of those with children who have worked on those properties.

Where a pensioner farmer transfers property to a close relative the Department of Social Security will accept that the value of the contribution by that relative through, for instance, forgone wages should be deducted from the value of that property transfer. This change will take account of the traditional practices of those in rural areas where farms are worked and then transferred from one generation to the next. It ensures that the relative's contributions to the pensioner's property are recognised. I happen to think that people ought to adjust their affairs over the years to take into account these contributions, but this proposal ensures that even if they do not do that those contributions are recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will it be calculated?

—In answer to Senator Messner's interjection, the amount will be equal to the current value of the wages lost. Under the deeming provisions, any income a pensioner could reasonably be expected to get from leasing a property will continue to be taken into account as deemed income, but the amount has been cut in half to 2 1/2 per cent of the value of the property. So once again there is an incentive to ensure that leasing is possible. If pensioners can show that they could receive less than this 2 1/2 per cent, the lower amount will be taken into account. This will more accurately reflect levels of property leases and will assist many needy pensioner farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: Valuations, reviews and appeals will be speeded up, as announced by Mr Howe, to ensure that any uncertainty is dispelled as soon as possible. Of course, there have been worries and concerns by affected pensioners about some of the valuations with which they disagree. Now they can have a free on-site valuation by the Australian Taxation Office within eight weeks. Appeals through the Social Security Appeals Tribunal are to be hurried along.

The final part of the package of changes in administration involves pensioners in aged persons homes. These people who have contributed a lump sum or made a donation or loan to secure accommodation have until now been regarded as home owners and therefore were subject to a lower threshold. Under the new arrangements only those who have bought an interest or right to accommodation which can be sold or redeemed will be regarded as home owners. Others who make a loan to such an aged persons home will be regarded as non-home owners and thus will receive the benefit of the extra $50,000 asset exemption. Obviously, this change will remove an anomaly and make a significant difference to the pension entitlements of the bulk of residents affected by the previous provisions. That change can in no way be described as cosmetic.

These changes will resolve many of the problems identified with the assets test, especially those affecting rural areas. We are not pretending that they are major changes to the scheme because we believe in the principle involved and do not intend to back off from that principle. But they are designed to assist those most deserving people who have been affected by the assets test. They remove a few of the anomalous provisions identified in the early stages. They will make a decisive difference to those on the edge of entitlement or those few pensioners who have been unfairly affected by a strict legalistic interpretation of the assets test. As stated right from the very beginning, the Government will continue to monitor the assets test to ensure that it continues to fulfil its goal of directing assistance to those most in need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Messner's matter of public importance this afternoon on the failure of the Government to make other than cosmetic changes to its harsh and inequitable pensions assets test. That description is just the way I see it. Over the last couple of years we have witnessed widespread confusion and concern amongst pensioners and beneficiaries at the intrusiveness of and the many unfair aspects and numerous anomalies contained in the assets test legislation. While many anomalies have been exposed, none has yet been corrected by this Government. The long and sorry history of this legislation indicates that the Government has continually refused or failed to act unless pushed to the limit. Obviously this afternoon in Question Time the Minister for Community Services, Senator Grimes, must have been pushed to the limit because he appeared very confused and worried. In reply to a question from Senator Messner about pensions, he implied that because only a few people were disadvantaged it really was not a problem. Obviously, the Government has shown again its scant regard for aged people.

SPEECH.PARA: The National and Liberal parties are opposed to the assets test in principle because it is designed to encourage people to become more dependent on government by discouraging them from accumulating assets in order to provide as much as possible for themselves. The Labor Government's assets test will not catch the really rich whom it claims are taking unfair advantage of the pension system. On the contrary it is the person who has, through thrift, modest enterprise, and in some cases involuntarily, built up moderate levels of savings who is more affected. The Government allows pensioners who swim as a recreation to have a swimming pool and this is not considered as an asset. On the other hand, pensioners who want to fish may not own a small boat because the Hawke Government decrees that a boat is an asset. A pensioner couple may sell both their home and weekender and buy a luxury home. That is not considered an asset, but they are denied the right to opt for a modest home and retain their weekender as an economic way of holidaying. A car is considered a luxury asset. Stamp and coin collections are considered assets.

Pensioners are unable to cope with the rate of change or with the details and technicalities of the assets test, and are having trouble all the time with it. This Government is having trouble understanding the implications of the assets test, which has been intrusive, inequitable, unfair, costly and complex to impose. The assets test has penalised those people who have worked hard during their working lives to put away a nest-egg for their retirement. The savings in the pensions budget of some $8 billion is minimal when taking into account the heartbreak it has caused. The assets test has effectively imposed a gift and death duty on pensioners. Senator Coates said a while ago that he believes in death duties by default.

Again there has been an attack by the Hawke Labor Government against country people and the small family farm which those on the other side of the House probably would not know about because they seem to live under the wing of the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the confines of the jungle of the cities. As I have said before in this place, we should give encouragement and incentives for people to save for their retirement, but the Hawke Labor Government really is kicking in the teeth those who have pursued that course. I quote from the editorial in the Australian on 27 May:

Mr Howe's announcement of changes in the way the assets test will be applied may limit the damage which the ALP has done to itself by introducing a test. Combined with its tax on lump-sum superannuation and, far more importantly, with its abiding fascination for capital gains taxes and death duties, the assets test has created for the Government an unenviable reputation. For an increasing number of Australians, the Hawke Government appears indifferent, and even hostile, to the efforts they have made to establish their financial security. To make matters worse, these people are being prepared by the Government for an era of high indirect taxes which will further whittle away the resources of those on fixed incomes.

Labor back benchers, particularly those in marginal rural seats, are worried about the electoral consequences of the assets test. Well might they be worried about it. Do not spare too many thoughts for them, however. We should spare the sympathy and the concern for the people that the assets test affects. I will quote again from the Australian of 27 May, which states that Mr McMullan, the National Secretary of the Labor Party, said that the assets test was:
. . . contributing to a perception of the Government being anti old people.
For once the Labor Party is right in its perception. The article continued:
One MP--
obviously a member of the same Party-
said the 50,000 pensioners affected by the test hardly constituted a threat.
Those are unfeeling words which do not show much compassion. I will read from a letter which I received recently from a constituent:

I enclose a copy of a letter I wrote to the Department of Social Security when we received notification that our age pension ceased with the introduction of the assets test on 21 March. Some months ago, under great moral protest on our part we completed and sent in the iniquitous assets test form-if ever there was an invasion of privacy, that form was a perfect example. Not a word was heard until 8 March when the verdict came that our last pension cheques were paid the previous day. The guillotine seems gentle by comparison. Later we received notice to surrender our pharmaceutical benefits cards. The reply to my letter was merely a pamphlet 'Hardship Provisions of the Assets Test' and the advice 'If you feel you qualify . . . lodge a claim for payment by advising this office in writing'. The conditions as set down are ridiculous. Do they really expect us to mortgage our farm at our age! We'll battle on as we've done all our lives but it means that we will draw on our savings more and more. Let's hope they last the distance! Would you please add our protest to the many others you have surely received.
I received a copy of another letter which the same lady had written to the regional office. It stated:
I accept your letter but only with the strongest possible protest against the inequitable assets test. To say the least it discriminates against rural people.

My husband and I own a small farm 450 acres. I will be 74 years of age in May and my husband is 80. He had serious major surgery in 1983 and 2 hip replacements in 1984. A victim of arthritis as well as circulation and embolism problems, his ability to work is now very limited. Our home is a very old weatherboard house, badly in need of repair, as are fences, sheds and yards.

Our son, a motor mechanic in a local garage, helps as much as he can. We are certainly not in the position to employ labour. 15 years ago we were confident that we would be able to support ourselves in our old age, but the spiral of costs triggered by the Whitlam Government in 1972 has changed all that. With income greatly diminished and certainly harder to acquire, costs are still soaring: Shire rates, road rental licences, insurances, telephone rental, electricity standing charge etc. All these and more must be met before we start to live: To eat, clothe ourselves, buy a newspaper, post a letter.

I ask you-are we being penalised for choosing to spend our remaining few years on a property that has been home for 40 years? Are we being penalised for having worked hard all our lives to provide for a worry free retirement?
As I see it, the answer in both instances is yes.

That letter quite moved me and I hope that it moves some people on the other side of the chamber. Will the changes announced at the weekend help these true blue people? I do not believe they will, but they should. The Government introduced the assets test changes and it has caused the hardship and heartbreak. The assets test changes announced over the weekend do not remove the anomaly which exists between a pensioner who lives in the country and one who lives in the city. Both own property and have assets of equal value, but the country dweller will lose the pension and the city dweller will keep it. I will quote examples that have been quoted numerous times. A pensioner in a town or city with a house worth $200,000 and $50,000 in other assets will get 100 per cent of the pension. A farmer on a small farm worth some $200,000 where he has lived for years and years, as in the case in the letter I have just quoted, and who probably has $50,000 in other assets, will get no pension. Is that fair or is it another case of discrimination by the Hawke Labor Government against country people and against country pensioners in particular?

The assets test changes do not remove or resolve the problem of those who lose their spouses, are reclassified under the provisions of the assets test, and then are forced perhaps to sell some of their property. The assets test changes announced last weekend-the assets test mark 4, mark 5 or whatever-will not resolve the problems of those who have bought land which is now highly valued. This land is often on city fringes-for example, around Dural in Sydney-but is not earning these people income. The changes announced on the weekend do not address those people who have been deprived of part of their pensions because they pursue hobbies which are imputed to be valuable under the provisions of the assets test. They do not resolve the discrimination against pensioners who rent their homes. The assets test changes do not resolve the discrimination against those who, because of illness, are forced to sell their homes but choose to live in granny flats with their families rather than enter nursing homes. Nothing has been done to overcome the hardships created by the assets test. I conclude by quoting again from the last two paragraphs of the letter I received:

I ask you-are we being penalised for choosing to spend our remaining few years on a property that has been home for 40 years? Are we being penalised for having worked hard all our lives to provide for a worry-free retirement?
As I see it, the answer in both instances is yes.
It is time that the thinking members of the Government showed some compassion and understanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be doing less than my duty if I left unaddressed the last statement of Senator Brownhill. This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance entitled:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to make other than cosmetic changes to its harsh and inequitable pensions assets test.

They are the words of the Opposition which proposed this matter of public importance. In response to Senator Brownhill, might I say that it is because we are deeply concerned for pensioners of every sort-the aged, the invalids and the poverty-stricken young families-that we have taken this extremely difficult step and introduced an assets test. We take a highly responsible approach to the whole question, unlike the previous Government which talked and talked about the possibility of a needs-based approach to pensions but which never produced any of the goods.

If the recently announced changes to the assets test are a cosmetic range of changes-I remind honourable senators that the assets test was fully introduced in only March of this year-might I ask, cosmetic to whom? It certainly has targeted the groups who have been shown to be at a disadvantage. They include certain rural pensioners those who have opted for the loans scheme in association with the assets test, those whose circumstances are so anomalous that they claim hardship and those who have made a donation in order to enter an aged persons home or hostel, yet who have no interest or right to accommodation which is salable or redeemable. These are the groups of individuals whose plight has been drawn to the attention of the Government. I might add that we have dealt with these problems very swiftly indeed. There is some inconsistency, one would have thought, in labelling these changes as cosmetic and then proposing a matter of public importance to occupy two hours of the Senate's time just when there seems to be inter-party agreement that we should not waste these hours but should deal expeditiously with the legislation on the Notice Paper instead of re-hashing something which has been dealt with seven times at great length and with enormous tedium in this place.

We do not know how many people are likely to be affected by the recent changes to the assets test, or what the cost will be. We do not know this because, of the 28,844 individuals whose pensions had been cancelled by mid-April, 18,751, or 65 per cent of pensioners cancelled their pensions themselves. Therefore, the Department of Social Security has no details of their financial circumstances. Among them there may certainly be some individuals whose problems are covered by the more recent changes. However, information is available on the 10,093 individuals, that is, the 35 per cent, whose pensions were cancelled on assessment by the Department of Social Security. If this income distribution is extrapolated to those who self-cancelled-and this is an extremely conservative assumption to make-763 of the total number of previous pensioners held assets of $500,000 or more. I know that the Opposition has quaint ideas about what constitutes deprivation, but was it those who were down to their last half a million dollars who were the subject of all of the crocodile tears we have seen since the Labor Government took the hard decision and introduced an assets test?

What does the Opposition have in mind? Does it intend to eliminate all means testing for pensions? If it does, it is about time it said so. That would hardly accord with the widely reported comments by all prominent spokesmen of the coalition, especially when it was in government. References to the truly needy and the essential nature of a needs directed pension system were falling like autumn leaves when I first came to this Senate in 1981 and they were falling like autumn leaves in the House of Representatives at the same time. No matter how closely we questioned the coalition's intentions, there was never any more than these pious statements of intent.
As recently as 1983 Mr Howard told us that he was personally in favour of a needs approach to the payment of welfare, and I quote:
It is time for us all to recognise that the real issue is not whether we should have an assets test, but what is the fairest and best form of the assets test.

We have had no contribution from the Opposition to assist us to develop the fairest and best form of assets test. In the absence of anything constructive from the Opposition-we have been waiting for four years to hear how it should be done-I must agree with Professor Gruen, who said:
Those who argue for smaller government and needs based welfare, whilst rejecting concrete administrative moves in that direction, deserve to be regarded as supremely opportunistic cynics.

Despite these recent adjustments which are of considerable significance to small numbers of deserving people, mostly in rural areas, there is no major backdown by the Government on its assets test and the test continues to qualify for the approbation of many diverse organisations. The Secretary of the Australian Council on the Ageing was glad to acknowledge that the figures vindicated the Council's support for the assets test since it was proposed in 1983. The Secretary was particularly pleased, of course, that:
. . . the order of savings in expenditure should enable the Government to keep faith with the poorest pensioners who rely on the pension payment as their sole income.
The Confederation of Australian Industry, a strange bedfellow for the Australian Labor Party, was quoted as giving support:
. . . in principle to the Government for tackling this unavoidable and increasingly urgent issue.
The Business Council of Australia was quite happy to acknowledge that:
. . . the Government deserves support for attempting to tackle this politically difficult problem now.
It is a politically difficult problem that the previous Government managed to avoid very successfully for a very long time. The Australian Financial Review of 6 May this year acknowledged:
While it would seem self evident that it is senseless to pay benefits to the comparatively wealthy, this message is hard to convey.

It is not particularly hard to convey to that 97 per cent of pensioners who are simply not affected by the assets test. It must, I admit, be acknowledged that it is hard to convey to some of those opportunistic cynics on the other side of this House who, in the words of the Australian Financial Review, have waged a 'campaign of stupid denigration of the assets tax on pensioners'.

This Government should be congratulated on its swift and sensitive response in modifying the assets test to accommodate the needs of small groups as identified by the Department of Social Security and by alert and responsible parliamentarians from both sides of the House and from both Houses amongst whom many have been involved in drafting the changes. Details of the changes have been discussed by my colleagues several times in the course of this debate so I will not list them again. However, the Department of Social Security has prepared three new booklets dated May 1985 to distinguish them from those prepared in February of this year. Those booklets are entitled: 'A summary of the assets test', 'The Pension Loans Scheme-How does it work?' and 'Hardship Provisions of the assets test'. They are clear and concise descriptions of the changes that are now about to be implemented. These booklets are now available from all regional offices of the Department. For those people who do not have access to regional offices, I suggest that they try the offices of their Federal members or senators. In winding up this debate I stress that 97 per cent of aged Australians are not at all affected by the assets test, and for those who are these recent measures should iron out apparent anomalies. Let us have no more of this supremely opportunistic cynicism from those who were not prepared to grasp the nettle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to use a few moments of the Senate's time available in this debate because for the last several weeks and, in particular, this week I have been the butt of a number of vitriolic attacks by honourable members who seem to feel that this is the way to carry on debates in the Senate. It occurred today when this matter of great public importance should have been the subject of debate. However, instead Senator Jessop followed the lead of Senator Walsh at Question Time today in setting out on a vendetta against the Australian Democrats and against me. I want to set the record quite straight: The accusation against the Australian Democrats is that we base our moves in the Senate chamber and our decisions on our endeavours to appeal to minority groups. I believe that our decision on this assets test-
—Order! Senator Evans, would you relate your speech to the matter before the Chair?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I was in the process of doing so when you called my attention to it. Our approach to the assets test and the Government's amendments to the assets test has been in an endeavour to help the minority groups in this country. It is about time that these minority groups were represented in the Senate. It is because of the Government's position and, incredibly, the Opposition's position that there is only one economic criterion in this country, which is the deficit; the deficit has to be reduced, no matter who gets hurt. That is why minority groups in this country are having to suffer. It is because of that pressure on the Government over the assets test that changes have been made to the test.

SPEECH.PARA: I am very proud to represent the people who would not otherwise be represented in this Parliament by the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia or the National Party of Australia. These are minority groups. Mr Acting Deputy President, I make it quite clear in responding to an earlier part of this debate, which was allowed, and which consisted of attacks for 10 minutes on the Australian Democrats for representing these groups, that it is appropriate that there be a political party in the Senate to represent those groups. I represent them very proudly, as I did earlier this week in representing the returned service people who were left in the lurch by both the Labor Party and the Liberal-National Party Opposition. Consistently, with my colleagues I have represented the farmers who, again, are subject to this assets test amendment. I make it quite clear once more that ethnic communities who have no other representative party in this Parliament-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Evans, the matter before the Chair is: The failure of the Government to make other than cosmetic changes to its harsh and inequitable pensions assets test. It is not a debate of your personal views. You are speaking either for or against the proposal.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am speaking about the matter of public importance. Is that in order?
—You must make your remarks relevant to the matter before the Chair.

—I am doing so. I repeat that the people who have been hurt by these changes to the assets test have been those to whom I have just been referring-those people who have no other representation in this Parliament and whose pleas are conveyed to this Parliament, in this debate and in other debates on the assets test, by the Australian Democrats. This debate comes about simply because no alternative approach to the assets test proposals has been put forward by either the Liberal Party or the Government.
—We would abolish the darn thing.

—Yes. Senator Jessop tells the people that if ever he is re-elected to government he will abolish the assets test, just as during a previous election campaign he promised his electors that Medibank would not be touched and he then did absolutely nothing about it. We keep on hearing from Senator Jessop of what will be his future endeavours to influence the future government, of which he presumes he will not be a member but simply a back bencher. He says that he will plead with it to do something about the assets test. What will happen is that the assets test will simply continue under any future government because it is the only fair way that people who really need pensions can get a fair share of those pensions.
—That is a load of rubbish.

—The other way of doing it would be to allow the deficit to expand a little, which I have been propounding for quite some time, but that has been vigorously opposed by the Opposition. There are alternative ways of ensuring that people get a fair pension, which members of the returned services in particular, and other people, are being denied.
