DEBATE.TITLE: RADIOACTIVE WASTE MANAGEMENT 1983-84 REVIEWReportAUSTRALIAN IONISING RADIATION ADVISORY COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council report for 1983-84 is an important report. It gives a lot of detail as to the activities of the Council which consists of eminent specialists, geneticists and scientists who deal with matters concerned with biology, public health, nuclear physics, radiological physics, radio biology, human genetics, animal genetics, biostatistics, geology, mining and engineering. A number of interesting references in the report come under headings such as 'Nuclear Tests' and 'British nuclear tests in Australia'. Page 5 refers to the indoctrinee force and states:

Since publication of the report 'British nuclear tests in Australia-a review of operational safety measures and of possible after-effects' (AIRAC No. 9), the United Kingdom Ministry of Defence has made available revised information (D/DSc 3/5/8/1, 3 April 1984) relating to the exposure of Australian servicemen to radiation during the Buffalo series of nuclear tests at the Maralinga test range in 1956. The information related to the stationing of men at closer range than that normally allowed for persons witnessing nuclear tests, during the first two tests of the Buffalo series. These men, referred to as the 'Indoctrinee Force', included some Australians.

The discussion of this matter, in sections 8.11 to 8.13 of AIRAC No. 9, was based on the material available at the time of publication, and needs to be amended in the light of the new information. The amendments relate to numbers of men and their precise locations at the firing times and provide more precise information on their dosimetry, but do not affect the conclusion that these men were not overexposed to radiation.
Page 6 of the report states:

The radiation dose limits prescribed in the Safety Regulations and applicable to everyone at Maralinga were not to be exceeded, and the doses received by members of the Indoctrinee Force were well within those limits. In no sense could these men be described as 'guinea pigs' used to assess radiation effects.

The project was intended to give the indoctrinees some experience, at a safe distance, of the flash, heat and blast effects of nuclear weapons, and subsequently, an opportunity to see the effects of the explosion under safe conditions. The levels of blast, shock and optical or thermal radiations experienced were not in any way sufficient to cause injury or ill-health.
That is a very important section of the report. It also refers to secondary malignancies following radiation therapy. Here it suggests:
Of considerable relevance is the finding that new cancers are up to 10 times more likely to develop in the survivors of cancer therapy than in healthy controlled subjects of comparable age.

I visited the nuclear medicine section of the Flinders Medical Centre not long ago and I was very interested to observe the work that is being done in respect of ultrasound technology. I believe that these sorts of reports are very helpful in guiding medical technologists in a proper direction in order to minimise the possible effects of radiation through X-rays. I think the report is most interesting. Other important subjects are covered and these, I believe, warrant the attention of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the same section of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council report as that addressed by Senator Jessop but I am afraid I am not able to agree with his soothing conclusions. This report has the same faults of AIRAC reports in the past of inadequacies in what it does not say. I quote from a passage in the report which says:

SPEECH.PARA: After the test conducted tours were held over a 4-day period to inspect the effects of the explosion; these tours included some contaminated areas.

There is no doubt whatsoever that the decision to put 283 men, including 100 Australians, very close to these tests and to take them afterwards on a tour was one of the most stupid, inane and irresponsible decisions taken by anyone anywhere and it may well have serious consequences in the future in ways that this report is very careful to avoid mentioning.

This report, after all, talks about X and gamma radiation and the dosimeters recorded that. It makes no mention whatsoever of the likely effects on the soldiers and other people of the very short alpha radiation. This is the very short wave length radiation which is conveyed to the human body in the form of dust. Dust which is ingested into the lungs or other internal organs as alpha particles is known to cause cancer and ironically that cancer starts to occur 30 or 40 years after exposure. Therefore, if there is to be trouble we can expect it now. If any of those 100 Australians who were present at Buffalo I can hear me now I would like them or their relatives to tell me now or at any time in the future if they do contract cancer. I hope with all my heart that they do not, but if they do there is every likelihood that it was related to this particular occasion. Why? Because we have been told in both the Kerr report of the Expert Committee on the Review of Data on Atmospheric Fallout arising from British Nuclear Tests in Australia and the present Royal Commission into British Nuclear Testing in Australia between 1952 and 1963 that the whole of that area was a sea of dust. The test was held in inland Australia where it does not rain and the whole area was afflicted by the most appalling dust contamination. When those men went in there after that test there is no doubt that they would have breathed in large quantities of dust. Anyone who suggests that there would be no alpha radiation in that dust is either a lunatic or irresponsible.

It is very easy for AIRAC, and therefore the Government, to wash its hands of all responsibility for any future illness experienced by any of these men. I take it very deeply to heart that AIRAC should come up with a report such as this which does not anywhere, in my reading, canvass the possible effects of the alpha particles on these people. It does not properly indict-as it should have indicted-those who carried out these tests for allowing them to be carried out under those circumstances. According to page 6 of the report the intention was to give the indoctrinees, as they are called:
. . . some experience, at a safe distance, of the flash, heat and blast effects of nuclear weapons, and subsequently, an opportunity to see the effects of the explosion under safe conditions.
It is that last part in relation to the first Buffalo test that we must draw attention to particularly:
After the test conducted tours were held over a 4-day period to inspect the effects of the explosion; these tours included some contaminated areas.

That is an admission by AIRAC that if there was X and gamma radiation present of course there was alpha radiation. The alpha radiation would have been conveyed in the form of dust. On page 7 AIRAC talks in detail about radiation doses received by Australians, and states:
The X- and gamma radiation doses were indicated by the personal film badges issued to all . . . members, but the three components are not available separately.

There are several paragraphs after this which do not make any reference at all to dust or the issue that I have raised. I also note briefly that on page 17 of the report there is a discussion on the ocean dumping of radioactive waste. AIRAC does not emerge as being in favour of this disposal method for waste. I urge all honourable senators to think carefully about this and support my Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Amendment Bill to prohibit this sort of dumping. As I said in speaking to that Bill, coastal waters are the most productive areas of our oceans and ought to be protected from that type of contamination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that Senator Jessop can take a lot of comfort from this 1983-84 report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council. I agree with some of the remarks that Senator Mason made but I move a bit further on to page 10 of the report, which mentions the visit of nuclear powered ships. I note that in February AIRAC went to Perth to review arrangements for the visit of the nuclear submarine USS New York City to HMAS Stirling, Garden Island.
—They reckon the Western Australians are pretty good about safety measures.
—Yes, I am concerned about Western Australia and I am particularly concerned about the last paragraph on page 10 which states:

SPEECH.PARA: AIRAC considers that the facilities and plans to cope with any radiation emergency during a visit by a NPW to Western Australia are effective and should be used as a model for visits of NPWs to other Australian ports and berths.

I do not know what the report means by the word 'effective'. It is adequacy which concerns me. If other States are not as effective as Western Australia I would like to see not just a tenth report but an eleventh report from AIRAC on what precautions are being taken by the States and just how adequate they are in case there is an emergency such as a nuclear accident. The Senate should take note of the fact that AIRAC, in all its reports, has not reported on what would happen in the event of such an accident.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the 1983-84 report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council, I wish to refer first to page ix, on which the Council draws attention to the work done on behalf of Australia and on behalf of AIRAC by the late Professor Bob Walsh. I would like to draw attention to the obituary and eulogy to Professor Walsh on that page and to say that many people who worked with him and knew him well would agree with every word AIRAC has written there about his contribution to Australia, about his eminence, about his commitment to what he did and about the very great contribution he made in so many areas. I knew Professor Walsh first as a medical student and then as a doctor. I knew him, of course, as Dean of the Faculty of Medicine in the University of New South Wales and had the very good fortune to work with him on a number of the committees which are listed in the report, but most of all I was privileged to talk to him as he worked to ensure that proper standards were applied in the area of ionising radiation on behalf of all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: This report is particularly important in that the Council attempts to discuss some of the material relating to the exposure which Australian serviceman might have met during the period of certain nuclear explosions carried out in Australia from 1952 to 1957. As honourable senators will know, this matter has become one of considerable concern, with a royal commission being conducted at present and with concerns being expressed about the health of the servicemen involved. Senator Mason, who spoke earlier, has asked us to accept him as the expert and to set aside what AIRAC says. The Council identifies exposures received by servicemen and the extent of the exposure. It is worth while identifying the extent to which it sets this down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read me the piece about alpha radiation.

—Either Senator Mason is the expert or he is a crackpot. I say that the people on the Ionising Radiation Advisory Council not only are honest but also attempt to be thorough. They are not attempting to lead people up the garden path. As to what is an acceptable dose, the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the highest dose recorded against any Australian member of the party--
that is the party exposed-
in the shelters at 1829m at Marcoo--
the centre of the explosion-

was 6.5 millisieverts. No more than about 0.3 millisieverts of these doses can have come from exposure during the detonations; the balance comes from the visit to contaminated areas before or after the tests. The dose limit allowed at the time for the 13-week operation was 30 millisieverts, and the present annual limit for occupational exposure is 50 millisieverts. The recorded doses are well within these limits.

Obviously, it is correct to have considerable concern about whether Australian servicemen were properly protected and whether they did not meet undue exposure during these explosions. It is quite proper that these matters should be tested, but I think it is highly undesirable for honourable senators to accuse this Council of having worked from a predetermined conclusion and having selected its evidence. I believe that the Council has acted with honour and propriety and has presented the findings as far as it can. These findings suggest that the exposures recorded against Australian servicemen were, first of all, modest and secondly, well within the safety limits that were laid down at that time, and they are well within the limits laid down even today for the same kind of exposure to radiation.

Finally-I say this as a doctor-it is quite outrageous for Senator Mason to say that any malignancy which people develop later on may well be due to the time they spent at Maralinga. That is medically incorrect and quite outrageous. It just illustrates the length to which the Australian Democrats will go to mislead the Australian people when it is to their political advantage so to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like, Mr Acting Deputy President, to speak to Paper No. 1, Radioactive Waste Management 1983-84 Review Report. When I was speaking earlier, I thought that it was on the basis of Papers Nos 1 and 2 being taken together, and I chose to speak on Paper No. 2, but I should like to speak to Paper No. 1. I seek leave to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to deal with the intractable problem of nuclear waste disposal. 'We've been accumulating wastes since 1942 and we have yet to dispose of a pound of the stuff'. That was said by United States Congressman Morris Udall, speaking in the Congress to a 1981 Bill on waste management. Most so-called methods of disposal are not disposal at all, but are storage-a short term shelving of a problem which lays an unacceptable burden on the natural environment and bequeaths the difficulties of nuclear waste management to future generations, who, for all that we can predict, may have lost the science of radiological protection, but who might badly need it.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United States of America alone there are currently 70 million gallons-that is like an area of 22 hectares covered 2 metres deep-of high level wastes left over from reprocessing to isolate plutonium for military purposes. With each year of reactor operation the problem of accumulating wastes grows. While kept in storage, high level wastes, whether isolated or remaining in the spent fuel, must continuously be cooled for 300 years until most of the fission products have decayed. Thereafter, the main source of radioactivity becomes the more slowly decaying transuranics, some of which remain radioactive for up to a million years. One of the major problems in the storage of nuclear wastes is that the storage tanks corrode and leak. So far in the United States of America, 500,000 curies of radioactivity have leaked into soil surrounding storage tanks.

Another method of waste storage is vitrification. This is the process of immobilising nuclear wastes in borosilicate glass, a procedure which was devised originally as a means of greatly reducing the volume of high level liquid waste. In this way, one year's output of waste from a large reactor may be reduced to about one cubic metre. This is a relatively small volume but it carries an enormous lethal potency, retaining 12 million curies of radioactivity 10 years after discharge from the reactor. It has been demonstrated, however, that the glasses will disintegrate in contact with groundwaters at quite low temperatures and pressures, resulting in leaks of radioactivity. A draft report of the United States President's Executive Office of Science and Technology, in 1978, outlines the problems of underground storage:

The task of accurately predicting the fate of radionucleides-radioactive isotopes-emplaced in a repository over . . . several hundreds to many thousands of years is unprecedented. The principle earth science disciplines involved in such a task-namely, hydrogeology, geochemistry and rock mechanics-are relatively young sciences with little experience in making or evaluating predictions that cover time frames even as short as a few decades.

In an attempt to overcome the difficulties and shortcomings of deep geological disposal, work has begun on developing a synthetic rock which would incorporate nuclear wastes in much the same way as borosilicate glass, but which would overcome the problem of disintegration. Synroc consists essentially of three rare titanite minerals. It has proved more durable than glass under some conditions, but it disintegrates in the presence of salt solutions. This process is still in the early stage of development. It is proposed that the Synroc wastes be disposed of in deep drill holes up to 2.5 kilometres in depth. So far, $1.512m has been committed to research by the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, the Australian National University and Griffith University. The Commonwealth Government is currently funding the project with $2.754 to be spent over three years for a pilot plant.

The project raises some important points to be considered. The first of these concerns the rarity of the minerals involved. These must be presumed to be very expensive, and informed sources concur with this view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.
—Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of my speech in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The remainder of the speech read as follows-

The second is the proposal to drill holes to a depth of 2.5 kilometres. Experts in the field quote the cost of this in the order of $3m to $5m if drilled through igneous rocks. Each hole is considered sufficient to take the waste of one year from 100 atomic reactors.

Lastly, as the Australian Government is currently funding the development of this material, some disquiet must be felt as to the possibility that atomic wastes may at some later date be stored in our 'safe' geologic structures. Long term studies are needed before there can be any assurance that the radioactive material would not leak into the environment. Pediatrician Helen Caldicott has said:

Even the most brilliant scientist may honestly think he's developed a container that will remain intact for a half-million years. However, he's going to be dead in 30 years; he will never live to verify his hypothesis.

The implications for Australia as part of the nuclear cycle are clear. As an exporter of uranium we are already part of the nuclear proliferation cycle. The peaceful and military aspects of nuclear energy are intrinsically linked. We export our uranium to Japan, Germany, United States of America, Sweden, France-under suspension-South Korea, Belgium and Finland. The United States and France are nuclear weapons producing countries. Sweden, Japan and Germany have wastes reprocessed at Windscale, so that the end product of some of our uranium ends up contaminating the Irish Sea. We can by no means be sure that Japan will not dump high level nuclear waste in the Pacific, and South Korea will not give any categorical commitment that it will never develop nuclear weapons.

We are shortly to be faced with our next problem-the reprocessing and storing of spent fuel. The government funding of the development of Synroc, if the process turns out to be viable, will not end there. Already can be heard the softening up whispers of a 'moral obligation' to reprocess and store spent fuel; yet none of the hazards, dangers or problems have been solved. If this is allowed to happen, it may only be a matter of time before we are enriching uranium before export. We have only one moral obligation: The elimination of the nuclear danger-whether waste or weapons-for the safeguarding of our future generations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, I present the report entitled 'Conscientious Objection to Conscripted Military Service', together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is with a sense of satisfaction, and even some pride, that I present the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled 'Conscientious Objection to Conscripted Military Service'. This report is signed by all six members of the Committee-my colleagues Senator Barney Cooney, Senator Nick Bolkus, Senator Alan Missen, Senator Robert Hill, Senator Chris Puplick and me. The unanimous support of its recommendations indicates a bipartisan awareness of the total inadequacy of the statutory provisions which have so far purported to protect freedom of conscience in relation to conscripted military service of Australians.

I thank those present members of the Committee, and indeed those who were initially members of it, for persevering with a project which may have appeared anachronistic, and certainly took a long time, some two years, almost to the day, to complete. After all, the reference of a private member's Bill on this topic was made on 31 May 1983. I said at that time, in moving the reference, that:
. . . Some may ask why the Committee should accept a reference to do with compulsory military service at a time when it is not a live issue in the Australian community . . .
And then I answered my own question:
I believe it is precisely a time when there is none of the hysteria associated with a military campaign that is most suitable for a careful look at the issues involved.

Not many Australians realise that the provisions of the National Service Act 1951 still lay on the statute book, though suspended in operation by an Act of the Whitlam Government. The Defence Act 1903 is operative and provides the legislative framework for, amongst other things, conscription in time of an actual or feared invasion of Australia.

Whilst evidence was taken during 1983, the Committee's work was disrupted by demands on its members during 1984, principally occasioned by the urgent need to report on a proposed national crime authority and to consider evidence on a matter relating to State parliamentary privilege. This perseverance was justified by the inherent importance of the project for the resolution of matters of vital concern to any democratic society. There is a tension and apparent conflict between the obligations flowing from the community's right to exist and the right of the individual person to act in accordance with conscientiously held beliefs. By keeping firmly in mind the sort of democratic society Australia is, and aspires to remain, the Committee, I believe, has provided a solution consistent with an abhorrence of authoritarian and, even more, of totalitarian political systems.
I now read the recommendations and conclusion:
Recommendations

1. The Bill should be redrafted so that it will provide a framework for dealing with conscientious objection to compulsory military service whenever there is lawful authority to compel such service and whatever the source of the lawful authority to compel such service (paragraph 1.9).
The next paragraph, paragraph 2, is the core recommendation. It states:

2. Parliament should add to its present recognition of absolute conscientious belief, recognition of specific conscientious belief so as to grant exemption from participation in a particular military conflict where to be compelled by law to do so would violate the individual's sense of personal integrity (paragraph 2.19).

3. The Bill should not seek to limit the grounds upon which conscientious belief can be based and proved before an appropriate tribunal. The Bill should be redrafted so that it indicates neither an exemplary nor exhaustive list of grounds for the conscientious belief. Section 29A (4) of the Bill should be deleted (paragraph 2.29).

4. The determination of applications by individuals for exemption from conscripted military service on the grounds of conscientious objection should be in proceedings which are, as far as possible, informal and non-adversarial before a tribunal with at least three members (paragraph 3.11).
5. The Tribunal should be chaired by a Judge or retired judge (paragraph 3.9).

6. The other members of the tribunal should be mature citizens able by their background and expertise both to elicit the facts by other than adversarial process and to enjoy credibility in the general community (paragraph 3.11).

7. Decisions of the tribunal should be subject to appeal on the merits to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Tribunal should also be subject to the possibility of review by the courts through the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 (paragraph 3.12).
8. The individual claiming to hold a relevant conscientious belief should carry the onus of demonstrating the existence of such a belief (paragraph 3.16).
9. The standard of proof to be discharged by the applicant should be proof on the balance of probabilities (paragraph 3.25).
Conclusion

Australia, as a democracy, even when engaged in armed conflict, is well able to accommodate the proposed extension of the recognition of conscientious belief in order to protect the integrity of the individual against the coercive power of the State (paragraph 4.22).

In addition, in an annex to the report, the Committee shortly comments on some matters not directly encompassed in the terms of reference, but which arose naturally both in submissions and in our discussions around the table. These include the issues of conscription itself, of both sexes being subject to conscription should it be introduced, of alternatives to military service and of conscientious objections formed after an individual has become a member of the defence forces. I believe that the views of the Committee on these issues will be of value.

What needs to be emphasised is that it is the unanimous view of Committee members, though not the subject of formal recommendations, that any future Federal parliament faced with a perceived military necessity to introduce conscription, should do so absolutely 'from scratch'. There should be no resurrecting or implementing of provisions left lying on the statute book for years. If any such statute providing for conscripted military service were to be passed, its provisions should protect the consciences of individual Australians in the way recommended by this Senate Committee.

I said earlier that I took some satisfaction in the tabling of this report. I think it has demonstrated the way in which the Senate committee system provides a mechanism for calm deliberation after the taking of public evidence. It has provided a mechanism for consideration of a matter which has been close to my heart since my contemporaries, and later my students at the University of Tasmania, were subjected to the provisions of the National Service Act during the Vietnam war.

I hope this report not only helps prevent such overbearing of conscience as occurred then from ever occurring again in Australia, but I hope it will also help heal some of the wounds still carried by many Australians as a result of their traumatic experience in conscientiously dissenting from military service in that war. This report is, in a sense, dedicated to them. I ask the Senate to bear with me while I quote from one of my own speeches in this place. Honourable senators will concede I do not burden them with that very often. But in my maiden speech given on 23 August 1978, I had this to say:

I believe that this chamber should be encouraging the exercise of moral discernment in the use of force and should provide for it. It will not be easy. Some will view as anarchic the proposal that a citizen could conscientiously disagree with his government's conduct of an armed conflict and be relieved from participating in it.

This point may seem remote and not grounded in any crisis presently facing Australia, but I believe that not to act now, in this chamber, in a time of relative tranquillity without an atmosphere of hysteria, will be to condemn future generations of Australians to cultural genocide, such that acting on individual conscience, the most potent insight of our Judao-Christian and Western tradition, will be as remote a possibility as it is in most of the world . . . we as legislators ought to be reinforcing the individual conscience as that which culturally makes us what we are-a society where the common good cannot be secured by means which destroy the individual personality.

I believe that if this report is taken up by the Parliament, in whose members I have the greatest faith, historians will record that we as legislators reinforced 'the individual conscience as that which culturally makes us what we are-a society where the common good cannot be secured by means which destroy the individual personality'. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present report 232 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts-the report of the Auditor-General of May 1983.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-Report 232 examines the report of the Auditor-General for May 1983. Honourable senators will be aware that each year the Committee examines recently published reports of the Auditor-General. Following the tabling of the report of the Auditor-General for May 1983, the Committee sought written submissions from 13 departments and authorities in respect of 15 items. This report analyses the responses by departments and authorities to the Public Accounts Committee, explaining the criticisms raised by the Auditor-General in his report.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous Auditor-General's reports have referred to overpayments of pensions, benefits and allowances by the Department of Social Security, and proposed improvements to the system for the recovery of such overpayments. These matters have been raised again in the Auditor-General's reports of March and September 1984 and April 1985. Statistics on overpayments refer to amounts identified by the Department as having been paid out in excess of entitlement-$63.7m in 1983-84-brought about by either incomplete or inaccurate information supplied by the payee at the time entitlement was assessed, or by a change in the payee's circumstances not immediately notified to the Department. The Department advised the Committee of initiatives to improve the recovery of overpayments and of administrative reforms to be carried out under the control of the performance monitoring branch of the Department. Nevertheless, the Committee was particularly concerned that the Auditor-General had found that the Department is still facing serious problems in the identification and recovery of overpayments. The Committee believes that the system for prevention and detection of overpayments is crucial and that delays in identifying overpayments reduce the likelihood of recovery.

The Committee firmly believes that the adoption of the direct credit method of payment of benefits and allowances positively reduces the opportunity for duplication and fraudulent negotiation of cheques and strongly recommends that the direct credit method of payment be the principal means of payment of all benefits, with only exceptional cases being paid by other means. The Committee is also very concerned that beneficiaries are properly identified prior to becoming entitled to, or continuing to receive, benefits. The current amount of unrecovered overpayments is in excess of $100m and is increasing each year. As the report shows, the addition to the amount unrecovered was $28m last financial year. While the amount is small, compared with the total payments of $13,000m in 1983-84, it is material and must be reduced. The Committee does not accept that the current level of overpayments identified is satisfactory, but does acknowledge that the high level of overpayments raised is partly a result of the Department's success in identifying cases. What concerns the Committee is the level of undetected cases.

The Committee also did not accept the arguments put forward by the then Department of Education and Youth Affairs on the use of the direct credit mode and believes that Department has not addressed itself fully to the identification and recovery of overpayments of student assistance. The Committee is concerned that this issue continues to be raised in Auditor-General's reports. The Committee again recommends that the direct credit method of payment of benefits and allowances be the principal means of payments to all recipients, except for those who do not have access to regular or direct facilities with banks, credit unions or building societies. The Committee is concerned that there still appear to be many problems in the Department of Education and Youth Affairs' administration of student assistance programs. The Committee recommends that departments should ensure that specific legislation is drafted for major programs; that is, those with a budget of at least $10m and with an expected life of at least five years. The report comments on a number of other issues which I have not raised here. I commend this report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table additional information received by Estimates Committee C and seek leave for it to be incorporated in the Hansard record of the Estimates Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Ministers of State Amendment Bill, which is simply a Bill providing for the application to Ministers of this Government of the increase in salary which has been applied across the board. The amounts involved are relatively small. They accord with the determination of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The only reason they are not applied automatically is that ministerial salaries are subject to special legislation, whereas the remainder of the parliamentary salaries are subject to the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal. Whilst we would prefer to see a situation in which those receiving the increase were members of the present Opposition in government, we cannot disagree with the fact that the Ministers are entitled to the increase. We support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank Senator Rae for his support for the Ministers of State Amendment Bill. I agree that it is for a very worthwhile cause. I urge that we pass the Bill as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative. (Quorum formed)
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Representation Amendment Bill 1985 is a relatively straightforward Bill the provisions of which are consequential upon certain changes which, although we did not support them, have taken place. The number of senators from each State was increased from 10 to 12 by the Representation Act of 1983; that is, two additional senators from each State were to be elected. Thus, in the election of December 1984 there was an opportunity for extra senators to be elected if they were given high enough priority on the ballot papers. I do not propose to deal with that in detail. That Act also increased the number of members of the House of Representatives. However, it provided that those members were to receive their salary entitlement from the date of the election. But under the legislation the new senators were not entitled to receive their salary-although they were required to work as senators, and were entitled to have staff as senators and to have all the other provisions as senators-until some three months-
—Their employees did though.

—Yes, I said that they had staff and everything else but they were not entitled to a salary. As I understand it, members of the various parties were concerned that justice be done and that there not be a difference between the new members of the House of Representatives and the new senators. It was felt that equality should prevail and that legislation should be introduced to correct what amounted to an omission in the original legislation in 1983 so that the new senators were entitled to be paid from the time they were declared elected to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not oppose the Bill but we point out that it should not have been necessary. It resulted from an omission by the Government in the original legislation. We did not support the initial legislation. We did not support the increase in the size of the Parliament. But, that increase having taken place, it is only fair that those new members and senators should be treated equally irrespective of the House in which they serve, and that the new senators should receive the same entitlement as the new members of the House of Representatives. We therefore do not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in favour of the Representation Amendment Bill. It corrects an anomaly which arose because the Government provided that members of the House of Representatives who were elected on 1 December would be paid from that date whereas senators doing the same work would not be paid as senators until 21 February this year. This seemed to be a complete injustice. In the second reading speech on this Bill the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) drew attention to this in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: This difference between the additional newly elected members of both Houses was drawn to the attention of the Government following a question asked in the Senate in February in the context of the nexus requirement between the two Houses.

I raised that question. Without going into detail, because the number of people elected to the House of Representatives at the time of the last election in December was not as nearly as practicable twice the number of senators and, in fact, the number of representatives who took their seats then was many more than that, doubt was cast on the validity of the election of the House of Representatives. At least this Bill also cures that problem in that it removes doubt about an improper election of the House of Representatives on 1 December last year.

More importantly, it corrects an injustice which should not have been done. If the Government had seen the precedent of 1948-49, when the Houses were last increased and when, quite properly, senators were paid from the date of election, it would not have made this mistake. It made the mistake on this occasion and will now, rightly, repair the omission. The position is a just one for senators, who naturally have been doing the same work since they were elected in December as have members of the House of Representatives. They have had staff and have been involved in all operations. Of course, neither House sat during that period and, therefore, there was no difference whatsoever between the work of members and that of senators. This legislation accords with justice and common sense in that any doubt as to the validity of the House of Representatives that would have sent its members to the people and forced them to repay all money received-a nasty consequence-will be removed. I am glad that that has not been put to the test and that the Government has accepted this legislation as a wise compromise.
Debate (on motion by Senator Button) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the Australian Shipping Commission (Additional Capital) Bill. It is a Bill to provide the Australian Shipping Commission, otherwise known as the Australian National Line, with additional capital of $70,541,000. This additional capital is required to provide the Commission with a capital structure which is regarded by the Government as appropriate for commercial enterprise and marks a further step in the Government's program of revitalising Australia's shipping industry. That is according to the Government. All I can say is that that is garbage. It does nothing of the sort. I will explain why I do not believe that this legislation will achieve its objective. According to the ANL annual report for the year ended 30 June 1984, it has a negative capital on the balance sheet of $3.65m. In other words, it is bankrupt. However, in a note to note 14 to the financial statement-I emphasise that it is a note-at the bottom of page 30, in relation to provisions, there is this quiet little statement:

SPEECH.PARA: An actuarial valuation at 30th June 1983 estimates the deficiency at that date as $55 million.

That is the deficiency in the ANL's contributions to the Commonwealth Consolidated Revenue in respect of employers' contributions towards superannuation. If one adds $55m, as at 30 June 1983 to $3.65m one comes out with a figure which is close enough to $60m. That is what ANL is down the tube for at the moment. That is not exactly a great start for a great, wonderful, national shipping line. I do not want to be taken as being a knocker of the service ANL has provided. I want to point out that it did a lot better in shipping goods to Tasmania than it did in running as a company. One of the problems is that it has been structured as a statutory authority rather than as it ought to have been-as a proper, private sector-owned company which could have done a good job. I accept that back in the 1950s there was a case for it being a publicly-owned operation, as there was a case in the 1940s for Trans Australia Airlines being a publicly-owned operation. But that is a long time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you sell it to them?

—Unequivocally, yes. This is why we oppose the legislation. Let me give the Senate an example of some of the support for the view which I express. On page 65 of the report by the Senate Select Committee on Statutory Authority Financing entitled 'Statutory Authorities of the Commonwealth: Financing' there is reference to the ANL. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: ANL's performance over the period 1970-71--
that is, the beginning of the 1970s-

to 1981-82 is second only to ANR as being the worst of all the authorities surveyed. Over that period it has only achieved a real rate of return on total assets of 0.9 per cent and while the cost of ANL's capital is unknown it seems certain that it was not as low as this. It is particularly significant that with the exception of 1980-81 negative real rates of return on total assets have been earned since 1979-80.

In other words, its performance, when compared with that of the other statutory authorities which were surveyed by that Committee, was the second to worst in that period. The major business authorities of the Commonwealth which were surveyed included Telecom Australia, Australian National Railways, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority, Australia Post, the Australian National Line, TAA, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Pipeline Authority. I quote further from the report:
Given the high debt/equity ratio (calculated on an historical cost basis)--
that is, not on a revaluation basis, but on an historical cost basis which gives ANL an advantage-

it is not surprising that over the period ANL has received considerable benefits from the effects of inflation on its debt. It is clear that these benefits will not be received now that interest rates are significantly positive and likely to remain so, with the result that the true income of the owners is likely to become even more unfavourable in future years. As discussed in Appendix A, the valuation of ANL's fixed assets (and hence replacement cost depreciation) may have been overstated in the later years given the depressed state of the international shipping market, but until ANL's assets are independently revalued in current prices these estimates are the most reliable available. They will almost certainly be more reliable than the historical cost estimates shown in the annual reports. It is therefore more difficult with ANL than with the other authorities to be as confident regarding the accuracy of the rate of return on equity figures. To the extent that the real equity figure is lower than the estimates published here, (as a result of the depressed state of the international shipping market), the rate of return on equity will be correspondingly higher. However it is likely that this effect was strongest in later years, with the result that for earlier years the results shown in Table 3.3 should be reasonably accurate.

As with a number of other authorities, the real financial situation confronting ANL is even worse than indicated by Table 3.3 given the difficulties with superannuation. In evidence to the Standing Committee employees of ANL revealed that the Commonwealth Actuary had calculated that at 30 June 1980, if the rate of contribution paid by ANL was 15 per cent of salary unfunded liability amounted to $57.2m--
that is, at 30 June 1980-

if the rate of contribution was 23 per cent the unfunded liability is $36.6m; and if 37 per cent of salary, the unfunded liability is nil. It is therefore clear that the true income of enterprises before interest is overstated by the unfunded superannuation liability and that the equity figure is similarly overstated.

That report was published in September 1983. Since it was published we have had the 1984 report of the ANL which shows that the deficiency as at 30 June was actuarially calculated at $55m. The ANL story is woeful. I believe that the ANL will not be helped by the proposed injection of funds at this stage. The injection of $70m at this stage to provide additional capital by converting a $50.5m Treasury loan into a grant and the provision of a grant to allow the repayment of a $20m overseas loan on 1 June will not do anything to overcome the real problems of the ANL. When one considers that the ANL has not only the problems I have already referred to but also the very real problem that, when the leases terminate-much of ANL's equipment including its ships, is leased-according to the Commissioner of Taxation, the ships must be sold in a properly advertised, fully arm's length sale at a public auction in which there is no opportunity for the ANL to exercise what would amount to an option to purchase the ships for next to nothing. Although the lease payments, as I understand it, have been calculated on the basis that the ANL virtually will have paid for the ships by the time the leases terminate, what will have to happen then is that the ANL will either lose its ships or will have to go out in the open market and pay market prices to buy them back. That is another impending disaster for the ANL.

When one considers what has happened so far as Commonwealth superannuation and the ANL's debt-ridden structure are concerned, when one considers that a large part of ANL's assets are on lease-what I have just described so far as the Commissioner of Taxation is concerned will have to happen-one can see that there is a very real urgency to do something about restructuring the ANL. In restructuring the ANL we would propose to give it a chance to operate as it ought to operate, that is, as an efficient, effective private sector operation. There is no reason why the ANL should be saddled with the expenses of Commonwealth employment, Commonwealth superannuation schemes and other expensive aspects of Commonwealth interference. It would be much more effective if ANL were able to operate as a private sector shipping line. This can be done quite effectively. There are examples in various places, both in Australia and overseas, which show that it is possible to operate a shipping company on an effective, profitable basis and that it is not necessary for the Australian Shipping Commission to continue to operate unprofitably at a very considerable cost to the taxpayer.

Insofar as it might be necessary for particular services to be provided, the Government could call tenders from shipping services which could provide those services to various parts of Australia. Tenders could be for what would amount to a subsidy or supplement to what would otherwise be the cost of operation. That could apply to some places. There is no reason why ANL should not compete with any other shipping company for the provision of such services on a supplementary basis by the Commonwealth. We do not have to have a Commonwealth-owned authority to provide services to particular areas which have a particular need and which may not be able to be served on a purely economic, profitable basis. I do not think it is necessary to take a long time discussing what we propose as the matter was debated in the House of Representatives. I have summarised the problems of the ANL. I have summarised why the provision of $70m will not give it a real capital base from which it can operate. It will perhaps give it some slight positive capital and that is all. That is a fairly difficult job to give to Mr Max Moore-Wilton or whoever is going to run the ANL. He has my sympathy. I am not in any way denigrating ANL individual staff who have been trying to make an impossible structure work profitably. The structure is just not suitable. It is not the way in which one would set out to run a shipping company if one had a choice.

I see no reason why this Government and this Parliament should approve the continuation of something that is unsuitable, unlikely to be profitable, unlikely to be able to pay its way, unlikely to get out of the grips of its creditors, in effect, and unlikely to operate efficiently and effectively. It is debt ridden. It is overridden with problems of the future as well as of the past. I believe that the best thing that could happen is for the ANL to be sold on the open market, notwithstanding that the problems it has may affect the price obtained for it. In 1983 the Senate Select Committee on Statutory Authority Financing reported that ANL's performance was second only to the Australian National Railways' as the worst of all the authorities surveyed. Let us get away from that situation. That is hardly basis upon which we should be encouraged to pour more money into an authority which already has a very major problem, as it will not overcome its problems.

Taking over the liability and debts of $246m in relation to superannuation for Trans Australia Airlines did not get TAA out of its problems. I do not think providing an extra $70m towards overcoming some of the debt problems of the ANL will enable that authority to operate as efficiently and as effectively as I would like to see it operate. I am sure that everyone connected with ANL would much prefer to have a proper capital structure, a company in which the Australian public could own shares, in which the employees could own shares and in which the people involved could work towards something that was likely to produce a profit. We would like to see that happen, and happen as soon as possible. Therefore, the Opposition does not support the action proposed by the Government because it will not succeed in what I read out as being the primary stated purpose for which the Government is introducing the legislation. Therefore, we oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that Senator Peter Rae and the Opposition have not been along recently to look at exactly what has been happening at the Australian National Line. Because of the situation which the Australian Democrats have been put in, I have made a point of talking to the executive management at the ANL and I am fairly convinced that the bleak picture presented by Senator Rae is painted much bleaker than is the real situation.
—What about the history of it?

—I support Senator Rae in respect of the history of the ANL, but I believe that it has restructured itself effectively and that this has been shown to be the case by a 1984 profit. The Australian Shipping Commission (Additional Capital) Bill 1985 will inject an additional $70.5m into the Australian Shipping Commission. Some $50.5m will convert existing Treasury loans to capital and $20m will enable ANL to repay an overseas Treasury loan that falls due in June. The effect will be to recapitalise the Australian National Line, assisting to put it on a sound commercial footing. I note, as Senator Peter Rae has, that this is the second time in two years that the Australian taxpayer has had to bail out ANL. In May 1983 ANL received an even more expensive lifebuoy, worth $90m.
—It is still $60m down the tube.

—The Australian Democrats support this Bill which guarantees the survival of Australia's own shipping company. However, we have reservations. We believe that mere recapitalisation and a realistic corporate strategy will not automatically ensure ANL's survival. These reservations have led the Australian Democrats to seek from the Government a guarantee of performance for ANL-as much as the Government can give it-an assurance that an independent report will be completed in 1986-87. That report should be on the financial performance of ANL and its progress towards achieving its declared commercial aims.

SPEECH.PARA: We accept that ANL needs to take tough decisions to improve its image. I now believe, after talking to ANL's chief executive, that it has developed a realistic corporate strategy based on sound accounting principles. However, our national shipping line is still in murky waters. It is still beset by a very poor image-as shown by Senator Rae in his speech. It is beset by a poor perception by Australians of its industrial management and economic viability. The report that we propose will allow ANL to vindicate itself and Parliament to have the real facts. It will allow ANL to provide a service as a sound commercial enterprise. ANL's progress in dealing with these problems must be monitored closely. The Australian people need to know that their good money is not being thrown after bad. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has recognised the importance of such an independent report and has responded positively to our request. We were delighted to receive the following undertaking from the Minister, when he stated:

I welcome the Democrats support for the Government's proposal to inject $70.5m capital into the Australian National Line (ANL). Unlike the Liberal-National Parties' narrow and blinkered opposition, the Democrats have assessed the issue on its merits and recognise that the Government is moving constructively to ensure that ANL operates on a proper commercial basis. They have sought an assurance from the Government that an independent report be brought forward in 1986-87 on the financial performance of the ANL and its progress towards achieving its declared commercial objectives.
The Minister continued:
I consider this to be a sensible proposal and give the assurance that such a report will be prepared by a member of the Inter-State Commission.

I believe that with this undertaking-I have been quoting the Minister's words-we can safely say that the Government will have an independent arbiter look at the performance of ANL. The evidence that we have before us now is that the Australian National Line showed an operating profit in 1984. The vital factor which we have to take into account is a commitment by the unions and ANL management to co-operate to ensure the commercial future of the Line. The unions must recognise the necessity of reductions in the ANL fleet and better productivity and work practices, both ashore and on board. Management must recognise ANL employees' concerns and interests and be prepared to consult employees when important decisions are being made. The management-union co-operation will have to be based on goodwill on both sides. The performance of ANL will depend on that. On the other hand, attempts to improve productivity, both at sea and on shore in ANL's terminals, have met with less success. All parties are participating in discussions. However, to quote the ANL annual report for 1984: 'implementation has been disappointing'. Implementation cannot and must not be disappointing if ANL is to survive.

The unions and management must combine to reduce costs and to make ANL more effective. Manning levels which contribute substantially to costs are of critical importance. New manning levels were agreed upon in 1983-84. The 1984 annual report expresses the hope that these new levels will be implemented in 1984-85. But the new levels of 25 to 26 people per ship, down from 31 to 38, will only be on new or replacement tonnage and not across the whole fleet. Those levels are still higher than those on other shipping nations. However, some of these nations exploit their crews mercilessly and we, in no way, expect ANL to follow these shameful examples.

The economic need for reductions in ANL's fleet has been recognised. But as at 30 June 1984 we had the same number of vessels as at the end of 1983, namely, 33 vessels. Since then that number has been reduced to 27. Rationalisation of operations and services has also commenced. Coastal liner operations have been examined and rationalised. ANL's east coast services have been rearranged. Tasmania has taken over its own link with the mainland, with a new vessel, the Abel Tasman, supposedly coming into service soon. ANL vessels no longer trade north of Brisbane and that service lost more than $6m in 1983-84. ANL is adding new divisions of stevedoring and agency operations which it believes will be effective and commercial. I believe this is all moving ANL towards being an effective shipping line of which Australia can be proud.

ANL has also begun to rationalise its services to foreign ports. The Pacific American Container Express Service to the east coast of the United States of America has been abandoned by the management of ANL because of general competition on that line. On this occasion the Seamen's Union of Australia, while not approving, has not taken disruptive action. ANL's management also attempted to withdraw the Allunga from trade on the west coast of North America after concluding that it was not commercially justified. Union action ensued and the service was retained for a further uneconomical six months on the west coast of North America. Short term considerations should not override the commercial imperatives confronting ANL. However, all of these things take time. The rationalisation of the Christmas Island phosphate transport will take some time. On each of these occasions the unions appear to have behaved sensibly in their longer term interests.

The prospects for ANL's future must be considered in light of the fact that industrial relations were worse in 1983-84 than in 1982-83. I believe they have improved this year. A total of 287 ship operating days were lost at a cost of $7.08m. That was approximately double the cost in the previous year. However, I am told that this situation is being remedied. Two of the major disputes in 1983-84 were painfully pointless demarcation disputes and quite beyond the control of management. Co-operation between unions, and unions and management is essential if ANL is going to survive. For Australia's economic well-being the Australian Shipping Commission must also increase its share of Australian foreign trade. ANL must do better than the 4 or 5 per cent that it currently controls.

The Government must be commended for the steps to increase ANL's share of liner traffic. ANL and the unions must be wise and work together to increase that share by making ANL economically attractive. Because of the Australian Democrats' support in the Senate, the ANL will get a chance to become more economically viable and attractive. But we have ensured that ANL's progress towards achieving its declared commercial objectives and its financial performance will be overseen by an independent person. A report will be brought forward and presented to this Parliament by people who understand the industry so that we can then check the facts. ANL's performance will be checked and monitored and the taxpayers' money will not be wasted.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before dinner I was explaining why the Democrats were going to support the Australian National Line and the Government proposal to let it have $70.5m to allow it to get its cash flow problems in order. I wish to continue by looking at a more global problem with our economy. Australia has negative net invisibles. Invisibles include the cost of services such as transport, insurance, exchange and money transfers provided both to foreigners-that is invisible exports-and by foreigners for Australia, which is invisible imports. The net invisibles figure is the sum of these two figures. Because Australia relies heavily upon foreign shipping services, foreign insurance and foreign banks our net invisibles are always negative. That means, even with a positive balance of trade, Australia ends up with a negative balance of payments on the current account. This is because nil invisible imports exceed net tangible goods export earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: Another worrying factor for Australia is that invisibles are paid in foreign currency. That, in turn, reduces our national reserves, which are needed to pay for our imports. To maintain these reserves we have to borrow overseas or sell Australian assets to overseas people or corporations. If this happens ownership of Australia and influence over our destiny passes into foreign hands. Even though the Australian National Line historically has a bad image it is an Australian shipping line and can be paid in Australian dollars. If we use the Australian line we can decrease our dependence on invisibles. Further steps must be taken to instill in people who set up shipping, agents, confidence in ANL. Unions and management must realise that the confidence of shippers is crucial if ANL is to win a greater share of Australian trade, improve its performance and survive. Only then will ANL begin to effect our invisible payments favourably.

Australia's foreign debt of $40 billion is increasingly difficult to service. Australia's foreign currency reserves must be used to service that debt, not to pay for invisibles. We must take steps to reduce our invisibles. Hence, it would seem rather stupid to obliterate ANL. The demise of the Australian National Line would increase invisibles and hence increase foreign debt. There is an alternative to greater foreign ownership and foreign indebtedness and that is for Australia to reduce its invisible payments for services. We must encourage and support Australian services not only in the shipping line but also in other areas. Retaining ANL as an Australian enterprise gives us a chance to reduce these payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a whole policy on that. Have you?

—Yes, indeed. If shippers and exporters use ANL in preference to foreign lines we will have to pay out fewer foreign dollars. On the other hand, if ANL disappears, the invisible costs will increase to our detriment.
—Not if it is owned by Australians.

—We are in favour of privatisation in some areas but currently the structure of ANL is such that it needs this boost. With its debt structure, it would not be worth very much if it were sold on the open market. We have to let it trade out of its current difficulties and that is the reason why the Democrats are supporting this legislation. I commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Australian Shipping Commission (Additional Capital) Bill we are considering a proposal by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) to save, yet again, the Australian National Line. It is only two years since $90m was given to the ANL; now Parliament is to be invited to give another $70.5m to this ailing company-$50.5m for the conversion of existing domestic Treasury loans into capital and $20m to enable ANL to repay an overseas Treasury loan which falls due next month. By any reasonable standards the ANL is just about broke.
—It is broke. It is $60m down the tube.

—Senator Rae may well be right. There are various accountants' ways of looking at this. I said 'just about broke' because I was trying to be charitable. Last year the ANL lost $67m, and the latest report from the Australian Shipping Commission-the body that runs the ANL-showed negative capital reserves of $3.6m and outstanding loans of $114m. As the Commission said: 'now that our standing financial loss estimates are recognised, the total balance sheet liabilities amount to $407m'.

SPEECH.PARA: The ANL is broke, or just about broke. Why is it broke? When we gave the company the last massive injection of capital I said that government-run enterprises seemed constantly to run into this problem of bankruptcy. The Government should not be in the business of shipping. Senator Vigor was talking about the difficulty of selling ANL. I do not think anyone would buy the company as it is but I think that its assets have value. The sensible thing would be to sell the assets and have them run efficiently by private enterprise. Why is the ANL doing so badly? It is only two years since the Minister was calling for a five-point plan to rescue the ANL with, as he said, 'a determined commitment by management and unions to greater productivity and joint action to improve ANL's performance'. Those were the Minister's words.

A great deal has been made of the reductions in crew levels. Recent Press reports have claimed that the ANL had succeeded in reducing ship manning from between 31 and 36 crew members to between 25 and 28. This sounds fine until we remember that world averages, including those of countries that are more affluent than we are, are between 21 and 24 crew members and some new ships have crews as small as 17. In any case, these claimed crew reductions have not yet taken place. According to the latest ANL report, the Australian Council of Trade Unions put forward proposals in May 1984 for reduced manning levels of 25 or 26 for new vessels and replacement tonnage, not for existing vessels. The ANL report went on to say that the manning levels on existing ANL vessels-that is, the ones we are dealing with at the moment-varied from 31 to 38. It went on to say also that it was hoped that the welcome initiatives I talked about earlier would be implemented in 1984-85.

One hopes these reductions will be implemented. To run our ships with up to 10 more crew members than those of other countries-including countries more affluent than we are, not cheap labour countries-is an extraordinary reflection on our management or our work practices or both. I ask the Minister what progress has been made in actually reducing these manning levels, rather than just talking about it. In any case, I must emphasise that when one looks at the problem one sees that it is not just the manning levels but the total manpower costs that must be borne in mind; and the total manpower cost of running an Australian ship is astronomical. Sweden has a standard of living, a standard of affluence, higher than ours. Yet to run an Australian ship costs twice as much in manpower costs as it does to run a Swedish ship.

I give another example. It has to be a few years old because the up to date statistics are not available. In 1981 the average world cost of operating a 110,000 dead-weight tonne ship on the open registry was $1.8m a year. For the British the same ship would cost $2.4m to operate, and for an Australian ship manned by Australians-bearing in mind the average world cost is $1.8m and the British cost $2.4m-under our present Australian conditions it would cost $3.8m, double the operating cost on the open registry. The Europeans estimate that to run their ships on Australian manning standards would cost them an additional $1m a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It costs more to send goods from Melbourne to Tasmania than it does to send them from Singapore to Tasmania.

—That is true. It is partly due to the cost of shipping and partly-this is an issue I will come to in a moment-due to the cost of our port facilities. Dealing with our shipping at the moment, the reason for our very high manpower costs to run our ships is partly overmanning, partly strikes and partly the extraordinary system whereby our voyage-on voyage-off system means that ANL must employ 2.3 men per berth. In other words, for every man on board the ship, there must be 2.3 men per berth somewhere. In other countries the manning figure is typically 1.5 men per berth. This is an industrial outrage, and we will not get efficient sea transport until the Government is prepared to tackle this outrage. One must remember that the whole Australian community and the efficiency of our economy are affected by our transport costs. As for industrial disputes, I read in the lastest report of the ANL this rather disturbing statement:

SPEECH.PARA: During 1983-84 a total of 287 ship operating days were lost through industrial disputation at a cost of $7.09 million, which was more than double the cost of $3.50 million in the previous year.
I seek leave to incorporate a table showing the operating days lost through industrial disputes in the ANL in 1983-84. They are the latest figures available.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

No. of Percentage
Days of Total
Shipping (e.g. ships crews) 92 32.00 Stevedoring
ANL Terminals 131 46.64 Other 24 8.00 Other Shore Disputes (e.g. Bulk loading, transport etc.) 25 9.00 Ancillary Services (e.g. Tugs, Pilots, Linesmen) 15 5.00
Source: Australian National Line Annual Report 1984, page 17.

TALK.START.PARA: —One can see from the table that 131 shipping days were lost through strikes in ANL terminals. This points up another problem, the waterfront problem, which we must tackle if our sea transport system is to be efficient. But 32 per cent of the total days lost-92 shipping days-were lost through crew disputes. Here again, one of the real problems is the multiplicity of unions, and I ask the Minister what advances have been made to reduce the number of unions that go down to the sea in ships.

SPEECH.PARA: I sum up by saying that it is very damaging to our whole economy that our shipping services are so enormously expensive-very much more so than in countries with higher standards of living than ours. We must take action rather than just talk about reducing crew levels. We must stop the extraordinary featherbedding by which one requires 2.3 crew members for each berth, and we must reduce industrial disputes. The obvious way to do that is to reduce the multiplicity of unions and thereby reduce demarcation disputes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support multinational unions?

—I would certainly support the amalgamation of unions into a single sea-going union as long as the unions who have members who go to sea are prepared to shed their members to provide a single sea-going union.

SPEECH.PARA: The figure we must look at constantly is our total manpower costs to run our ships. We must not be headed off by some minor aspect of it. I repeat that, vital though it is we tackle this problem, we must also simultaneously recognise that governments cannot run efficient shipping lines. Only two weeks ago we heard that the Government was going to turn over the defence services home loan scheme to private enterprise.

The Government, in a much publicised statement, claimed as a result that savings would be made, backlogs would be removed, 400 or 500 public servant positions would be saved and the effect of this would be carried by private enterprise at no cost to the community. Of course, it is true and obvious that private enterprise operates much more efficiently in this field than government does. That is what should be done with the ANL. The whole Australian community suffers very greatly from the inefficiency and high costs of our sea transport. We have only to look at the subsidies that must be paid to Tasmania because it is restricted to sea transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —To compensate them.

—This is to compensate Tasmania for the inefficiency of our sea transport. That should not be necessary. Sea transport, properly run, is the most efficient method of transport available to anyone, yet we have to compensate Tasmania for the inefficiencies of our sea transport and our Australian flagships which have a very inefficient monopoly of all traffic on the Australian coast. We must see to it that the whole community has an efficient shipping industry. It is important to our economic development and to the standard of living of all Australians that the Government takes some decisive action on our shipping rather than just tinker with the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of points have been made in the second reading debate this evening on the Australian Shipping Commission (Additional Capital) Bill 1985, the purpose of which is to provide the Australian Shipping Commission with additional capital of $70.541m. This capital will be used to convert the existing domestic Treasury loans to capital-a sum of $50.541m-and to enable the ASC to repay an overseas loan of $20m that falls due in June 1985. During the debate a number of honourable senators made criticisms of the Government's decision to make a further capital allocation to the Australian National Line. But their criticisms are quite unfounded; they are no longer appropriate. For example, Senator Peter Rae drew a picture of a body which was historically true but which is no longer true.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Vigor from the Australian Democrats pointed out, the picture has changed substantially over the past two years. The ANL has a new legislative charter to enable it to act competitively and commercially. The ANL has new management with a proven commercial track record. The ANL is rationalising its services, it is disposing of obsolete and inappropriate vessels, and it is improving its productivity and its efficiency both at sea and at its terminals. Some benefits have already appeared from this new management and new legislative arrangement. The ANL recorded an operating profit of $3.3m in 1984-85; that is, a $22m turnaround from the previous year. There might be Opposition senators in this place who would like to ignore that fact but I suggest that it is a very considerable improvement and certainly disproves the claim made by Senator Hamer, the last speaker for the Opposition, that it is impossible for a public authority or a government enterprise to act profitably in this regard. It is not. The figures prove Senator Hamer wrong.

Of course, ANL does not face an easy task in the future to build on this promising initial response but the $70.5m capital injection which is provided by this legislation will be an important step forward. With the ANL on a more commercial financial footing and relieved of part of the debt which it faces, the ANL management will be better placed to move forward into sustained profitability.

A number of points have been made during the debate, but I particularly want to respond to Senator Hamer's query about the manning of the ships. Senator Hamer suggested that the ships were overmanned and that this is one reason why the commercial performance was not as good as might be expected. I am happy to respond to Senator Hamer that in fact progress is being made in this respect. For example, the newest vessel introduced into ANL is a container ship, the Australian Trader. It has a crew of 25, which compares favourably with crews of 31 to 35 in existing vessels in the fleet.

It is clear that ANL has turned around from the loss situation and is operating in a more commercial fashion. The new management, I suggest, has made a very promising start and progress is being made in respect of the problem of overmanning. The criticisms made by Liberal Party senators in particular during this debate are no longer relevant. I place on record my appreciation of Senator Vigor's remarks. He showed a very keen appreciation of the circumstances of ANL and of the positive and constructive developments which have taken place under the new management. Having refuted the unfounded criticism made by Senator Peter Rae and Senator Hamer, I now commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions previously on the Representation Amendment Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
