That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985 provides for expenditure of more than $4,000m over the next five years. This is something of an anti-climax after the Representation Amendment Bill with which we have just dealt and which involved a minor amount of money. This Bill replaces the Roads Grants Act, which is due to expire on 30 June, and will become the major source of Commonwealth finance for road construction and maintenance over the next five years. The legislation provides some $810m for the first year, and this amount will be indexed to the consumer price index for each of the succeeding years. This, together with the $440m for 1985-86 from the Australian bicentennial road development program, will provide a total of $1,250m of which $1,245m will be available for roads after allowing the $5m for road and rail research.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill re-establishes a new trust fund for the receipt and distribution of this money and provides the certainty that the indexation consumption base-that is, 3.66c per litre-will provide some $810m over the first year. Combined with the other funds to which I have referred, this provides a great start for a road building program for Australia.

The point I wish to make is that this is the continuation of a program which was started under the former Fraser Government. I congratulate the Government for continuing this program and the important development of Australia's roads. But we do not think it is appropriate for the Government to claim credit and full kudos for this program. The program is a continuation of the Australian bicentennial road development program which was started under the former Government; it is being carried on by the present Government. The 1984-85 Budget estimates, on the kindest interpretation, reveal that the amount allocated for this financial year, that is a total of $1,245m for road grants and the Australian bicentennial road development program funds, is actually a reduction in real terms of about 3 per cent on the figure for 1983-84, which was the Labor Government's first year and the first year of the former coalition Government's Australian bicentennial road development program funding.

What in fact has happened is that, although the present Government is going ahead with a road development program of major proportions, for which we give it due credit, it is not going ahead in the proportion which had been planned under the former Government. The basis of the calculation is quite simple. The Budget document indicates a 3.4 per cent increase. If one then deducts from the consumer price index increase of about 6 per cent, one arrives at a decline in real terms. For 1985-86 the reduction will be at least 6 per cent greater than the figure for 1984-85; and the reduction will probably be greater, depending on the inflation rate. In anticipating that figure, it is regrettable that almost every step this Government is taking in economic management indicates that the inflation rate for 1985-86 will be substantially higher than it has been whilst the Government has been enjoying the benefits of what the previous Government was able to set in train and hand over to it. In two years of Labor Government there has been a reduction of over 9 per cent in real terms for road finance, construction and maintenance.

Whilst the Government has seen in two years a real reduction of 9 per cent, it has been increasing expenditure on administration of its departments by anything between 15 per cent and 30 per cent. In some instances, up to 40 per cent of the increases in the past year has been on administration alone. The huge explosion in the Budget deficit is not because of expenditure on important infrastructure developments such as roads, but because there has been an extreme increase in expenditure on administrative costs of the Government. If the Bureau of Transport Economics road construction price index is used instead of the CPI, the reduction would probably be greater because of the significant increase in petroleum prices which is now occurring and which is accelerating the cost of bitumen.

The new legislation basically follows the earlier Roads Grants Act but also incorporates many of the features of the Australian bicentennial road development legislation. The Opposition basically supports the concept of the legislation. There are several significant similarities to the Australian bicentennial road development program which the former Minister for Transport, the Hon. Ralph Hunt, introduced in 1982, to his credit and to the credit of that Government of which my colleague Senator Peter Baume was a member, and about which all who were involved can be proud. The first is the establishment of a trust fund to administer the Commonwealth grant. The Opposition supports this concept which has now been introduced but we have some doubts whether the Government is completely genuine about the trust fund concept. For instance, the Government indexed the Australian bicentennial road development program levy beyond 2c a litre but has not paid that into the trust fund. It has pinched the money; that is what has happened. It has plundered the public purse. Have honourable senators ever heard anybody talking about plundering the public purse? Once again the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the fellow who talks about plundering the public purse, has been a member of a government which has been involved in plundering the public purse. It has increased the levy on petrol and indexed it and, instead of passing this money on for the development of roads, has pinched it and put it into Consolidated Revenue so that it can be spent on its excessive administration costs. That is the sort of thing that is happening.

There is separate provision for rural and urban arterial roads, as is provided in the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Act; and the Opposition supports that proposal. Maintenance, as well as construction, is allowed. However, the Opposition is concerned that there has been a 5 per cent reduction in the total grant for arterial roads, which equals a 15 per cent to 18 per cent reduction for that category. The reduction is even greater when allowance is made for the optional use of rural arterial finance for railways. In the Australian bicentennial road development program, of course, up to 25 per cent is used for urban public transport from the urban arterial sector.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has indicated that, as with the Roads Grants Act, tendering will not be required for arterial roads-the opposite of the bicentennial program, which requires tendering. Generally speaking, the State Ministers and local governments are opposed to tendering because of the possible effect it could have on continuity of employment for their road gangs, particularly in regional areas. The States also say that this requirement would be unfair because they have to provide two-thirds of the arterial road money. The private road construction industry, however, supports tendering and wishes to see it extended further, believing that this is the most efficient use of taxpayers' money. The on-site and geographic advantages of regionally based State or local authority gangs should provide enough edge to win any tender which is really competitive, particularly in conjunction with exemptions to the tender requirements that are provided.

The Opposition has decided not to move an amendment to require tendering at this stage. However, the Opposition will monitor the progress of this legislation very closely. We shall see that the Australian bicentennial road development legislation is reviewed for possible reconsideration upon the Opposition's return to government after the next election, whenever that may be-may it be soon. While the bicentennial road development levy has been indexed, the $500m plus which was gained from that indexation has not been paid, to the shame of this Government, into the trust fund and is not being used for road construction, as it should be. It is being used for administration expenses of the Government. As I said before, I believe that matter is shameful. The Australian road users, the people who are paying the levy, are being ripped off by a form of taxation which they should not be paying. The Consolidated Revenue funds should be gained by other taxation measures. The bicentennial road levy was to be used for road development and was not for Consolidated Revenue.

My further comment concerns the matter of the cuts which we heard so much about in the recent mini-Budget. There was a claim than $60m had been cut out of the 1985-86 figures of this Government. The fact is that the Minister for Transport in his Press release and in his answer to the shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Lloyd, in the House of Representatives on 16 May last stated that the $1,245m, which is the total road program figure for the next year that was first announced over five weeks ago, will not be reduced. Yet in the mini-Budget the Government tried to claim that there had been a $60m road cut. The Government obviously put on that amount in the first place, took it off again and said that it had cut it. In fact, the Minister announced five weeks before the mini-Budget the amount to be expended. This cut is as phoney as the whole lot of other sleight-of-hand tricks which were engaged in by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and others responsible for the phoney mini-Budget which pretended to show that this Government was dinkum about taking a hard line in relation to the necessary expenditure cuts. In fact, the average Australian, the Australian financial market and the world financial market have shown that they do not believe the Government is dinkum.

I will not hold up the Senate by going into more detail in relation to that aspect of the phoneyness of the mini-Budget. I simply say that that $60m as well as all of the other items to which many of us have referred at various times were, in fact, phoney cuts. They were never real cuts. In this case the Minister had announced five weeks before the mini-Budget that the amount to be expended would be $1,245m in respect of the total road program, and that is what it will be. There is no $60m cut. Many of us may be relieved to find that, in fact, road development will be going on to a degree which we would like to see taking place. I would much prefer to see the $500m which the Government pinched out of the levy going into road development and not into Consolidated Revenue. That would be much more preferable as an honest approach by a government which genuinely is prepared to levy from the users an amount of money to be invested in the development of better roads for this country at a faster rate of development. That is what we need and that is what we regret the Government is not doing. The Opposition, with those reservations, will support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985. It is commendable in its recognition of the importance of and the need for guaranteed indexed funds to construct and maintain Australia's transport infrastructure. It recognises the importance of forward planning by establishing a trust fund and setting levels of funding for the next five years. The Bill also ensures in some measure that the user pays, that those who use the most fuel pay the most excise and hence have a greater input into the trust fund. The Bill also goes some way to making sure that road hauliers, whose trucks do the most damage to roads, pay for the necessary repairs to those roads. It extends Federal funding beyond the confines of the Roads Grants Acts which it must replace by 1 July this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill also goes beyond the Roads Grants Acts in another way, by attempting for the first time to establish a coherent and comprehensive approach to land transport. I agree with the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) about the importance of Australia's transport system. An efficient system has a major economic impact, both now and in the future. One area of impact is our success as exporters. However, a well organised and maintained and cost-efficient transport infrastructure is also of immense social importance, something that has not been sufficiently recognised in this Parliament. Road safety and road research are now to be funded by this program from moneys raised by the fuel excise-a commendable step. However, I am still disappointed that economic factors have been put above social factors, even in this Bill. The admirable concept of social audit, part of the Australian Labor Party's platform on transport, is absent from this Bill. But then, it was ignored when the terms of reference for the Hill inquiry into the Darwin to Alice Springs rail line were set. On that occasion the defence aspects were excluded as well. On this occasion the economic and trade aspects are the qualities stressed in the discretion given to the Minister when declaring appropriate projects to be of national importance.

The funds created by the railways through the use of diesel fuel, we believe, should be returned to them to assist in the maintenance of their road; that is, the track on which the trains run and the switching gear which is used to protect that track. This provision could be criticised in the light of the large amount of funds which are already being provided to the railways. However, Australian National is not the only railway in Australia. Other railways deserve to have their fuel excise returned to the rail networks, by the same justice that requires that road users' excise is ploughed back into the road network. It is also just that road users pay for road safety programs, research into roads and road use. It is legitimate that Federal funds raised from excise and customs duties on fuel be used to pay for the maintenance work on roads.

The addition of these new funding categories means that the Government's claim that it is maintaining road funding levels is possibly open to question. Not only have total funds been slightly reduced to $810m, but also the assistance must now be spread further over a greater number of categories. The fact that funds may be directed to both the construction and maintenance of national and arterial roads is a very significant change. It is significantly different from the Roads Grants Act 1981 as well as the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982, which directed funds solely towards construction work.

Interstate mainline railways are as significant as national highways. They link major capital cities and provide a freight service which spans the continent. The coexistence of rail and road is significant to Australia's transport infrastructure and this has been recognised in this Bill. Funding for the upgrading of the interstate rail links may be provided from the allocation for national highways. We believe that this is very important. The possibility of funding rail from rural arterial categories, of course, recognises the important role that rail transport plays in our primary industry sector. What a pity it is, then, that the Minister has not seen fit to allow himself a degree of discretion and to declare an interstate mainline railway a significant project, similar to the way in which national highways are treated, and to put it in the 'developmental road' category.

Clause 4 of the Bill covers this area. Developmental roads are equated quite properly by the Bill to national roads. As the definition in the Bill shows, they are roads of national significance. They are aimed at the development of particular industries or particular energy resources, including those in remote areas; at facilitating or developing interstate or international trade or commerce; and at facilitating significant tourist travel. The roads are, of themselves, of national importance. By comparison, the definition of 'interstate mainline railway' allows only the meagrest of ministerial discretion. A declaration may be made for intercapital lines, or any line of national significance in relation to interstate trade and commerce. This is a much smaller area of discretion than that available for roads. We would like to have this looked at in the long run.

The Bill should allow a line that facilitates international trade in resources to be funded, for example, under the 'developmental road' category. Bulk resources freight is one category of freight that rail handles very efficiently and effectively. I am pleased to see that the Government has learnt from the Australian Road Research Board program and indexed, to the consumer price index, the specified share of customs and excise duty on motor spirits and diesel fuel that will be paid into the Australian Land Transport Trust Fund established by this Bill. To some extent indexation will maintain the value of the money set aside by the Bill. However, I hope that the Government does not show under this Bill the same contempt for trust funds as it has shown by cutting funding for the Australian bicentennial road development program by a claimed $60m. However, it will not prevent each excise and customs duty dollar buying less road over a five-year period. To some extent indexation will combat inflation, but the cost of road construction and maintenance escalates at an even greater rate. Road costs continue to rise at a rate at least 50 per cent higher than that of CPI increases.

We support Senator Peter Rae's proposal of using the road construction cost index as a measure of inflation in this area. This would provide a more realistic indexing of Australia's land transport program. Indexation by the road construction cost index would more truly maintain the impetus and effect of this program. In my State of South Australia the use of that index and a formula approach would have helped us. South Australia has been discriminated against. Under the current arrangement, South Australia receives only 7 to 8 per cent of total road funds. However, if we had a formula based on area, population and road length, and not a formula based on expenditure, South Australia's share would rise to approximately 9 per cent of total road funds.

I now turn to clause 32 (1), which requires that States invite tenders for categories of national highways and capital railway projects. The Australian Democrats have received a number of submissions to the effect that arterial roads should be subjected to the same tendering process. The Australian Democrats have decided that requiring the States to invite tenders for urban and rural arterial roads would be inappropriate. The Australian Council of Local Government Associations has calculated that 13,000 local jobs would have been at risk if full open tendering for arterial roads had been introduced-some 5,000 jobs in New South Wales, 3,400 in Victoria, 2,800 in Queensland and 1,800 in other States. By putting jobs at risk tendering would have a major disruptive social impact especially on communities that rely on the local road work for sustenance. This effect would be especially serious in remote rural areas.

The economic reasons for favouring tendering, however, are substantial. The major reason is that tendering appears to provide the best value for money by a process of competitive pricing. However, the cost of tendering itself is eventually passed on to the Government. Tendering, however, means that there is public accountability. We believe that this public accountability is also available when public bodies such as local government are doing the road building. The Minister for Transport in his second reading speech sensibly recognised the administrative cost of tendering and said that it would be meddling in the traditional responsibilities of the States to change the current system. He pledged to require the simplest of administrative information in respect of the approvals for arterial roads. Tender preparation is a costly process that must be paid for. The investigation, design, documentation, supervision and administration for a small project of approximatley $20,000 could be as high as $1,000. We sought and found no conclusive evidence that the tax dollar built more kilometres of road through the private sector as opposed to the public sector. There is only a philosophical argument that somehow open tendering is better. This, however, did not justify a special amendment to handle this process. Therefore, the Australian Democrats are supporting the Bill unchanged.

The Federal Government has a responsibility to ensure that the Australian land transport system is developed effectively and safely and that it will assist Australia's economic prosperity. The advances and benefits of the last few years must not be squandered. This Bill is a step in the right direction. The Australian Democrats support the Bill and will be watching the Australian land transport program's implementation with interest. We commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill which provides for continued Federal funding for roads following the expiry of the current Roads Grants Act at the end of this financial year. As a senator representing Western Australia I have of course a particular interest in and concern for road funding. Western Australia's road network of some 140,000 kilometres constitutes 17.8 per cent of Australia's total public roads. Some 28.88 per cent of Australia's national roads, that is, 4,562 kilometres, are within Western Australia. However, it is not without significance that our share of Federal spending in 1985-86 on these highways represents only 10.5 per cent of the total Commonwealth outlays on national highways.

SPEECH.PARA: What gives me very real concern is that Western Australia's percentage has declined from an already low base in 1984-85 of 10.9 per cent, to the 10.5 per cent which I just referred to. To compound that inequity, while Western Australia has 17.8 per cent of Australia's total public roads, our share of total Federal road grants in 1985-86 is only 12.19 per cent of outlays. Again, that is a decline from the 1984-85 figure of 12.67 per cent. I might add of course that Western Australia occupies 33 per cent of the Australian land mass. The construction and maintenance of Western Australia's roads have played a vital role in the resource development in that State and have provided sufficient support to enable the development to continue. This reduction in funding is not just a matter of concern to Western Australia. Resource development in both the mining and agricultural sectors has enabled Western Australia to contribute 21.5 per cent of Australia's export earnings in 1984-85. The opening up of remote and regional developments has increased Western Australia's export earnings from $286m in 1963-64 to $5,334m in 1983-84, increasing its contribution to Australia's total exports from 10.3 per cent to 21.5 per cent.

Under Labor's land transport program the amount of Federal funds allocated to roads in 1985-86 will be $1,245m, approximately the same in money terms as for 1984-85. Therefore, in real terms, after allowing for inflation, this will represent a decline in funding compared with 1984-85. It should be remembered that funding for roads in 1984-85 represented a decline compared with 1983-84. The 1984-85 Budget allocation for road grants to the States and the Northern Territory increased by only 3.4 per cent compared with last year to $1,245.2m. Allowing for last years inflation rate of 6.9 per cent, this represents a fall in funding in real terms of 3.5 per cent.

The new legislation is similar in some respects to the Australian bicentennial road development program which was initiated by the coalition Government. A proportion of the revenue collected from the excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel-in fact 3.66 per cent-will be paid into the Australian Land Transport Program Trust Fund. In 1985-86, out of this fund, $5m is to be allocated for land transport research and road safety and $805m is to be allocated to national, urban and rural arterial roads and local roads. In addition, $440m is to be provided under the Australian bicentennial road development program. The $805m will be distributed among the various road categories on a percentage basis. For 1985-86, therefore, funding for national highways will be $380.8m and funding for local roads will be $204.3m. This involves an increase over 1984-85 allocations for these categories of 9 per cent and 10 per cent respectively. According to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) in his second reading speech, this increase in funding is intended to maintain expenditure on national and local roads in real terms. If that is the case, it gives us at least some indication of this Government's expectations of the level of inflation for the coming year. By contrast-this is the bottom line-funding for arterial roads is to be cut quite severely from a total of $263.2m in 1984-85 to $219.9m in 1985-86. That represents a cut of 16.4 per cent.

As I have said, the trust fund concept of this legislation is based on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund. I suspect it is worth examining the Labor Party's record on that particular trust fund. The Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund was established by the coalition Government as part of the 1982-83 Budget with the aim of upgrading roads in the States and the Northern Territory to reasonable standards by 1988. An excise surcharge was applied to motor spirit and distillate to provide revenue specifically for the road development program originally at 1c per litre until July 1983, when it rose to 2c per litre. Unfortunately we had an aberration in the voting pattern of the Australian people and we ended up with a Labor Government which in its 1983-84 Budget, introduced a system of half-yearly indexation of excise rates to include the new fuel levy. However, this additional revenue now flows to the Consolidated Revenue Fund, not to the road development fund for which the fuel levy was specifically originally intended. The consequent shortfall in revenue for the road development fund will amount to something like $491m by the end of the program. As we all know, the Labor Government was given ample opportunity to rectify this anomaly during the debate on the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill. In May 1984 the Liberal and National parties moved an amendment to the Bill to provide that the additional funds arising from the indexation of the fuel levy be paid into the road fund where they quite properly belong. The Labor Government showed how seriously it was committed to funding Australia's roads by combining with the Australian Democrats to defeat that amendment.

Honourable senators will recall Labor's election commitment to 'continue the greatest road building and maintenance program in Australia's history'. What have we seen? We have seen a reduction in real terms. In particular, I refer to the famous promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke):
Within the next three years, the national highway system will be brought to an all-weather, dust-free and flood-free standard.

Particularly in view of the conclusions of the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities study, it is very hard to have any faith in the ability of this program to fulfil those commitments. What is significant about this piece of legislation is not the level of funding, not the cuts, not the allocations between the main, arterial and local roads; rather it is the fact that it is consistent and in line with the legislation with which we have been dealing for the last two or three weeks in this Parliament, and it is another broken promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not another one?

—Yes, another one, and as Senator Rae quite properly said, it is very similar to the local government legislation we had before us this afternoon whereby revenues raised were pocketed. The moneys collected from the surcharge levy and indexation which was intended to go to roads has now gone into Consolidated Revenue.
—Plundering the public purse.

—That is right, the Government is plundering the public pocket and then splurging it on its crazy socialist schemes. We saw that with the legislation before us this afternoon in respect of local government, where the Government cut back on local government revenue and then asked that it increase its level of rates. We have a long litany of broken promises by this Government, of which I am quite sure the people of Australia will be very mindful at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I thank honourable senators for their support of the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Bill 1985. I think that, in general, the Senate is in agreement with the legislation. Senator Rae in his contribution raised the record of the Australian Labor Party in its support for roads. I simply point out to Senator Rae that expenditure on roads in 1985-86 will be 82 per cent higher than it was for the last full year of the Fraser Government, which was 1981-82.
—It is our program you are implementing, be honest.

—I do not think there is any argument about that. Senator Rae makes the point that the program was started under the Fraser Government. Of course I do not argue with that, but I point out that the actual level of expenditure is 82 per cent higher now than it was in the last full year of the Fraser Government. We have implemented the Australian bicentennial road development program as enacted during the Fraser Government's period in office. The question of indexation has been raised, and I point out that the Opposition refrained from writing indexation into the legislation when it had the opportunity of doing so. However, our Government has written indexation into this legislation so that the very greatly increased funding will now be maintained in real terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vigor, for the Australian Democrats, also supported the legislation and I thank him for it. I point out in regard to one of the matters he raised that the Government will require full compliance with its environmental legislation in considering projects for approval. Senator Crichton-Browne addressed the matter of Western Australia's share of road funds. Our Government has recognised the various State arguments for increased funding and accordingly we will establish an independent inquiry to recommend to the Minister for Transport the distribution of the unallocated 10 per cent share for arterial and local roads for years three to five of the Australian land transport program. I thank honourable senators for their support of the legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

The speeches read as follows-
BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT BILL 1985
The purpose of this Bill is to implement a number of recent government decisions regarding
the revision of broadcasting legislation to relate it to services rather than to technologies;
the licensing of services to outback areas utilizing Aussat satellites-the Remote Commercial Television and Radio Service or RCTS/RCRS;
changes to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's inquiry procedures additional to those passed in 1984;
the extension of some rights of appeal against decisions made under the Act; and
the deletion of some obsolete provisions of the Act.

I shall be shortly introducing related amendments to the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Act 1964 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Act 1964, as well as amendments to several other Acts consequential upon these amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act.

The proposed amendments can be summarised as follows: in relation to the service-based revision, the Bill will implement a Government decision to change the basis on which broadcasting licences are granted from a technological basis to a service basis-in other words, services will be licensed, and not stations. This will remove the need for extensive amendments to cope with any new technological development-a situation which in the past has militated against the introduction of new services.

Honourable senators will recall that amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act were passed last year to streamline the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's inquiry procedures by the automatic extension of licence periods pending completion of a licence renewal inquiry, and the formation of divisions of the Tribunal with power to make decisions on behalf of the Tribunal. The further amendments now proposed set out the framework of uniform procedures for Tribunal inquiries, with details to be prescribed in regulations. The Tribunal will be empowered to dispense with a public hearing where no substantive issues of public concern are raised. There will be provision for area inquiries so that the Tribunal may hold public hearings into the adequacy and comprehensiveness of licensed broadcasting services in an area, having regard to the diversity of interests of the area. As a consequence separate licence renewal hearings will only be necessary if substantive issues have been identified.

The Administrative Review Council has reported on rights of appeal against decisions made under the Broadcasting and Television Act, and the Government has decided to bring forward amendments to implement two of its recommendations.
The Bill will also delete obsolete provisions in the Act, which regulate the re-broadcast and publication of broadcast matter and the broadcasting of coded material.

The amendments contained in this Bill will not greatly alter either the costs or revenues of the Commonwealth. Initially the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will have to meet additional costs relating to changes in procedures and in complying with the new public access requirements, but in the long term the Tribunal will be enabled, by these amendments, to use its limited resources more efficiently and effectively. Likewise, the major revision of the Act to relate it to broadcasting services rather than the technological means of delivery of broadcasting signals will obviate the need to license subsidiary transmitters and translators. The savings in bureaucratic workload for applicants, the Tribunal and my department are obvious, but once again are difficult to quantify. There is expected to be an increase in Commonwealth revenue arising from the creation of additional categories of licences for remote radio and television services. However it is not possible to provide a realistic estimate of the extra revenue which may be obtained as the future revenues of remote licensees, which determine the amount of fees payable, is unknown. The other amendments which I have briefly outlined will not result in any significant costs, revenue or savings for the Commonwealth.

Mr President, this Bill, and particularly the service based provisions are the culmination of a substantial period of development and consultation which commenced in November 1983. Last year my department distributed several discussion papers to the Broadcasting Council and industry organisations. Discussions ensued with industry bodies and representatives of consumer and employee associations.
A number of the important provisions of the Bill will come into effect on proclamation and a significant amount of the procedural detail will be in regulations.

Consistent with the consultation approach, my department will be conducting a seminar on the Bill, in the near future, to explain its provisions and to provide a further opportunity for public and industry input.
I now turn to the detail of the proposed amendments.
(a) Service-Based Revision

I am sure I do not need to remind honourable senators of the complexity of the Broadcasting and Television Act. Indeed it is often referred to as one of the Commonwealth's most complex and difficult pieces of legislation. One of the reasons for this is that the legislation deals with difficult and often conflicting concepts of public interest and access to the limited public resource of the broadcasting spectrum for an industry of great influence in modern society. Given these circumstances, legislation must necessarily be complex and detailed to protect both public and private interests.

The other reason why this act is so complex and imposes unnecessary burdens on all who attempt to interpret it is because it is technology based. It was originally drafted to cover radio, and has had successively added to it provisions for television, subsidiary transmitters, public broadcasting, supplementary licences, and so on. The result has been an act which is unnecessarily confusing and repetitive. The amendments contained in the Bill will go a long way towards removing much of the present unnecessary complexity.

The Bill changes the basis of the legislation from technology to service. From its inception the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 has been a technology based act directed towards licensing and regulating various classes of radio, and later television, stations, each defined by reference to their technical characteristics; that is, the stations themselves, not the services they provide are licensed. It has become apparent, however, that placing legislative emphasis upon licensing broadcasting (Radio and Television) services for defined areas will remove unintended planning impediments, simplify and make more coherent the provisions of the Act, and facilitate the introduction of legislative provisions for new services arising from new technology including satellite technology.

The cornerstone of the service-based concept for planning and licensing is the service area for a licence; that is, the area containing communities which the Licensee is authorised to serve. From the licensing viewpoint, whether the broadcasting service is delivered by means of one transmitter, or a combination of transmitters, will be largely irrelevant. Emphasis will be placed upon the nature and purpose of the licensed service and the nature and interests of the communities in the service area. These concepts are already present in the licensing requirements of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Broadcasting transmission facilities needed to provide adequate reception within the service area will be authorised merely as technical conditions on the operation of the transmission facilities.

This change in the concept of licensing will remove the present duplication of planning and licensing procedures which places an unnecessary administrative burden on licensees, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, and my department. For example, under present arrangements, where a licensed station needs subsidiary transmitters to improve reception within its determined service area, translator station licence applications must be invited by the Minister and considered by the Tribunal. The existing Act in some circumstances prohibits translators even within a licensee's service area. This Bill allows changes to a licensee's transmitters to be authorised by the Minister as part of the technical conditions associated with the licence.

The supplementary licence provisions of the Act are already based on the concept of licensing services to a specified service area. Every effort has been made in the drafting of the service based licensing provisions of the Bill to make as little change as possible to the policy effect of the current Act. As far as these provisions are concerned the objective of Government is to change from a technologically based licensing system to a service based licensing system and not to introduce changes which are not consequential to the adoption of the service based licensing system.
The main features of the service-based amendments are as follows:

Broadcasting (Radio and Television) is to be regulated by reference to broadcasting services provided to communities within service areas rather than by reference to broadcasting stations defined by their technological characteristics;

The Minister will be empowered to designate (a) classes of licences by reference to the nature of the service, for example, commercial radio licence and commercial television licence, among others; (b) a service area or areas for the licence; and (c) all broadcasting transmission facilities necessary to ensure adequate reception by communities within the service area of the licence;
the technical specifications for the service area, the transmitters, frequencies, and so on, are to be included in a warrant which is issued by the Minister;
the licence to provide the service is issued by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

The Bill provides for a person other than a licensee to be authorised to operate one or more broadcasting transmitters specified on the licence warrant. However, I should emphasise that this third-party authorisation can only be given with the consent of the licensee. The effect of this provision is to shift responsibility from the licensee to the third party for a deliberate breach of technical conditions if the third party is not subject to control by the licensee.

Mr President, service areas will be determined by the Minister and notified to the tribunal. Changes to service areas may be made by the Minister after the publication of a notice of intention which must also be served on the licensee concerned. The Minister will be obliged to take into account any comments received on the intended variation. Because of the perceived importance of this definition of these areas the Minister will publish and table, guidelines which will be used in the determinations of service areas. While the Bill does not specifically provide for the guidelines or their publication a further amendment will be considered if it is found to be desirable to formalise the guidelines. The forthcoming seminar could consider this question.

The Bill creates a new category of licence to be called remote licences. These licences will enable licensees to provide commercial radio and television services to the estimated 650,000 people living in outback Australia, by means of the Aussat satellites, due for launch later this year.

The licences to provide for remote commercial services will differ in a number of ways from the existing licence provisions. Firstly, these licences relate to broadcasting services which are to be provided by the use of an Aussat satellite. Secondly, the public interest criteria which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal may apply to the granting or renewal of a licence are more widely expressed. The Tribunal is, for instance, obliged to take into account, when considering the 'public interest', factors such as the desirability that all Australians have the opportunity of receiving a commercial radio and television service, relevant government policy statements, matters prescribed in the regulations and such other matters or circumstances that the tribunal considers relevant. There is also the usual fit and proper person with the necessary financial, technical and management capacities concept as well as a prerequisite that remote licences may only be granted to an Australian company with a share capital or a consortium of such companies. There is no absolute prohibition on the concentration of ownership although the Tribunal must consider the need to avoid an undue concentration of ownership and control in the service area concerned subject to the objective of ensuring that all Australians have the opportunity to receive both a commercial radio and television service.

Two other new categories of licence, re-broadcast licences and re-transmission licences, should also be noted. Re-broadcast licences will enable persons such as self-help community groups to install transmitters to obtain or improve reception of one or more existing broadcasting services, while re-transmission licences will enable persons to install cable distribution systems to provide improved reception.

This Bill also creates the opportunity for licensees to provide a proportion of local programs and advertising on transmitters within their service area. Honourable senators should note that this amendment is a change to existing policy, in that at present all subsidiary translator stations are required to re-transmit the same signal as the principal transmitter. The proposed change is consistent, however, with the Government's policy of localism whereby broadcasting services should serve the needs of local communities. I expect that local origination will become an important part of programming for remote broadcasting services which will use the satellite to broadcast programs to widely separated communities.
Some concerns have been expressed about local origination, and to answer these concerns I make these three points:

The Tribunal will only approve of local origination for a licensee following application by the licensee and following the normal consultation process which will enable interested parties to put their views before the Tribunal;
The fact that a licensee has not provided locally originated programs will not be a ground for censure of the licensee for not providing an adequate and comprehensive service; and

The local origination provisions are subject to proclamation at a later date, and there will also be separate proclamation in respect of local origination for each licence category. This will allow the Tribunal time for consultation with industry and the public in the development of its policies and procedures.
(b) Australian Broadcasting Tribunal Procedures

As I mentioned earlier, two recommendations of the Administrative Review Council regarding Australian Broadcasting Tribunal procedures have already been enacted. These concern automatic extensions of licence periods pending completion of licence renewal inquiries, and the formation of divisions of the Tribunal with power to make decisions on behalf of the Tribunal.
The Government now proposes to implement other recommendations of the Administrative Review Council on the Tribunal procedures. Significant features of the proposed amendments include:
Inquiries into the exercise of any of the Tribunal's substantive powers will be conducted in accordance with a uniform inquiry procedure, the detail of which will be prescribed in regulations;
The uniform inquiry procedure will allow the Tribunal to dispense with a public hearing where no substantive issues of public concern are raised; and
There is provision for area inquiries so that the Tribunal may hold public hearings into the adequacy and comprehensiveness of licensed broadcasting services in an area.

The principal purpose of an area inquiry will be to enable the Tribunal to assess the performance of broadcasting licensees in meeting their obligations firstly, to provide an adequate and comprehensive service to the area, having regard to the nature and the diversity of the interests of the community in the area. Secondly such inquiries will enable the Tribunal to consider the extent to which licensees providing the services encourage the broadcasting of programs wholly or substantially produced in Australia and the extent to which they encourage the use of Australian creative resources. To fulfil the first of these aims it is expected that the Tribunal will seek information from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service on their services in a particular area to allow the Tribunal to assess the total broadcasting services in the area.
Area inquiries are linked to licence renewal inquiries as follows:

Area inquiries will normally be held every three years, prior to the expiry of the broadcasting licences in a particular area; it will therefore be desirable for the expiry dates of licences (both commercial and public) in each area to be synchronised. However, this will take some time, and will not be possible in all cases, for example, where the Tribunal decides to renew a licence for less than the normal three year period.

The Tribunal will normally commence an area inquiry after applications for renewal of licences in the relevant area have been received and after the closing date for submissions. All renewal inquiries will then be suspended until the area inquiry has been completed.

The area involved will be any area that the Tribunal considers appropriate but would normally be expected to correspond to service areas which are defined by the Minister. The flexibility is necessary to cater for area inquiries which may be desirable prior to the definition of all service areas and to permit the Tribunal flexibility in the interests of efficiency.

The Tribunal will not be empowered to exercise any of its regulatory or licensing powers during an area inquiry other than those which are necessary for the conduct of the inquiry itself. It cannot, therefore, determine whether or not, for example, a licensee has contravened a licence condition without holding a separate inquiry under the uniform inquiry procedure.

Once the area inquiry has been completed, the renewal inquiries will be recommenced. If there are any substantive matters outstanding in relation to a licence the tribunal will hold a public hearing into the renewal of that licence. In other cases, the licence can be renewed without any further hearing.

The Tribunal will have wide discretionary control over the conduct of area inquiries. Procedures will be similar to those already followed for inquiries directed by the Minister. The objective is a minimum of formality. Area inquiries will be held in public.

The tribunal will be required to report to the Minister on each area inquiry, and may include recommendations to the Minister on any matter arising from the inquiry. These may relate to undertakings made by licensees, the need for new or different types of services, changes in service areas, or a need to improve reception.

The provisions relating to area inquiries will be subject to a proclamation date separate from the remainder of the Act, to allow time for consultation with the industry and for the Tribunal to put the new procedures in place. The consultations will include the issue of whether there will be area inquiries into the adequacy and comprehensiveness of services provided before existing licences are made subject to the new licensing arrangements.
(c) Rights of Appeal against Decisions made under the Act

The Bill incorporates measures to implement recommendations by the administrative review council that appeals should be allowed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against ministerial decisions on two matters. These relate to the installation of beacon lights on transmitter masts, and the preservation of records of historical interest.

Honourable senators should note that the Government has asked the Administrative Review Council to review its recommendations and that licensing decisions made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should be subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Government has sought this review because the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's procedures have changed substantially as a result of recent amendments, and will change further if the amendments contained in this Bill are accepted. The introduction of this Bill's uniform inquiry procedure is expected to provide adequate safeguards against arbitrary decisions, or undue influence by particular groups.

If the Government had accepted the Administrative Review Council's recommendations outright, there would almost certainly have been a far greater number of appeals lodged, many of which would have been unnecessary or intended to delay implementation of a decision for commercial, political or strategic advantage. The Government is committed to making the Tribunal's procedures as streamlined and efficient as possible. Communities throughout Australia are anxious for new or improved broadcasting services, but the implementation of such appeal provisions could have led to serious delays in making decisions about licences which would have been to the detriment of both the general public and the industry.

The Administrative Review Council's recommendations that appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal be allowed against ministerial planning decisions have been rejected by the Government because such decisions involve complex issues relevant to general broadcasting policy. It would be inappropriate to allow decisions concerning elements of major Government policies to be subject to such external review.
Appeals on questions of law are, of course, available.
(d) Deletion of Obsolete Provisions of the Act
Sections 120, 121 and 123 of the present Act are no longer necessary, and it is proposed that they be deleted.

Sections 120 and 121 regulate the publication or re-broadcast of broadcast material. Section 120 constituted an unnecessary restraint on freedom of communication as licensees cannot authorise publication of their broadcasts without Tribunal approval. In regard to section 121, the Copyright Act 1968 already provides adequate protection, and one effect of this section has been to make uncertain the Tribunal's power to use videotapes as evidence in its hearings.
Section 123 of the present act regulates the broadcast of encoded material. This provision was enacted during the Second World War, and no longer serves any useful purpose.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's powers to make program and advertising standards have recently been thrown into doubt by a federal court decision. It had been the government's intention to bring forward amendments at this time to clarify and affirm the tribunal's powers to make standards. Because of concern about the possible effects of such legislation expressed by some sections of the broadcasting industry, I have decided not to delay the amendments I am now presenting by waiting for standards provisions to be finally settled. The Government considers that it is important that the provisions of the current Bill on service based licensing and the new uniform inquiry arrangements be introduced now to give some relief to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by providing for a more efficient system. Further, and most importantly, the Government considers that the new remote, or satellite licences should be provided for as soon as possible as the launch of Aussat's first two satellites are scheduled for launch in some 3 and 6 months respectively. To introduce new remote technology based licences in the absence of the service based system would be technically very difficult and wasteful. I now give notice, though, that it is the government's firm policy that the tribunal should maintain its powers to set both qualitative and quantitative broadcasting standards or conditions. I intend to bring forward amendments in the Budget sittings to give legislative effect to this policy. In the meantime, because of the government's commitment to a viable and flourishing Australian film and television production industry, I assure the industry and the Senate that the Government will take all necessary steps to maintain the industry. Should this require making the proposed legislation effective from the date of the minister's second reading speech in the other place, we will not hesitate to do so.

The Bill provides a scheme for the progressive conversion of old system licences to the proposed service-based licences. The provisions of the present legislation will continue to apply to existing licences until they are converted, as it will take some time for service areas to be defined for all licences. When the service area has been determined, the Minister will direct the tribunal to grant a new licence without the need for a fresh inquiry. The expiry dates of existing licences will not be affected. Inquiries into the renewal of 'old' licences commenced before the commencement of these amendments will continue and be concluded under the provisions of the present Act. Special provision has been made to require the tribunal to grant a remote licence to persons recommended by the tribunal pursuant to the inquiry directed by the Minister on 7 October 1984.

In the process of conversion of service areas, where the Minister proposes a service area not substantially co-extensive with the area presently served, the Minister will be required to publish a Gazette notice of the proposed service area variation, invite public and licensee comment and consider those comments.

These amendments repeal provisions for repeater television stations, consistent with the service basis of the new arrangements. The repeater provisions will continue to apply, however, to existing repeater stations. It is expected that licences for repeaters will not be renewed when the remote radio and television services are broadcast by a combination of satellite and terrestrial transmitters.

Honourable senators should also note a change to the ownership or control provisions resulting from the licensing of services rather than stations. The Act will continue to limit the services or licences which can be held in each State. Under present arrangements the location of a station is easily determined by the location of its principal transmitter. Under the proposed system, the Minister will publish a Gazette notice identifying the State of each service which overlaps State borders. In doing so, the Minister would have regard to the State of residence of the majority of people living in the service area.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1985

These amendments are purely formal and flow from amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act. For an explanation of those amendments I refer honourable senators to my second reading speech on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1985.

The changes to other acts consequential upon proposed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act are terminological rather than substantive. Thus, for instance, references to stations are changed to licences, and the tautological 'Broadcasting and Television' is reduced simply to 'Broadcasting', which applies to both radio and television.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BROADCASTING STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1985
I foreshadowed this Bill in my second reading speech on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1985.

As I explained in that speech, amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act Bill convert licensing and regulation from a Technology-basis to a service-basis. As a consequence references in this licence fees act to 'stations' will be anomalous. This Bill will amend the principal act to relate fees to licences for broadcasting services. Consistent also with the proposed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act, 'Broadcasting' will encompass both radio and television services, which, where appropriate, will be separately specified.
The substantive provisions of the Act, that is, the levels of licence fees, will continue unchanged.
As a transitional provision, the Bill provides for the existing licence fees Act to continue to apply to existing station licences until they are converted to licences for broadcasting services.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TELEVISION STATIONS LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1985
I foreshadowed this Bill in my second reading speech on the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1985.

As I explained in that speech, amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act will convert licensing and regulation from a technology-basis to a service-basis. As a consequence references in this licence fees act to 'stations' will be anomalous. This Bill will amend the principal act to relate fees to licences for broadcasting services. Consistent also with the proposed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act, 'Broadcasting' will encompass both radio and television services, which, where appropriate, will be separately specified.
The substantive provisions of the act, that is, the levels of licence fees, will continue unchanged.
As a transitional provision, the Bill provides for the existing licence fees act to continue to apply to existing station licences until they are converted to licences for broadcasting services.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

By this Bill the Government proposes to amend the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act. The amendments to these two Acts are part of the package to settle the doctors' dispute in New South Wales.

This Bill is a clear demonstration of the Government's conviction that disputes can only be resolved through consultation and negotiation, and not by confrontation. It is a substantial response to the concerns put forward by the medical profession about the impact of Medicare.

Some of these changes would have been implemented as a matter of course in the coming months, as the Government assessed Medicare's operations over its initial 12 months. The community should deplore the actions of a militant minority of procedural specialists in New South Wales, who created considerable pain and suffering in pursuing their political aims.

Fortunately they have not been successful. The changes put forward in this legislation are all sensible and rational changes to health insurance policy, and the basic principles of the Medicare program have not been altered. All Australians are still entitled to the 85% Medicare benefit for private medical services, and to free accommodation and treatment in public hospitals. The additional cost of the Medicare program remains substantially funded through the fair, income related 1% levy.

Mr President, I believe that the package to settle the doctor's dispute in New South Wales will ensure that the public hospital system continues to provide the best care by the best health care professionals. The great majority of doctors clearly support the Medicare arrangements as well as the package to end the dispute. This is evidenced by the national 75.6% vote for a return to normal services in the AMA plebiscite of all doctors, and the number of doctors who have now returned to work in New South Wales public hospitals.

One of the major points of contention between the Government an the medical profession in the past eighteen months, has been the existence and purpose of the amended section 17 of the Health Insurance Act since the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1983. That amendment required that an agreement approved by the Commonwealth Minister for Health must be in force for Medicare benefits to be payable for prescribed services provided in public hospitals.

The concern of the medical profession has generally not been what the Minister did with these powers, but the potential for what he could do at a furture date. Despite the excellent recommendations on this matter put forward by the Committee of Inquiry into rights of private practice in public hospitals chaired by Professor Penington, the continued existence of section 17 became a much misinterpreted symbol, around which unnecessary concern was generated.

In substance the major provision implemented through section 17 was to oblige the charging of the schedule fee for prescribed radiology and pathology services provided in public hospitals. This was to be further modified by the specific Penington recommendations in relation to billing review committees that would have provided peer review of hospital doctors' billing practices.

In order to assist in resolving a dispute that had become stalemated, at great human cost to patients in New South Wales, the Government is moving in clause 7 of this legislation to repeal all of the amendments to section 17 that were made as part of the Medicare legislation.

Mr President, the Government greatly appreciates the work undertaken by Professor Penington and his committee of Dr Cashman and Dr Kearney, many of whose recommendations will be incorporated in the legislation or taken up in consultation over the Medicare agreements with the States. For example, negotiations are being conducted with the States to amend the Medicare agreements to allow for the automatic classification of privately insured patients as private patients unless they specifically opt to be Medicare patients. This will address the problems being encountered under existing hospital admission procedures regarding patient election for private treatment which were addressed in Penington's recommendation No. 29.

Similarly, the Medicare agreements are to be amended to accommodate recommendation No. 32 which identified the need for new equipment in teaching hospitals. The Government's proposal to spend $150m over three years is clear evidence of its recognition of the position of teaching hospitals as the base of health care system. This injection of funds into teaching hospitals will help to correct the appalling legacy of inadequate funding left by the previous government when it abandoned the hospital cost-sharing arrangements and left no constructive arrangements in their place. States will be required to continue at least their current levels of capital funding to teaching hospitals and the public hospital system generally to ensure that the effects of additional Commonwealth support are not diminished by reduced funding by the States.
At a time of severe economic stringency, this allocation of extra capital works funds underlines the Hawke Government's unshakeable commitment to upgrading our public hospital systems.

At the heart of the dispute is the concern of doctors as to losses of income arising from the increased numbers of medicare hospital patients in public hospitals and reduced numbers of private patients. The Medicare compensation arrangements with New South Wales will incorporate proposals to share the cost of bringing the funding base for the payment of visiting medical officers on to a par with those enjoyed by other States under the former cost sharing arrangements. $10m per annum will be provided towards meeting 50% of the costs of sessional payments to visiting medical officers who currently provide honorary services without charge and for the extension of fee for service remuneration to country hospitals where there is no resident medical staff.

The Commonwealth has also indicated that it is prepared to meet the additional costs flowing from the introduction of fee for service remuneration for the treatment of public patients, in all but teaching hospitals. The fee for service remuneration is to be offered at the following rates:
85% of the schedule fee, where there are no resident medical officers or registrars at a hospital.
70% of the schedule fee, where a hospital has resident medical officers, but not registrars.
60% of the schedule fee, where there are registrars in the same discipline at the hospital.
Each of the broad disciplines of medical staff will be able to choose a remuneration method between fee for service and sessions. Within each of the major country and metropolitan district hospitals.

The New South Wales Government has already offered a $12.50 interim increase in the sessional rate to $62.50 an hour. Any further increase in the level of the sessional fee can only be made through the established arbitration procedures. However, the New South Wales Government has an adequate fund available to provide an increased number of sessions for medical staff in recognition of the increased number of public patients.

The total package provides the New South Wales Government with an additional $16m per annum from the Commonwealth for paying doctors, on top of the estimated additional $27m per annum provided for doctor remuneration under the Medicare agreement with New South Wales.

The additional State and Commonwealth funding brings the total amount of remuneration available for the treatment of hospital (or non chargeable) patients in public hospitals in New South Wales to $105m per annum.

I believe that both governments have acted fairly and decisively in addressing any reduction in incomes that could have occurred because of the shift from private to hospital patient status in public hospitals.

Mr President, the Bill provides for amendments to the National Health Act for the introduction of a more comprehensive hospital table to replace the existing basic table. The new basic private table will cover:
Accommodation charges in public hospitals as at present.
The difference between the Medicare benefit and the schedule fee for private medical services in hospitals.
Benefits for a defined list of surgically implanted items such as replacement joints, cardiac pacemakers and the like.
A new 'single day' hospital benefit for patients not required to stay overnight in hospitals and certain day hospital facilities.

The amendments to the National Health Act allow private health funds to offer insurance up to the level of the schedule fee for medical services provided in hospitals. This change recognises that people entering hospital for an operation as a private patient could be faced with a significant payment because of the multiple 'gaps' involved in a range of medical procedures. The medical profession regarded this as a significant disincentive for people to choose to be treated privately.

The risks of this additional coverage leading to overutilisation and increased charges for medical services is much less in the hospital setting. Peer review of medical procedures is well established in many hospitals, and billing practices for hospital based services will be closely monitored.

Both of the recent substantial examinations of aspects of health care in Australia-the Jamison and Penington Reports-have been clear in their opposition to the introduction of a general form of 'gap' insurance. It is viewed as undesirable because of its effect both on the utilisation of medical services and on doctors' billing practices. The authors of the reports would no doubt be less opposed to 'gap' insurance if it could be guaranteed that doctors would abide by a set level of fairly arbitrated fees.

However in the Australian situation where doctors are able to set their own level of fees, 'GAP' insurance would in most cases simply shift the 'out of pocket' payment from the difference between the Medicare benefit and the schedule fee, to a payment for charges in addition to the schedule fee. For these reasons this legislation only permits 'gap' insurance for medical services provided in hospitals, and the government would strongly oppose its further extension to cover all medical services.

The current medicare benefit arrangements, which provide for benefits at 100% of the schedule fee after 'gap' payments of $150 per person per annum are met, will continue in respect of non hospital medical services.

Clause 12 of the Bill also provides for the inclusion of benefits under the new basic private table for specified surgical implanted devices. This provision was recommendation 33 of the Penington Report. Presently, implanted devices are provided free of any additional charge to public and private patients in public hospitals. For private patients, surgical devices are regarded as part of the 'all inclusive' public hospital accommodation fee whereas they are charged as additional items by the private hospital or the specialist concerned, where the procedure is performed at a private hospital.

The Medicare agreements will be amended to allow public hospitals to raise separate charges for the specified implanted devices in public hospitals will be reduced. Because insured patients in private hospitals will be able to obtain benefits for implanted devices, a possible financial barrier to private hospital treatment will be removed.

The introduction of the 'single day' hospital benefit within the new basic private table follows arrangements that already apply in South Australia and the A.C.T. Extension of these arrangements to all States should assist in stabilising contribution rates by encouraging free standing day care facilities and day care in existing hospitals.

The establishment of surgical day centres has been a significant element of overseas strategies for reducing hospital costs, most notably in the United States. Until now this worthwhile innovation has been substantially discouraged by the insurance arrangements in Australia which provided benefits only to hospitals.

The Government is also taking this opportunity to coordinate fund benefit payments with Commonwealth bed day subsidy payments for private hospitals. In future, the new fund day care benefit will apply to all non-overnight stays, while a full fund benefit and Commonwealth subsidy will apply to overnight stays.

Mr President, those people who wish to have private hospital health insurance cover should be able to obtain it at affordable contribution rates and on reasonable terms and conditions. The only way this can be achieved is through the principles of community rating which ensures that the good risks assist in carrying the bad risks to equalise contribution rates. For this to occur there must be an adequate pool of good risks, and the costs of health care must be contained.

The Government has been concerned that the principle of community rated health insurance under which organisation registered under the National Health Insurance Act are obliged to operate, is being steadily eroded by cheaper ''risk-rated'' insurance being offered to good risks by insurers not registered under the National Health Act. The threat to community rated insurance not only comes from the risk rating life and general insurers but also from registered funds opting out of community rated insurance because of their concerns at the loss of good risks.

The Government recognises that in most areas of insurance, risk-rating is an appropriate commercial practice. However, health insurance has important social welfare implications that other forms of insurance do not have. The Government is committed to the concept of community rated health insurance, and for this reason clause 14 of this Bill requires all health insurers to comply with the requirements of the National Health Act.
In clause 15 legislative changes are proposed to facilitate the registration of commercial insurers. In particular, they will retain the right to distribute profits to shareholders.

Mr President, I do not believe that any existing risk-rated insurer who chooses to register will be disadvantaged in complying with the statutory requirement of maintaining reserves equivalent to at least two calendar months' contribution income. This should be well within the working capital capacity of any viable business undertaking. Similarly, I do not consider that the registration requirements of the National Health Act will place any administrative burdens on the insurers. If a body registers under the National Health Act, its health insurance activities will be subject to that Act only. The legislation also allows commercial health insurers to continue with contracts which are not cancellable and to discharge their normal liabilities. This will minimise any disruption to their policy holders.

Mr President, I draw the attention of the Senate to the provisions of the Bill which will allow registered health insurers to offer front-end deductible tables as an option to the new basic hospital table. This will be particularly attractive to those who now have similar cover with non-registered insurers, and to those who wish to undertake to meet the first part of the costs of illness in return for considerably lower premiums.

The lower contribution rates currently offered by commercial insurers derive from two major factors. Firstly, their membership is restricted to people below a certain age and those with chronic conditions are not admitted. The Government believes that these practices are discriminatory and totally undermine community rated health insurance. As I have indicated these practices will not be permitted following registration under the National Health Act.

The second factor that gives rise to reduced liability for the insurer is that commercial insurers require policy holders to meet the ''first part'' of their health costs, as set out in the terms of the insurance policy. This is a reasonable insurance practice that could contribute to some overall reduction in health costs, and the Government believes that it should be open to all health funds to offer this type of cover.

As this front-end deductible insurance will in future be offered through registered insurers, any profits that accrue from this form of business can be used to subsidise the basic table that most people will continue to insure under. In this way the benefit will not be lost of having the young and healthy contributing to the same risk pool as the elderly and the sick.

Of course, it may be expected that some risk rated insurers will not seek registration. As part of the arrangements to minimise any difficulties for those persons transferring from non-registered insurance and to assist others who may wish to contribute to private health insurance, the Bill provides that the general two month waiting period for basic table benefits to new fund members will be waived for a period of three months from 1 September 1985.

The current maximum exclusion from benefits for pre-existing illness will be reduced from two years to one year. Medibank private will totally waive the pre-existing ailment rule for three months to any of their former contributors who may wish to rejoin. Other health funds will be encouraged to do the same.

Mr President, the main financial impact of the package to settle the doctors' dispute will be from increased payments to the States-$16m per annum to New South Wales for increased remuneration to visiting medical officers and $150m to be spent over three years to upgrade the facilities and equipment in Australian teaching hospitals.

Additional costs of Medicare medical benefits will be incurred as a result of any increase in the numbers of private patients in public hospitals and a greater use in private hospitals. However, these will be more than offset by savings in Medicare compensation grants to the States arising from any shifts back from public to private status in public hospitals, largely because of the altered patient classification arrangements.

It is not possible to estimate with any degree of accuracy because of the numbers of variables involved, however it could be expected that net savings to government would result from any substantial movement back to private health insurance usage. Moreover, savings arising from the 'single day' hospital benefit, and from increased numbers of good risk contributors, are expected to dampen any increases in private health fund premiums. Most health funds are achieving surpluses on their operations and nearly all have reserves in excess of the statutory minimum. Accordingly many will be able to absorb at least some of the additional costs stemming from the changes to the basic table.
