Mr President, I believe that the Health Legislation Amendment Bill and the non-legislative changes to the Medicare arrangements announced by the Prime Minister on 2 April 1985, provide the right balance between maintaining the fundamentals of Medicare and recognising the legitimate concerns of the medical profession.

The overall package to settle the doctors' dispute allows flexibility of choice for patients, provides the opportunity for doctors to treat patients on a private basis, but ensures that there is no basis for discrimination against Medicare patients both in terms of the quality and availability of care in public hospitals.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Mr President, the Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1985 will amend the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the Postal Services Act 1975, the Radiocommunications Act 1983 and the Telecommunications Act 1975.

Provisions of this Bill will allow Telecom and OTC to enter into currency hedging and financial futures contracts. It will also enable Australia Post, Telecom and OTC to lease property for periods longer than 10 years without the need for approval of the Minister for Communications, providing the cost of the lease does not exceed the current prescribed contract threshold-presently $2,000,000 in the case of Telecom and $500,000 in the case of Australia Post and OTC. The Bill also provides for amendments to the Telecommunications Act arising from recommendations of the Vincent Report and imposes a duty on Telecom to ensure its facilities are not used for illegal purposes. Other provisions of the Bill give effect to the recommendations of the Bowen Committee relating to the disclosure of pecuniary interests by members of statutory bodies.
I will deal firstly with the currency and financial futures provisions of the Bill.

In line with the majority of large business enterprises, there is a need for Telecom and OTC to manage their foreign exchange exposure in a prudent and effective manner. As will be appreciated timing is critical in the placement of forward cover financial and foreign exchange contracts.

In the interest of efficiency, the Government believes it is inappropriate to require the Commissions to obtain approval for currency hedging or futures contracts when the main contract is either exempt from the requirement for Ministerial consent or has already received it. Currency contracts are negotiated and re-negotiated quickly in circumstances which make a requirement for Ministerial approval impractical.

This Bill will enable Telecom and OTC to respond efficiently to changing circumstances in financial markets but, at the same time, will prohibit any element of speculation by requiring dealings to be in accordance with guidelines to be determined by the Minister. Such an arrangement provides the flexibility necessary for commercial efficiency while ensuring the appropriate level of Ministerial control.

The Bill also repeals the requirement for Ministerial approval of property leases entered into by Australia Post, Telecom and OTC for periods in excess of 10 years. Where the consideration for such leases exceeds the prescribed contract threshold value the arrangements will fall within the contract approval provisions of the legislation and adequate control will continue to be exercised through that process. As appropriate, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services would continue to exercise approvals under provisions of the Lands Acquisition Act 1955.
I now turn to the other provisions included in this Bill.

In March 1984 the Government appointed Mr F. H. R. Vincent, QC to review certain allegations in regard to breaches of the laws of the Commonwealth, and impropriety or official misconduct by officers of Telecom. It is now a matter of public record that Mr Vincent concluded that the perception of substantial corruption within Telecom lacked anything remotely approaching an adequate evidentiary base and that any involvement by Telecom employees in SP betting was relatively minor.

The Government's detailed response to the matters raised by Mr Vincent was presented by the Special Minister of State on 13 September last year and it is not my intention to repeat the Minister's comments on this occasion. However, as part of the Government's response, this Bill will implement amendments to the Telecommunications Act arising from recommendations of the Vincent Report. Consistent with those recommendations, it is the Government's intention to incorporate into the Act those offences currently in the By-Laws and Regulations dealing with the misuse of Telecom's network, including the supply, connection and maintenance of lines, apparatus, equipment or fittings, and the alteration or modification of approved private branch exchanges and private lines. The offence provisions in the Act are also intended to cover the use of the telecommunications service for the purpose of menacing another person, the sending of false information, the harassment of a person and the sending of indecent, obscene or offensive communications. The Bill substantially increases the monetary penalties relating to these offences.

In a further response to the Vincent Report, the Bill provides that Telecom is under a duty, in performing its functions, to use its best endeavours to ensure that its network is not used in, or in the furtherance of, an offence under Commonwealth, State or Territory law.

Other provisions in the Bill include amendments to the present disclosure of interest provisions in the Overseas Telecommunications Act, the Telecommunications Act and the Postal Services Act in order to bring the relevant sections into line with Government policy on the disclosure of interests by members of statutory bodies. It also amends the Overseas Telecommunications Act to allow persons over 65 years of age to be appointed and hold office as Commissioners. The age limitation will apply only to the office of Managing Director, the only fulltime Commissioner.

Finally the Bill amends the Radiocommunications Act. It provides for an amendment to the present definition of 'radio transmission' in section 3 (1) by expanding the definition to include transmissions or emissions of electromagnetic energy of frequencies in the range 3 terahertz up to 420 terahertz. This amendment provides for the licensing of recently developed systems in the infra-red spectrum.

Section 65 of the Radiocommunications Act is amended by the Bill to remove the need to make regulations which would otherwise be necessary to protect Royal Flying Doctor Service radio services from interference. This amendment was considered necessary as the role of the Royal Flying Doctor Service is different in kind to the other organisations and services specified in this section of the Act.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1985STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating three education Bills-the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill and two allied Bills-which are being taken together in cognate debate. These Bills are supported by the Opposition. They seek to supplement the grants made for universities, for colleges of advanced education, for technical and further education and for schools to take account of the price movements of the last six months, and the Opposition certainly does not object to this. The Bills seeks to correct certain minor typographical and drafting errors which were present in the Bills which went through this place at the end of 1984. The Bills seek to make minor changes to the principal Acts. They have no significant policy implications and, again, the Opposition supports the measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Against the background of that support, however, I do wish to draw attention to a couple of matters concerning Australian education. On this occasion I will not talk about schools or issues relating to school funding but I will concentrate on some matters affecting the post-school area. The first matter concerns the funding for the participation and equity program. Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the fact that one of the Bills before us is the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1985, which deals with the participation and equity program and seeks to give it extra money. I remind the Senate that that program, which is the subject of one of the Bills before the chamber, was mentioned in the mini-Budget the other night when the Government announced that the funds available for spending under that program will be halved in 1986.

The Government has sought to use subterfuge to explain what will happen. Let me explain that the participation and equity program is a continuation of a previous program, the school to work transition program. Together these programs have been operating for some nine years and they have supplied a number of very important services to unemployed youth. If we accept that the Government's intentions have been carried out in relation to the participation and equity program, over the last year special attention has been given to unemployed youth who have been disadvantaged in various ways-who are handicapped, who are Aboriginal, who are non-English speaking and who are isolated. In addition, there has been a special emphasis upon including women in the programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —And mature students.

—And mature age students; I thank my colleague Senator Teague for his interjection. This program and its predecessor, the school to work transition program, have both provided very important services. It would be the expectation of every senator that these programs would continue and that funding for these programs would continue for the foreseeable future. It is really not good enough for the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, to say, as she has done in Question Time on several days, that the available funds have been spread between 1986 and 1987. We would have expected that the program would have continued into 1987 anyhow. Senator Ryan stated in Question Time that there has not really been a cut. She actually had the effrontery to say:

SPEECH.PARA: So the amount of money available for the program over a two-year period will not be decreased at all-it will be a four-year program instead of a three-year program. Whereas in some respects that is to be regretted, it is inaccurate for Senator Baume to suggest that the money available under the program will overall be any less. It will not.

That is not true. The easy way to test whether or not it is true is to ask some of the groups who depend upon the program what their perception is and to ask some of those who teach in the participation and equity program what their perception is. Do they believe Senator Ryan's statement that there will not really be less money or is it their perception that this was an ongoing program delivering essential services? The level of the services to be offered in 1986 will be cut probably by half and the level of services to be provided in 1987 will be maintained at that lower level of activity.

All I want to get on the record is that in this mini-Budget, where Labor took certain steps which had to be taken to cut expenditure and where it said that in making those cuts it had due regard to protecting the disadvantaged and those in special need, it has managed to make one of the most spectacular cuts and to impinge disadvantage most particularly upon the powerless, uneducated, disadvantaged unemployed who have looked to this program as a special source of hope and some prospect of a future. I want to place on record my request that Senator Ryan at least come clean and say that. I want to make clear to the Senate that I can imagine the anguish she went through in Cabinet. I can imagine that she was rolled in Cabinet on this matter and that this cut was hung around her neck; but it is a cut and it is not possible to argue it in any other way. I am not saying that the Government should not have made cuts; not at all. I am merely saying that it should be pointed out that while the Australian Council of Trade Unions, we senators, the powerful and those who are employed have by and large been spared the effects of the cuts, those cuts have been targeted on these disadvantaged groups as an act of policy by this Labor Government.

There is no doubt that within the technical and further education sector and the disadvantaged schools around Australia which have been the recipients of funds under PEP, there is a very clear perception of where the cuts have fallen and on whom they have fallen. I am reminded of the words of Kipling, when he said:
The toad beneath the harrow knows
Exactly where each tooth-point goes;
The butterfly upon the road
Preaches contentment to that toad.

I would suggest that Senator Ryan is rather like the butterfly preaching contentment, but it is a bit difficult if she is the person beneath the tooth-point of the harrow. Those are a few words about the participation and equity program.

I would also like to identify the real squeeze that is occurring in higher education in Australia and the effects it is having in limiting access and opportunity. Heady promises were made prior to the 1983 election, but in spite of those promises the last two years have seen a very tight squeeze applied to tertiary education funding; so tight that some of the people who are active in the higher education sector-academics and students alike-have declared that their sector is at risk. There is no doubt that the Government found it very difficult even to contemplate accommodating some of the recommendations made by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in its first volume report for the three years 1985-87. In that report the Commission made it clear that if Labor's avowed goals of participation and activity in the tertiary sector were to be met, considerable extra expenditure would be required. The Tertiary Education Commission set out what those levels of expenditure would have to be. The CTEC was responding to the program which the Government had laid down while soliciting votes in opposition; a program it said it wanted achieved. So volume 1 was in fact an attempt by the CTEC to spell out the financial implications and consequences of the Government's announced policies.

The moderate nature of the CTEC recommendations is evidenced by the fact that they were very much less than the recommendations that came up from the universities councils, the advanced education councils and the TAFE councils; yet the Government has ignored the advice of the CTEC. The Government has provided only marginal funding increases for the higher education sector, and by the end of the triennial the Government's guidelines will provide allocations some $100m less than was recommended by the CTEC and some $210m less than those recommendations made by the councils. Of course, we all know that bids made to government are sometimes in the nature of an ambit claim and government has to assess whether the bids are reasonable and, in the end, has to make and be responsible for the final allocations.

It is fair enough to ask what has been the effect of the funding provided to tertiary education for the triennial. The real impact of these inadequate allocations has been clearly expressed in the number of dollars available for every student place, because as the places are increased one would expect more money to be provided. The Government's proposals are for the funding of additional student places at about $4,500 a place, a figure which is far below the absolute minimums of $5,700 for universities and $5,125, which were the levels set by the Advanced Education Council and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission. So even when the Tertiary Education Commission cut back what it saw as the bids and came up with what it considered to be the minimum level of funding for higher education, the Government still decided to fund extra places way below that.

This means that new students will not be able to gain access to quality higher education unless academic staff work loads increase or unless other areas of expenditure within the sector-for example, the provision of library services-are further reduced. The marginal funding-it is really short run marginal funding-of new student places is a breach of faith by the Government. It will penalise precisely those groups on which the Government allegedly depended for support-young people, the socio-economically disadvantaged and Aboriginals, all of whom were supposed to be the recipients of special educational attention. So marginal is the estimated rate of increase in student numbers that, in fact, it is possible that participation rates could conceivably fall over the triennium.

I remind the Senate that the Government promised that there would be an extra 25,000 students by 1990, but the guidelines under which we are working and to which some of these funds in the Bills refer are committed to an increase of only 1,400 in total student load in 1985. The pipeline effect-that is, the same number in 1986 and the same number in 1987-will mean that there will be an extra 4,000 new places by the end of the triennium. Any new places are welcome, but the Tertiary Education Commission advised the Government that a real increase of 1,100 a year in student load was required just to keep pace with demographic change-with the increase in population. An increase of 1,100 was required just to stand still. The Government is providing only 1,400 new places a year. As I say, the figure will be 4,000 at the end of the triennium. Only a slight reduction in the 1,400 a year will mean a negative real growth rate and a fall in participation rates. This will be accentuated by the fact that participation in the upper levels of secondary school education is increasing. The number of students presenting themselves for the final examinations to qualify for matriculation is increasing. The number of students qualifying for matriculation for university and college entrance is increasing and the number of extra places is not sufficient.

The tragedy in Australia is not only that we are providing too few places but also that there are no alternative ways into the system for these people unless they leave the system and return later as mature age students. That is one very satisfactory way to go about it. I might say that in my family we have a mature age student doing very well after being able to get back into the system in this way. But it is still true that there are not enough places for those who complete their schooling and look for further educational opportunity as one of the chances to improve themselves and to participate in a modern Australia, a skilled Australia, an Australia where the acquisition of skills will help not only them but the whole community. This situation is impossible to reconcile with the Government's stated commitment to increased access and to increased participation. The Government is obviously embarrassed by this state of affairs because the Minister has actually attempted to comment on it. In talking about the increased numbers and the increased money she said:
. . . The increase of $65.15 million for tertiary education in 1985 would allow for 15,000 extra places in higher education by 1987--
I repeat 15,000-they were the Minister's words-
. . . (which) would enable increased participation by women and girls in higher education fields of study such as science and technology.

This is simply not true. There simply will not be 15,000 new places. The Minister may say so, but it is not true. All one has to do is go around again and ask the institutions, in the same way as we asked them how many students were turned away and in the same way as they measured and found that this year 29,500 students were turned away from higher education, from colleges and universities. To put that figure of 29,500 into perspective, it means that two large university campuses of almost 15,000 students each do not exist. That many students were turned away, with no chance to participate and no other way into the system. As I have said, the Minister's figures have been refuted by the Federation of College Academics, which has pointed out:

In fact 15,000 'extra' will not be created by 1987-the guidelines make provision for only an additional 4,000 places over the triennium. Moreover, it appears likely that even these growth projections are overly optimistic.

Those are the words of the Federation of College Academics. We have had statements by Mr David Hester, the Chairman of the Joint Matriculation Committee of Adelaide and Flinders universities. He has suggested that funding within the faculty of law-I am not sure of which university-may have to be cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —The University of Adelaide.

—Funding for the University of Adelaide law faculty may actually have to be cut because of the squeeze on places and on resources. The University of Adelaide Law School actually voted to cut its quota by one-third because it was worried about the squeeze on places and on the student-staff ratio. What worries me is that the squeeze on funding will affect adversely current staff and students. David Hester points out that the faculty of arts at Adelaide University faces a large increase in the size of tutorial classes because of the lack of staff. He points out that it will have to discontinue employing part time tutors because, with the funds available, it will commence with a negative general teaching fund after the full time tutors have been allowed for. So, before it even starts, it cannot take on any part time tutors and will actually have to sack or otherwise lose some people who are employed full time. The problem is not an isolated one. For all of the 1960s and 1970s the student-staff ratio was never higher than 12 students to one staff. Now it is closer to 13 to one. This is a direct result of the funding squeeze which is going on and which has been exacerbated in the last couple of years.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation in the areas of capital and equipment funding is no better. I will not go through those, but the figures are just as bad and the squeeze has allowed nothing new to happen. The squeeze has also been applied to academic salaries. Last year the Government took the appalling and unprecedented step of intervening for a second time before the Academic Salaries Tribunal, which led to the Tribunal overturning its previous decision to award a 5 per cent salary increase to academics and, instead, to delay some of that increase. So, for example, those academics who retired during the phasing-in period have for the rest of their lives lost part of a salary increase which was granted by a tribunal, in a properly argued case, after the Government and the unions had presented their cases and the unions had won. The Government used its muscle, in direct abrogation of a solemn election promise that it would abide by the decisions of the Academic Salaries Tribunal. It really showed a flagrant disregard for the independence of a tribunal which it had lauded so much before it came to office.

Of course, the students have also been the victims of the squeeze. The Government has found sufficient funds to raise the unemployment benefit but it has not allocated new funds of anywhere near as much to raise the level of the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance for students who are 18 years old or over. This meant that the gap between the maximum TEAS allowance payment and the single unemployment benefit has more than doubled since Labor came to office. In addition, there has been little easing of the means test on parents. Those of us who listened to the mini-Budget the other night will know that parents have now been singled out as one of the groups to bear some of the brunt of the mini-Budget, with the family allowance having been abolished for students 18 years and over.

It is not surprising that six education unions representing 200,000 academics, teachers and students have begun sustained campaigns against this Government-the Government they worked so hard to elect-because of the way it has treated tertiary education. This year we could see the unprecedented situation where these unions and students take industrial action on campus against a government which they supported before the election to try to reverse what they see as an intolerable squeeze on funds. I am concerned to see tertiary education healthy and flourishing because it is one of the avenues to a better Australia for everyone.

This nation, by and large, is underskilled; its skills will provide the cutting edge and security to allow us to compete and succeed in what is an increasingly hostile world in the post-industrial era. For that to happen, we must be sure that no properly qualified Australian finds himself or herself unable to get access to any education or training when he or she finishes schooling. Sadly, that is not so at present and the funding policies of the Government, part of which are contained in this legislation, do not indicate that the situation will ease. The Opposition supports the Bills although it has some very real reservations about what is happening to education in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a series of States grants education Bills. Such Bills come into the Senate twice a year to provide funds to State governments for schools, specialised programs such as the participation and equity program, and tertiary institutions. Various items in the legislation, as Senator Peter Baume has indicated, are somewhat overshadowed by the announced cuts in education funding. I want to look at some of those cuts that the Government has announced since they affect these Bills. In many respects, the cuts could be termed cheap. They are probably what the New Statesman called recently the 'grocerist deviation'. They bear no relation to the education policies announced by this Government. They have been supported by no analysis by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) of why they are necessary for education and they do nothing other than save a few dollars at great cost, especially to the youth of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember well an exercise that took place under the Fraser Government-the razor gang exercise-in which education decisions were also made that had no bearing on education, no support and no analysis. They were the amalgamation proposals, which also appeared in a cutting Budget. A post hoc rationalisation was then generated after is was discovered that this decision had been taken. It is a pity that these types of education policies are made and such decisions taken in an exercise of cutting costs rather than in an exercise of educational support. The instance of the participation and equity program illustrates this well. On 3 September last year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in announcing the participation and equity program, said:
One of the cornerstones of the Labor Government's education policy . . .
That was what it was, one of the cornerstones of Labor's educational policy. Mr Hawke went on to say:

addressing our concerns about equality of opportunities; about more equal outcomes for those traditionally neglected in Australian education and training systems; and about the relevance of schooling and curricula.

That was, indeed, a very rousing statement. What do we have in the mini-Budget? We have that rousing program hacked by 50 per cent. The spurious reason given by the Government was that cutting PEP spending in half and spreading the original amount over two years will 'provide time for greater attention to the development of the program, especially in areas such as curriculum change and the targeting of schools'. I am not sure who wrote that but I think that person should be given a special Brownie point for thinking of that excuse for that exercise. We all know precisely what that decision will do to the various people who have been putting forward programs.

Enthusiasm has been generated by this Government to get courses under way, particularly in technical and further education, in support of the types of things the Government has been talking about. People have been working hard in devising curricula. They have been going through the normal accreditation processes to have these courses accepted. They have been working on a variety of support mechanisms which are necessary for any course that is undertaken at that level. Now they have been told that the Government is going to spread out funding over a couple of years so that it can provide greater attention to the development of the program. That is a rationalisation which nobody in education accepts. That was suggested to a group of people who have been working in this area. After the laughter died down, they said quite seriously that that was the last time they would ever be conned by government.

The Government, particularly in terms of TAFE, not only hacked about at the participation and equity program in regard to schools. Of course, $19m of the $41m comes from the TAFE sector. This is the sector which the Government has said will have to provide 75,000 new traineeships by 1988. Demands are made, proposals are set out, goals are laid down and then the money is cut. It is an interesting exercise in something not meeting. We are buying ourselves very expensive tertiary institutions. By that I mean that we have a base operation in our universities, colleges of advanced education and TAFE colleges which is necessary just to keep the institutions going. We have highly qualified staff who are necessary to support those institutions and who have been paid for, by and large, by Australian dollars. It is now proposed to put all of that exercise once again on the back burner.

Of course, TAFE is easily the most under-resourced sector of the educational system. In addition to that $19m in terms of PEP there was another $12m or 9.3 per cent reduction in the TAFE capital works program. I raise the point-I wish at least to have this on the record-that one can look at the fire which occurred recently in Britain and the number of people who died. In the following few days people were saying that they had been warned. This is the third occasion on which I have raised this issue. Existing in our TAFE institutions, CAEs and universities in Australia are innumerable fire traps, each one of which has been documented, and that documentation has been provided to the Government. I fully expect that at some time in the future there will be a massive tragedy in one of our tertiary institutions. It is not a matter of if; it is simply a matter of when. When one looks at some tertiary institutions-I have travelled around every State and looked at them-one comes across lecture theatres with no access other than one door which leads into a narrow corridor. Often there are 300 or 400 people in those lecture theatres. I suppose that when we have such a massive tragedy the same types of excuses as those brought forward in Britain will be brought forward. Is it not interesting that probably we will have to sacrifice a few hundred tertiary students, who will be burnt to death in the most horrible circumstances, before any action is taken to get rid of these fire traps that the Government has had on record as existing for nearly two years?

What do we get? We get a 9.3 per cent reduction in the capital works program, all of which could easily have been used simply in providing some safety for buildings, particularly those on TAFE campuses, but also those on the campuses of colleges of advanced education and universities. That is quite apart from any new buildings or proposals that would be necessary to take up the types of increases the Government has made. I refer to the last election when the Government said: 'Look at the new numbers who will be able to be accommodated in our tertiary institutions'. However, I will come to that matter shortly. Quite apart from the educational consequence of removing $20m from the TAFE budget, one wonders what the economic gains and benefits are supposed to be. Precisely what are we arguing here?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very good question.

—A very interesting article appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. If the Minister is interested perhaps he might listen instead of reading his papers. The article reported an official linked with the program as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The PEP program, started last year, is a key tool in helping reduce unemployment and increasing the employment skills of the long-term young unemployed.
That seems to be a fair proposal. It is the type of proposition and rhetoric the Prime Minister has been putting forward. The article continues:
Between 50 and 90 per cent of youngsters taken into these programs have obtained work as a result. The decision to halve the program is a disaster for the young unemployed who need to acquire skills.

The rationale given by the Government was precisely that it wanted to give these skills to young people. The Government has said that young people need those skills. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has managed to carry out an exercise which I thought was confined to Liberal education Ministers, that is, to go on television condemning schools and saying that they really ought to pull up their socks-that they are probably one of the causes of unemployment. If the Prime Minister wants to run that line, that is fine. However, if he does not want to provide the resources it would be fair to say so on the same program. It is the Government which has raised the expectations. It is the Government which has been putting in the programs. It is the Government which now proposes to cut them back. There are not likely to be any benefits from these cutbacks. The long term disillusionment that will be created and the long term damage that will be done will far exceed anything like $20m in terms of the Australian economy. It could not possibly be limited to that amount.

If one looks at the attempt to provide 75,000 new traineeships by 1988, one is confronted with the fact that what they could provide to the Australian economy would far exceed $20m. Yet if students do not have those types of skills, if they are not provided with those types of advantages, the cost to the Australian community will make $20m look like chicken feed. Quite simply, PEP was the Government's flag ship. It has just been sunk by the Government.

What about the other types of promises that were made by this Government? Senator Baume raised the issue of the number of places available in tertiary institutions. The Government promised to increase the number of places in higher education by 25,000 by 1990. People may not remember that promise, as it is nearly three years old. That promise actually ended up being modified to an extra 15,000 places through that brilliant public relations work that went on. Again, I hope that the person who wrote that speech was promoted because I thought that was a brilliant piece of work as well. Of course, it did not fool anybody in the education institutions but it seemed to get a reasonable run in the Press, and I suppose that is all that matters.

The Government now has clearly shown its hand. There are 4,000 new places for the next triennium. The target of 15,000 has been abandoned or wiped out. Not only that, but as we see from the report presented today by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission-a very conservative report-10,000 demands for places were not met.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in higher education only.

—Yes. We have the very conservative report from the University of Queensland commissioned by CTEC. It discounted on every point. It came up with 4,000 places for the University of Queensland alone in the next five years. What we are looking at is certainly an absolute minimum of 10,000 places. I do not think anybody can disagree with that. The Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee and the Australian Committee of Directors and Principals suggest that that is the bare minimum we are looking at. I would suggest that a more realistic figure is in the vicinity of 20,000 to 25,000. Even if we take the bottom line-even if we take 10,000 people-what an extraordinary waste by putting aside those people who could obviously contribute so much to the future growth of our type of economy.
—Even a hundred.

—Even 100. The Government also made a range of promises with regard to student assistance under the tertiary education assistance scheme. It was going to bring it up to the level of the unemployment benefit and liberalise the definition of independence under which a student who supported himself or herself could quality irrespective of the parent's income. The two main promises were to increase assistance to the level of the unemployment benefit and to liberalise the definition of independence. What do we have? The reality is that, far from increasing the level, it is now $14 less. The gap was $5 when the Liberal Government lost office. It is now $14. The gap has widened and not closed. Has the Government kept one out of its two promises? The provisions with regard to independence are now much more rigid. Last week's mini-Budget announced:

SPEECH.PARA: Applicants seeking dependent status under TEAS and ASEAS on the basis of work experience will be required to provide evidence of the equivalent of two years full time work in the last three instead of the last five years at present. This change will result in the saving of $1.5m in 1985-86 and $2.9m in a full year.
In other words, the Government's score on promises on TEAS is nil out of two.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even nil out of three.

—If we go through all the promises made we find exactly the same thing. I will just run briefly through some of the other cuts. English as a second language, picked out as needing to be one of the priority areas, got a 4 per cent cut. Special education, picked out to be one of the special areas needing attention, got a recurrent 6.3 per cent cut; integration, a 6.6 per cent cut. Multicultural education, picked out to be one of the special areas to be looked at, got a 4 per cent cut. Of course, I have already mentioned the capital works program, a 9 per cent cut.

SPEECH.PARA: What about research? The Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), has been a very strong advocate of research in Australia. This has certainly been demonstrated in his speeches in this regard over the years that I have been in this place. What is the Government's record in regard to research? The Government promised 300 post-doctoral scholarships; it has delivered none. Of course, the Government's contribution to the nation's research has been to cut-not increase-the budget by $24.9m. The Government has cut the funding for industrial research and development by $9.6m. Of course, we know that post-graduate students contribute on their own up to 50 per cent of all published research works in this country. Yet, we have cuts in two major areas-in the amount of money available and in the fellowships available. Those post-doctoral people are getting a smaller and decreasing percentage and attempting to support themselves and their families on allowances which are now below the poverty line in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shouldn't you be careful to avoid getting an awful spray from me in the Budget session? Shouldn't you be worried about what will happen in the Budget context before you get too judgmental about it?

—What I am discussing are the Bills before the chamber. In fact, I am discussing the cuts announced by this Government, which are now included in these Bills. If we look at what I think has to be seen as the hidden cost of the exercise-Senator Baume alluded to this fact in his speech-we find that in every tertiary institution in Australia two things are happening. Firstly, we find that the normal contact hours available to any student have decreased alarmingly. For example, at the Canberra College of Advanced Education the hours in the two courses that I inquired about have been reduced from 21 hours to 10 hours and nine hours. That seems to suggest that it is something that is going on not only there but elsewhere. I have checked a number of universities and CAEs in my own State and in the State of New South Wales and I believe that that exercise is probably Australia-wide.

SPEECH.PARA: There are hidden costs and hidden squeezes resulting from the fact that so-called new places are not being funded to the level that it is costing the institutions to keep the places open and filled by students. Hence, savings have to be made. If an institution has a certain number of permanent staff and a certain number of students the area where savings can be made is fairly obvious-part time, non-tenured and tutorial staff have to be cut. That means one thing-it is necessary to decrease the number of contact hours. Therefore, we find that in some professional courses in Australian universities the number of contact hours has been cut in the last two years by over 50 per cent. We are expecting those students undertaking such courses to meet the same level of proficiency without having the type of contact which has always been considered absolutely essential in the past.

Secondly, we find a rise in the number of students in tutorials. It is now a commonplace expectation that a student will go into a tutorial with at least 20 to 25 other students. I think when a number of honourable senators went to university they would have expected to attend lectures with only 20 to 25 students. This is now the number of people in tutorials. Tutorials are supposed to be an adjunct to lecturers to enable an exchange between lectures and students, to follow up the thoughts, ideas and points raised in lectures, and to discuss them in some detail. That cannot be done in a tutorial with those numbers. It is impossible to do that. Basically the situation renders that exercise nothing more than a farce and no more than a mini-lecture which the students and staff have to go through because it represents the only contact hours which are available to them. That type of exercise does not appear in a balance sheet. It does not register in dollars and cents anywhere that we can actually get at, but it must register in the quality of the courses that are being conducted in tertiary institutions. Undoubtedly it has to. This means that the quality of those courses cannot do anything but suffer and the quality of the degrees cannot do anything but decrease. This is at a time when we are required to lift our game to compete in the international market and to compete as hard and as fast as we can in a basically information-based society.

The exercise we are going through stems from a view that I know is not shared by everybody in the Government but I know is certainly shared by some because they have expressed it in this place often enough; that is, to view the education enterprise in Australia as a cost to the taxpayer rather than as an investment by the taxpayer. We come into this place and talk quite happily about spending money, investing money in our roads and railways. For example, today we provided another $70m to the Australian National Line, and we covered a number of other exercises. We see those as investment in Australia's future.

When we look at the distribution of moneys in the Budgets of countries that are still doing well in the international market place it is interesting to find the percentage of total gross national product rising. I use that figure because I think it is the fair figure. I say it is a fair figure because Australia has a peculiar education system which is funded almost exclusively at the tertiary level from governments, and that is not the case in competitive countries. Private enterprise actually funds to a much greater extent in the United States of America, Great Britain, Japan, West Germany, the Scandinavian countries, and in almost every European country than it does in Australia. That is something which is peculiar to our history. It is not an excuse for the Government to say that other countries, in terms of government contributions, are necessarily funding at around the level we are doing in Australia, because private enterprise in those countries also maintains a role in these areas. It does not in Australia and it never has, for a variety of reasons. Hence I believe the obligation still falls very heavily on the Government in Australia to provide those types of resources for our young people and for their education. It is not only for them. I rejected the idea that was bandied around to a great extent during the last years of the Fraser Government, and seems again to have crept into the ideology of the current Government, that education is a private good. Undoubtedly, education does provide-certainly in Australia it provides very directly-goods to the individual; but it also happens to be a public good. If that is not accepted, I think the Government has to give some educational and economic rationale as to why it does not also seek to look at the schooling exercise and say: 'Why are we providing funds there? Why can't people provide their own funds for schooling?' If we start off by saying that we believe every citizen in this country ought to have a basic education as a right, we are doing it because we believe it benefits the country enormously. If we do it at that level, a fortiori we have to say that at the tertiary level it is also the case.

I think these cuts were shortsighted. The Minister, by way of interjection, was urging me to wait for the Budget. I am not at all sure whether people in the community are all that willing to wait for the Budget, having seen this particular exercise. I think waiting for the Budget becomes a matter of fear and trepidation and not of hope.

I think we now have an enormous amount of disillusionment in the education sector; we have a lack of morale in the tertiary institutions. All that we have is an increasing despondency that we are again back in those years through which we have suffered so recently of simply dawdling at the tertiary level. The advent of the Labor Government raised hopes extraordinarily in this area. The Labor Government made promises in 1983 and again in 1984 very clearly and very directly to all education sectors in Australia. The Labor Government made a number of promises which were clear, unequivocal and which would have worked well for the education community and for the Australian community as a whole. The fact that it has now not only reneged on those promises, but also engaged in further cuts in education has caused massive disillusionment. I think that the education community feels that the Budget will simply continue the trend which has now set in, that what we will see in the Budget is further cuts to tertiary education and a further contraction in the number of young Australians who will be able to undertake tertiary education in Australia and be able to develop their skills for the benefit of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I feared for a while that Senator Macklin was going to speak until the Budget was brought down; at least it seemed that way to me. Today we are debating the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, the States Grants (Tertiary Education) Assistance Amendment Bill 1985 and the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill 1985. The purpose of the Bills is to provide cost supplementation for various education programs and to make some minor technical amendments to the relevant Acts. As such the Bills are not controversial and have the support of the Opposition. However, the passage of the Bills provides the Senate with an opportunity to examine some of the programs covered by the legislation and more broadly the overall effectiveness of our system of education in achieving its primary goal, namely, to give individuals the maximum choice and the necessary skills to pursue their chosen careers and thereby contribute in a meaningful way to Australia's economic performance.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments today will largely relate to the government education sector since this sector has the responsibility for educating about 75 per cent of our population, although there has been a significant shift away from the government sector in the last decade, particularly in the secondary area. A cursory glance at our education system reveals that there is something rotten in the state of Denmark, despite the many claims of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to the contrary. Associate Professor David Cohen of Macquarie University made the following statement:
Secondary schooling is failing to educate. It is riddled with dissatisfactions and remains a disastrous, chaotic disjointed jungle.

According to Bob Gottliebsen, a journalist with wide experience in both the business and education fields, it is now clear that the education system of some of our trading partners is producing students who have far greater skills than our own. Even more damning is the following claim:

Whilst attention has been focused on our manufacturing industry, and the need for restructuring, we overlook other areas where performance has been lamentable. Australia has been very badly served by its education system, for example. How can we become competitive given the quite inadequate performance of this important sector. If manufacturing has to undergo a painful process of restructuring; if manufacturing has to be competitive; then we must also look at other areas where protection has led to lamentable performance.

This statement comes not from the 'right wing' academics, such as Lachlan Chipman or Greg Sheridan, whose views are well known, but none other than the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, speaking last year. Even more arresting is the following observation:

In a hard, competitive world we do not do service to our young people by throwing them to the wolves completely unprepared for the responsibilities they are expected to carry. We must face up completely honestly to the question whether the present-day education system is adequate to the task: to whether it is of such quality that we can be confident of our children's future. Frankly I have my doubts.
This statement was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in September last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I liked mine better.

—I did too. There is ample evidence that such views damning our education system are shared in the wider community by teachers in universities and colleges who train the products of the system, by businesses which employ them and, more important, by parents who care for them.
—Is the Prime Minister still in the country?

—I believe he is in the bunker. Parents are voting with their feet by increasingly sending their children to non-government schools, often at great financial cost. Recent surveys, particularly here in the Australian Capital Territory, reveal that many more parents would do likewise if they could afford it. Queues for private schools are growing.

SPEECH.PARA: The problems we face are serious-youth unemployment of nearly 30 per cent in some States; low participation rates in tertiary education compared with our major trading partners; and low retention rates at the secondary school level, particularly in the government sector. Now we pay students simply to stay on at school, yet we cannot find places in our tertiary institutions for many of the young people who are persuaded to stay on until Year 12. Senator Baume tabled in the Senate some time ago a survey executed by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee and this indicated that, of 29,000 students, about 21 per cent who were eligible for places in colleges of advanced education were not able to find places. The system is suffering from inconsistency and overload. We are not giving our young meaningful life choices and our economy is suffering.

Unfortunately, much of the education debate is couched in ideological terms which fail to focus on the issues which concern most parents-the value they are getting for their educational dollar, whether paid in taxes or school fees or both. They are rightly concerned about such issues as the move away from public examinations, one of the few means by which teachers can be held accountable to their customers. They are concerned about the disturbing move away from traditional subjects which teach skills which benefit all students in pursuing whatever careers they choose. Such a move has already been tried in the United States and it has failed. Parents are concerned about some of the activities of politically-motivated teacher unions. They are concerned about what their children are being taught. Let me list some of the courses which receive the benefit of participation equity program funding as provided for in one of the Bills before us today. These courses include child psychology, French for travellers, great mysteries of history, only one earth, self-esteem, coping with death and-believe it or not-growing up in the 1980s. In fact, in 1985 the New South Wales Board of Senior School Studies approved 1,100 OAS courses; that is, courses outside the traditional curriculum.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you believe those courses are all valueless?

—I believe that they have a place, but they should not take a major role. I agree that people require a complete education, but these courses should not become the major part of the curriculum. Unfortunately, a lot of the rationale for these kinds of courses rests upon a misplaced egalitarianism which does no good to those students who are persuaded to pursue such courses. Even the left wing teacher unions are sceptical about the moves to decentralise curricula.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is whether such courses advance the interests of our young people in being able to sell their labour in an increasingly competitive and highly regulated labour market. The disadvantages to the young in our system of unrealistic wage relativities are sufficient already without unleashing on the job market students who may feel good about themselves and who may know how to drive a car but will never be able to afford to buy one. Unfortunately, there seems to exist in Australia a widespread belief that by throwing money at a problem it will somehow go away. Also, in the education area there is the view that the education system is a means of removing inequality in society and redistributing benefits from one group to another. But the real point of the education system is to educate, with the emphasis on the fundamentals.

The problem with our education system is not related simply to funding levels. It is more a matter of accountability. Put simply, the providers of education-teachers, textbook writers, and course designers-must be more accountable to the consumer, the parents and students; to the indirect users, such as the employers; and to the providers of funds, the taxpayers. Clearly, the non-government sectors do not have the same problem with lack of accountability. Consumers simply have more meaningful choices and less bureaucratic control, and hence there appears to be less dissatisfaction with the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —And much less parental say in the schools.

—That is not true. One can only view with some trepidation the Government's recent manoeuvrings in the area of parental choice in education. If what Senator Zakharov says is the case, why is there such a great demand for people to move into the non-government sector?
—Mainly misleading advertising.

—The honourable senator would believe anything. The tertiary sector is a classic example of lack of accountability between providers of the service and their clients. Instead, there is only the heavy hand of government and the education bureaucracies. The service is so bad that some young people-many thousands-who qualify for tertiary places just cannot get in. Again, academic departments, course designers and lecturers-all tenured, of course-are responsible, not to their students, who do not have to pay for the service anyway, but to the bureaucracy that provides the money. Political decisions replace what are essentially economic choices and the students, their parents and employers suffer.

SPEECH.PARA: The education system is in trouble. The Australian economy is in trouble. We are wasting enormous talent by not properly training our young people. We are rendering meaningless their chances in life. Students are ill-prepared for higher education, many are forced on to the dole, and those who remain in the school system-not all of them but many-are encouraged to do courses which may well be of no use to them in later life, while neglecting other subjects that may be boring but which may offer many rewards, not just for those going on to higher learning. Such courses may make school more interesting, particularly for teachers, and temporarily may shorten the dole queues, but it should be remembered that the purpose of education is not simply to keep children at school for as long as possible, however good this might look on paper, but to provide our young people with usable skills and real choices of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the seven minutes that remain for debate tonight on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Legislation Amendment Bill and allied legislation, I want to support the remarks in part made by my Liberal colleagues-Senator Peter Baume, our shadow Minister for Education, and Senator Parer from the State of Queensland who has just preceded me-and indeed many of the remarks by Senator Macklin. All senators in this debate on these education Bills have felt that the provision for education in Australia is not adequate and is in need of being freed up to allow individuals and individual institutions to be creative to meet the needs of Australia, and to make an investment through education in the future of Australia. These Bills that are now before the Senate do not offer anything towards freeing up those structures to allow Australians to take the initiative free of the constraints to which Senator Parer has just referred in his analogy with the industrial system. Senator Parer rightly quoted the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who is in the chamber, on restrictions such as tariffs in industry and compared those with similar restrictions that occur when too many bureaucratic controls inhibit constructive decisions made by individuals and individual institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills that are before us are in the regular format that we see every six months. They amount to some $235m, most of which relates to grants to the States for tertiary education. They almost follow an arithmetical formula. There is no creativity in these Bills at all. They are purely supplementary and are designed to catch up with the rises in costs for programs that have already been committed. In the calendar year 1985, 1986 and 1987, there are supplementary provisions for tertiary education of $60m, $80m and $80m. There is provision of an additional $1.5m for the participation and equity program and an additional $15m for schools. All those amounts are purely the outcome of costs formulas that supplement rises in costs for the three respective years. This illustrates that these Bills are routine, machinery Bills.

There is no initiative in this legislation that relates to freeing up the structures and allowing initiatives such as my colleagues, and to some extent Senator Macklin, have called for. I predict that tomorrow or the next day when we complete this debate the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) will summarise these matters in a couple of sentences and the Bills will be passed. Nobody in the Senate is seeking to block these grants of money to the State governments to provide for education at the secondary and tertiary levels in this regular, six-monthly machinery way. But this legislation gives us the opportunity to make remarks and I will conclude my remarks when debate on these Bills resumes tomorrow. My principal remarks will repeat what I was saying earlier today when I spoke to the annual report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission for 1984. In that report and in the actions of the present Labor Government there are initiatives as to administration and structure which have political goals in mind and which have an entrenching administrative effect. I do not believe that this is the way in which this country should go.

I believe that the Commonwealth should be facilitating the meetings of representatives from the actual providers of education in the States-whether in the State education departments, in private schools, or, in the tertiary area, in the universities and colleges which are increasingly becoming autonomous institutions. They can implement good ideas and initiatives and, in taking a national approach, they should be able to gain curriculum ideas and programs which they can take back to their States and implement. To the extent that they represented in such a national or all Australian activity, they are not involved in a duplication of their efforts by the Commonwealth but in the Commonwealth facilitating their co-operation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Industrial Dispute: Latrobe Valley-Education: South Australia-Swan Island Lighthouse

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to put on the record the industrial problems being experienced in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria. I do this because I believe that the Electrical Trades Union is demonstrating very clearly that it is not abiding by the assurance that it has given to the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats sought and were given assurances by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the unions involved in the power strike that they would accept the outcome of the conciliation or arbitration process and would abide by it, and, secondly, that they would allow the proper means of discussion and conciliation to resolve the dispute without resort to further industrial action. In agreeing to abide by the decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, they in effect agreed to accept a no strike clause if the Commission decides that such a clause is necessary. Clearly, the ETU in the Latrobe Valley has broken that agreement even before the Democrats have voted for the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The ETU has voted for a compulsory $5 a week levy for every ETU worker for a fighting fund to support the ETU campaign in Queensland. A number of people were opposed to the compulsory levy in the ETU, as they saw themselves being involved not in an industrial dispute but in a political dispute. John McNamara, an ETU worker, has refused to pay into a central fund but is willing to support a needy strike affected family directly. He has said also that he would be prepared to accept the results of a secret ballot on a $5 per week levy if the ETU were prepared to put it to their members. Of course, the ETU was not prepared to accept that. Mr McNamara has been declared black and has been told that he will have to accept a different job and be changed to a different work area or lose his job. Mr Neilson Duff, an ETU member, has refused to pay his $5 levy and he has been told that he also will be black banned. At the Morwell brickworks, 11 shift electricians also have been black banned as a group for non-payment of their levy. A notice was placed on the brickworks notice board stating that unless retribution was made by the 11 members, backdated to the first pay period after 2 May, they also would be declared black and lose their jobs.

In contrast to the ETU standover tactics, all other unions involved in the electricity industry-the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, the Municipal Officers Association, the Federated Ironworkers Association, the Australian Workers Union and the Amalgamated Society of Carpenters and Joiners-have agreed to a voluntary levy of $5 a week, but not the ETU. It has demanded the levy, threatening workers and their jobs and declaring them black if they will not pay the levy. Mr John McNamara sent a telegram to Senator Jack Evans, the industrial spokesman for the Democrats, seeking his support against the Government's Queensland electricity legislation while the ETU continues to black ban him and other ETU members in the State Electricity Commission of Victoria.

I ask: Where do the Democrats stand on the issue of the Queensland electricity legislation? The Australian Democrats have sought assurances from the unions and they have been given to them; yet we find that in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria these assurances are being dishonoured already before the legislation has come before the Senate. I believe that the Democrats policy is not to accept compulsory levies on unions or black bans on workers; yet the ETU is doing both to its members in Victoria. I ask the Democrats to stand by their principles and oppose the Conciliation and Arbitration (Electricity Industry) Bill until this industrial problem is solved in the Latrobe Valley. In today's Courier-Mail there is a headline 'Delay in coal union action'. The Courier-Mail states that the workers are not prepared to go on strike lest they upset the Democrats' vote. I ask the Democrats to look very closely at the implications of this industrial dispute in the Latrobe Valley before they make their final decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to keep the Senate long this evening. I use the opportunity of this adjournment debate not to make a point that I believe everybody should follow on apolitical lines but to raise a matter of concern that I think everybody in the Senate should be interested in and should watch closely. I refer to the impending development of a special school for black pupils at Elizabeth in South Australia. We have often heard in this chamber and in the Press of the notion of separate race-based schools and other social or governmental functions being of benefit to the race that is segregated into that school or government function. We have all made comments on those sorts of attitudes. It concerns me greatly as a South Australian to see this sort of development in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence of having been in Canberra for the parliamentary sittings I have not had the opportunity to speak with all the people involved, but I do want to raise the matter in the Senate to alert honourable senators who may be interested to what is happening so that the development of the school can be watched very closely. I say 'watched very closely' rather than 'opposed' because I am not convinced, from what I have seen in the Press, that at the moment the development of this school should be opposed; I am convinced that it should be watched very closely. The first Press report that is available to me is one dated 23 May. Under the headline 'Vote defeats school for Aborigines' it says:
A plan for a separate Aboriginal school on the Elizabeth High School campus was narrowly vetoed by the Elizabeth High School council last night.
Nonetheless, the school still proceeds. The Adelaide Advertiser of 24 May states:

A separate Aboriginal primary school will be established on the Elizabeth High School campus despite opposition by the local city council, the Elizabeth High School Council, and some sections of the community.

I want to highlight to the Senate that, irrespective of this opposition, the school is still going ahead. I accept quite happily the comments of Mr Arnold, who is the South Australian Minister of Education-a Labor Government Minister-that he feels it is inappropriate at the moment for critics of the school to draw comparisons between what is happening in South Africa and what is happening in Elizabeth; that that is using excessively emotional tricks, if you like, in debate, and that we would be better informed if we drew analogies with New Zealand schools. I accept that. He may well be right. All I ask is that the Senate give close attention to this matter to make sure that Mr Arnold is right and that what appears to be an apartheid type of measure, a separate race-based school, is not allowed to develop into one that continues in that way from the primary school into the high school area.

Separate from my concern that this matter be watched so that education in South Australia, and for that matter Australia as a whole, is not allowed to develop on racist lines, is my concern that, despite the criticism that has been raised, the State Minister for Education has chosen to proceed anyway. In closing I cite a couple of comments from the Advertiser editorial of Monday, 27 May, which states:
Unease, and even alarm, are the consequences of any marked deviation from the path of natural race integration.

It is my position that integration is the way we should be going, not only with Aborigines but also with any people who choose to come to this country and that a separate apartheid-type system is inappropriate. I accept the comments that have been made by Mr Arnold that that is not the basis on which this school has been established. I simply ask that the Senate watch this matter and ensure that that is not the way in which the school is permitted to develop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly and in continuation on a matter which I have raised previously about the possible automation of the Swan Island lighthouse. On a previous occasion I raised certain matters and the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is at the table, said that she would endeavour to obtain from her colleague the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) certain answers for me. I am looking forward to receiving those. In the meantime, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a Press release dated 12 May 1985 which begins:

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposing the automation of the lighthouse at Swan Island are creating a public mischief, the Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, said today.
It was dated 12 May and was published on 24 May after the debate had taken place in this chamber. I seek leave to incorporate the Press release.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MODERN TECHNOLOGY VITAL FOR OUR LIGHTHOUSES
Those opposing the automation of the lighthouse at Swan Island are creating a public mischief, the Federal Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, said today.
'It is vital that our lighthouses are equipped with the most up-to-date technology for the safety of all shipping dependent on that light.'
Mr Morris stressed that the automation of a lighthouse does not necessarily mean that staff will be withdrawn.
'But Australia's shipping industry-which pays for the costs of our navigational aids in full-is entitled to the safest and most economical service that it can afford.'

'The Prime Minister has given a firm commitment to the Premier of Tasmania that we will consult with the Tasmanian Government before any decisions were taken that might affect the staffing of Tasmania's lighthouses.'
'We remain committed to that undertaking. When the Government has more specific plans beyond those announced to the Parliament last year, that consultative process will be initiated.'

'Until then, it should be understood that the equipment currently in service at Swan Island is old and may soon prove to be quite unreliable. Clearly, upgrading is required, and to that end modern, automatic reliable equipment has been acquired.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The Press release was issued with the formal ministerial Press releases in a group dated 23 May but it was published on 24 May. I also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a letter dated 16 May addressed to me and signed by the Minister for Transport in which he makes none of the comments and none of the references which he makes in the Press release which was alleged to have been published four days prior to the letter. I seek leave to incorporate the Minister's letter in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
MINISTER FOR TRANSPORT
Parliament House Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Senator Rae,
Thank you for your letter of 24 April 1985 and your telegram of 3 May 1985 referring to Swan Island lighthouse.

I can assure you that full consultation will take place with the Tasmanian Government and other interested parties in developing the lighthouse conversion program. The procedures that I outlined in my statement to the Parliament in October 1984 will be followed.

At the time of the inquiry the Department of Transport made it clear in its submission that the equipment at Swan Island was approaching the end of its economic life. In the interest of safety new equipment to up date this important light has been purchased and is now stored at Hobart. No decision has been made regarding its installation.

Following the resignation of the Head Lightkeeper at Gabo Island the Head Lightkeeper from Swan Island was transferred to replace him on the basis of his merits. He in turn has been relieved by the lightkeeper from Bruny Island and a replacement taken on to fill that position. These are normal movements that occur in the lighthouse service and are in no way intended to pre-empt the consultative processes I outlined to the Parliament.

I will shortly be in contact with the Tasmanian Government and other interested parties, such as the Australian Lighthouse Association, to commence the consultative process recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure.
Yours sincerely,
PETER MORRIS
Senator Peter RaeSenator for Tasmania,Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply placed those documents in the record and I hope that the Minister will be able to obtain for me not only the answers which she promised to obtain previously but also some explanation of the obvious inconsistency between the two documents which I have incorporated. I thank the Senate for granting leave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Boswell raised matters and made some comments concerning the dispute involving the Electrical Trades Union and the terms of legislation arising from that dispute. His concern seemed to be mainly with the Australian Democrats and therefore it is not appropriate for me to reply. However, I will ensure that his remarks are drawn to the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone raised some concerns about a proposed Aboriginal school at Elizabeth in South Australia. I listened carefully to Senator Vanstone's remarks. I have some difficulty in identifying the basis of her concern. I simply state that the matter of registration of schools, be they based on religious, cultural or any other particular philosophy, is a matter for State governments. It is not a matter over which the Commonwealth has any control. Once schools are registered, they are in a position to seek recurrent and capital funding from the Commonwealth Government. They must fulfil a number of criteria but the basis, be it philosophical, religious or cultural, of the organisation of the school is not a criterion which the Commonwealth takes into account. However, it is the case that the Commonwealth currently funds over 2,500 schools in the non-government sector, many of which are organised to promote a particular religious, philosophical or cultural view. Given the Commonwealth's willingness to fund schools on that basis, I cannot see any automatic problem with Commonwealth funding for that school should it secure registration from the State Government. I suggest that Senator Vanstone pursue the matter in more detail with the South Australian Minister for Education with whom will lie the power and the responsibility for the registration of that school. In arriving at a decision regarding registration, it is the responsibility of the State Minister to ensure that the curriculum, standard of teaching and standard of facilities available for the children are satisfactory in terms of the educational standards of that State.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.44 p.m.
