QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Defence any plans to reduce or close down its facilities at Singleton in New South Wales.

(2) Have any studies been conducted about the desirability of centralising all Army facilities in non-metropolitan New South Wales at one location; if so, what recommendations have been made or are currently under consideration.
(3) Has the Singleton area been considered as a possible site for the Army's training area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I announced on 9 May the commencement of detailed studies on the suitability of an area between Bathurst and Orange as a site for the Army's School of Artillery and Infantry Centre. I also announced that the Government would investigate ways to maintain a significant Army presence in Singleton. This would be in the event that the Government decided to move the Infantry Centre from Singleton to the Bathurst-Orange area. Such a move would be unlikely until well into the 1990s.
(2) Such studies have not been conducted by my Department.

(3) Yes. A potential training area near Bathurst-Orange is being studied, however, because the existing military area at Singleton is too small for planned artillery training. Additional areas recommended by the New South Wales Government at Singleton would be unsuitable because of their precipitous and heavily timbered terrain and inaccessibility to vehicles and artillery. Use of other areas near the existing base would conflict with economic and social development of the area, and could be much more costly than the Bathurst-Orange option.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 28 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment aware of the poor condition of the road through Uluru National Park to the Olgas.

(2) Does the Minister acknowledge the need to maintain the road in safe condition for motorists, given the heavy tourist traffic the road carries between two of the Northern Territory's major tourist attractions.
(3) What does the Minister consider to be an appropriate level of upgrading needed to be undertaken on the road.

(4) Does the Minister believe that the $100,000 currently set aside by the National Parks and Wildlife Service for upgrading the road is sufficient to bring the road up to a suitable standard to deal with the volume of traffic it carries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Latest advice to me is that currently the road is in reasonable condition following maintenance work and the upgrading of certain sections.
(2) Yes.
(3) Planning is proceeding on a project to construct a sealed road to the Olgas and the proposal will need to be considered by the Parliamentary Public Works Committee due to costs involved.

(4) The $100,000 for upgrading the road to the Olgas this financial year is adequate in view of the proposal to construct a sealed road on a new alignment as soon as funds are available. Over $1.4m has been spent since 1981 on upgrading, to a sealed standard, the more heavily trafficked roads in Uluru National Park, particularly the circular road around Ayers Rock.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen a report from the Central American Health Rights Network claiming that United States of America backed contras fighting against the Nicaraguan Government have destroyed medical facilities and killed doctors and nurses in a campaign to terrorise the rural population; if so:
(a) what is the Australian Government's attitude to these reported killings;
(b) will the Government ask the United States Administration to use its influence to stop these attacks;
(c) will the Government submit this report to the United Nations Committee on Human Rights for investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer:

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen the report referred to and am aware also of other more general reports dealing with alleged human rights abuses by anti-Santinista contra forces. This and other information available to the Australian Government suggests that contra forces have pursued a policy of destroying health centres and schools and have sought to intimidate and terrorise the population. Indiscriminate attacks also appear to have been carried out against civilians.

(a) The Government has consistently opposed the use of military force in Central America and on a number of occasions has expressed publicly its concern about contra activity and conveyed its views on the subject to the United States Administration. Reports of human rights abuses by the contras, particularly those directed at civilians or medical personnel, are cause for added concern and are to be deplored.
(b) I have made arrangements for the Government's views on this particular issue to be brought to the attention of the US authorities.

(c) The Commission on Human Rights is an intergovernmental body which meets in February/March each year. The Commission will next meet in 1986. Under the procedures adopted by the United Nations, there are possibilities for private individuals and non-government organisations themselves to bring human rights matters to the attention of the Commission. In the case of the report in question, the most appropriate course of action would therefore be for the authors of the report, if they so wish, to submit the report through the established United Nations channels for consideration by the Commission.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Employment and Job Creation: Trojan Owen and Associates

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many projects under the Commonwealth Employment Scheme or the Federal Employment Creation Program has the firm of Trojan Owen and Associates of 189 Greenhill Road, Parkside: (a) proposed; or (b) been associated with.
(2) Was a housing project in Thebarton, South Australia and a yabby farm project funded by the Federal Government's Job Program and was the firm referred to in (1) above involved in these projects.

(2) A project sponsored by Thebarton Council titled 'Kilmore Street Development' was funded under the WPP. My Department has no record of Trojan Owen and Associates being involved in this project.
Yabby farm projects sponsored by the Gerard Reserve Council were approved under the WPP and the CEP and Trojan Owen and Associates were engaged by the sponsor as consultants.
(3) Trojan Owen and Associates are known to have been involved in the following approved CEP projects:

Gerard Reserve Council-Yabby Farm Development; Gerard Reserve Council-Yabby Farm Development Stage 2; Kuipto Colony Inc.-Redevelopment of Kuipto Colony; City of Burnside-Redevelopment of Chelsea Theatre; City of Burnside-Indoor Sporting Complex Construction; District Council of Victor Harbour-Indoor Recreation Centre; City of Noarlunga-Onkaparinga Estuary Conservation and Development; City of Port Adelaide-Linear Reserve Taperoo Beach; Development Adelaide Central Mission-Redevelopment of Mission House; Department of Fisheries-Aquaculture Research Station; Memorial Drive Tennis Club-Public Administration and Club Facilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 April 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Australian Government collate all information relating to deprivation of human rights in South Africa and submit it to the United Nations Human Rights Committee for investigation in view of the recent killing of at least 19 black South Africans on 21 March 1985 when police opened fire on a funeral procession in Cape Province, South Africa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government's abhorrence of apartheid is on public record. It has been made clear in the Commission on Human Rights, of which Australia is a member. The Minister for Foreign Affairs made a public statement on 22 March expressing the Government's outrage at the deaths of Uitenhage to which Senator Bolkus has referred. The Government condemns the use of violence by the South African Government.

The question of human rights in southern Africa is regularly on the agenda of a number of United Nations bodies, including the Commission on Human Rights. Member states take the opportunity to address the Commission in some detail. Australia made a statement at the last session in February 1985 reaffirming its opposition to apartheid.

Each year the Commission examines the report of the Ad Hoc Working Group of Experts on southern Africa, a group set up by the United Nations to make enquiries and prepare reports of the kind that Senator Bolkus is seeking on human rights violations in South Africa. Furthermore, the Commission has mechanisms through which it receives communications about human rights abuses from individuals and non-government organisations. Additional and often first hand information on the situation in southern Africa is thus brought to the Commission's attention.

In the light of these comprehensive arrangements, it does not appear to be necessary for the Australian Government to collate information relating to the deprivation of human rights in South Africa for submission to the Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 22 April, 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given that the Federal Government's Skills in Demand Program will fund re-training for over 900 nurses in New South Wales and Western Australia, what involvement is anticipated by other States.
(2) Has the Queensland Government rejected the opportunity to re-train nurses under the auspices of the program referred to in (1) above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Most States/Territories are developing proposals for funding nurse refresher course training under the Skills in Demand Program administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The development and negotiation of proposals are at varying stages in different States and Territories.

(2) In Queensland discussions on the need for such training are continuing between the DEIR, relevant unions, hospitals and the Queensland Department of Health. No sponsoring body has been nominated. Consequently no proposal for SID funding has yet been received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice, on 8 May 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government currently funding some scientific publications in Australia such as Techlink, but has decided not to fund the National Journal of Science Search.

(2) Does the Government already provide copies for high schools of scientific publications including Ecos and Sci-file, which report only on developments in the CSIRO, and the Atomic Energy Commission's Nuclear News.
(3) Will the Government consider funding the National Journal of Science, Search to the extent of providing copies of the journal for Australian high schools; if not, why not.

(4) Is the Government aware that in countries with similarly small scientific communities to Australia's, journals such as Search are subsidised by their governments, as is the case with Sweden's Ambio and India's Current Science.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Techlink is produced by SIROTECH, a company set up by CSIRO to deal with technology transfer and commercial assessment.

Search is the journal of the Australian and New Zealand Association for the advancement of Science. A Committee of the ANZAAS Council is currently considering the future of Search. Until a decision is reached by the Council, no consequential decision about government funding for Search can be taken.

(2) The CSIRO quarterly Ecos is not supplied free to high schools, but high schools are among the subscribers to the magazine. The subscription rate is $7 per year. Sci-file provides schools with accounts of CSIRO research of relevance to teachers. It is issued free once a term. Sci-file is also available on subscription at $2 per copy a term to members of the public and teachers requiring additional copies. The Atomic Energy Commission does not fall within the Science portfolio, but I am advised that Nuclear News, a 4 page leaflet style publication, is distributed free to most high schools.
(3) Refer to paragraph 2 of answer to (1).
(4) The Government is not aware of the details of subsidisation arrangements for science publications in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Aulich asked the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment the following question, without notice, on 19 April 1985:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to attacks by the Tasmanian Premier on the register of the National Estate and its effects on Tasmanian development. Is the Minister aware that the Premier has described the register as a Commonwealth takeover, and land grab et cetera? Is the Minister aware of the open letter placed by Mr Cohen in the Tasmanian media outlining the truth about the register of the National Estate?
The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
There appears to have been a campaign, for some time, in Tasmania, to spread false information about the role and function of the Register of the National Estate.
Heritage Week was considered a fitting time for the Commonwealth Government to provide some facts in the debate in Tasmania about the Register of the National Estate to prevent people being misled.

The letter in particular stated what the Register is-a cultural inventory that has no direct effect on a listed place or on the obligations of private owners or occupiers of that place. The letter indicated that it is not a land grab or an excuse for conservationists to stop progress. The letter also reminded the public of the $10m that the Commonwealth has provided to Tasmania's heritage for both the National Estate and Port Arthur Programs.

Finally the letter invited all Tasmanians to provide the Government with comments on the National Estate as part of a previously announced review of the processes of the Australian Heritage Commission Act.
